Penal Law § 265.03 (3), making it a class C felony for anyone previously convicted of any crime to possess an unlicensed, loaded firearm in his home or elsewhere, easily passed that test. It is beyond dispute that preventing the criminal use of firearms is an important government objective; and keeping guns away from people who have shown they cannot be trusted to obey the law is a means substantially related to that end. More specifically, to punish severely a convicted criminal such as defendant who, though eligible for a license, again violated the law by obtaining an unlicensed gun was a means well-suited to the end of assuring that lawbreakers do not have firearms. Defendant's 3 1/2 year sentence was not draconian and did not raise constitutional problems.

 

40 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Brightonian Nursing Home v. Daines


No. 161


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


21 N.Y.3d 570; 999 N.E.2d 510; 977 N.Y.S.2d 147; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 2805; 2013 NY Slip Op 6636


September 11, 2013, Argued 
October 15, 2013, Decided


DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review reversed, with costs, and judgment granted to defendants declaring that Public Health Law § 2808 (5) (c) is constitutional to the extent challenged.


CASE SUMMARY:


OVERVIEW: ISSUE: Whether the trial court erred in granting respondents summary judgment on the basis that Public Health Law § 2808(5)(c), which prohibited the withdrawal or transfer of certain residential health care facility equity or assets without prior permission from appellant New York Commissioner of Health, was facially unconstitutional. HOLDINGS: [1]-The lower courts erred in finding that § 2808(5)(c) violated substantive due process because its purposes were legitimate, and its limited constraint on access to facility funds within a 90-day period was justified by the legislature's election to avoid financially improvident withdrawals; [2]-Section 2808(5)(c)'s catch-all phrase--"and such other factors as the Commissioner deems appropriate"--was not an improper delegation of legislative policy-making power and thus was not an affront to the separation of powers.


OUTCOME: The high court reversed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court and granted judgment to appellants declaring that § 2808(5)(c) was constitutional to the extent challenged.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Restrictions on Equity Withdrawals and Asset Transfers by Nursing Homes -- Substantive Due Process 

1. Public Health Law § 2808 (5) (c), which prohibits the withdrawal or transfer of residential health care facility equity or assets in an aggregate amount exceeding three percent of the facility's most recently reported annual revenue from patient care services without the prior approval of the State Commissioner of Health, does not violate the substantive due process property interests of facility owners. Economic regulation will violate an individual's substantive due process property interest only in those situations where there is absolutely no reasonable relationship to be perceived between the regulation and the achievement of a legitimate governmental purpose. The regulation here is not so outrageously arbitrary as to constitute a gross abuse of governmental authority, and plaintiffs have not met their extraordinary burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the challenged provision suffers wholesale constitutional impairment. The legislature's prescription of means, particularly in the arena of economic regulation, is entitled to judicial deference so long as those means are in a very broad sense reasonably related to the achievement of a permissible regulatory end. In employing the three percent threshold based on annual facility revenue, the legislature put in place a mechanism that would at once identify contemplated withdrawals sufficiently substantial to be of legitimate regulatory concern, and afford owners of facilities with positive net worth a measure of unregulated access to facility assets and equity. Moreover, nursing homes are with ample historical and practical justification pervasively regulated and, in that context particularly, the additional regulatory increment cannot be viewed as a constitutionally untoward assault upon the private property interests of facility owners.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Restrictions on Equity Withdrawals and Asset Transfers by Nursing Homes -- Separation of Powers 

2. Public Health Law § 2808 (5) (c), which prohibits the withdrawal or transfer of residential health care facility equity or assets in an aggregate amount exceeding three percent of the facility's most recently reported annual revenue from patient care services without the prior approval of the State Commissioner of Health, does not unconstitutionally delegate legislative policy-making power to the Commissioner by the statute's use of the catch-all phrase "and such other factors as the commissioner deems appropriate." The enumerated criteria to be reviewed by the Commissioner in reviewing a withdrawal or transfer application tie the Commissioner's disposition of the application to the financial condition of the facility and its quality of care record. Those are highly pertinent and not excessively general criteria and the catch-all's immediately subsequent reference to "such other factors" does not authorize application dispositions based on criteria that are generically different.

 

41 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Osterweil v. Bartlett


No. 167


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


21 N.Y.3d 580; 999 N.E.2d 516; 977 N.Y.S.2d 153; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 2807; 2013 NY Slip Op 6637


September 12, 2013, Argued 
October 15, 2013, Decided


DISPOSITION: Following certification of a question by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and acceptance of the question by this Court pursuant to section 500.27 of the Rules of Practice of the New York State Court of Appeals, and after hearing argument by counsel for the parties and consideration of the briefs and the record submitted, certified question answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


OVERVIEW: ISSUE: Whether an applicant for a New York State pistol/revolver license who owned a part-time residence in New York but made his permanent domicile elsewhere was eligible for a New York handgun license in the city or county where his part-time residence was located. HOLDINGS: [1]-Penal Law § 400.00(3)(a) did not preclude an individual who owned a part-time residence in New York but made his permanent domicile in another state from applying for a New York handgun license because there was no intent by the Legislature to exclude applicants on the basis of domicile; [2]-Since a handgun license could be issued, under Penal Law § 400.00(7), to a person who was not usually a resident in New York State, there was no requirement of domicile.


OUTCOME: Certified question answered in the affirmative.


HEADNOTES

Licenses -- Firearms -- No Domicile Requirement for Handgun License 

Penal Law §400.00 (3) (a) does not preclude an individual who owns a part-time residence in New York but makes his or her permanent domicile in another state from applying for a New York handgun license. Generally, establishing residence turns on whether one has a significant connection with some locality in the state as the result of living there for some length of time during the course of a year, whereas domicile requires a physical presence in a place with an intention to make the place a permanent home. Thus, an individual can have more than one residence, but only one domicile. Penal Law §400.00 (3) (a) refers to the applicant's residence in the context of delineating the procedure whereby an individual files an application for a license, instructing the applicant to apply to the licensing officer in the city or county where he or she resides (or is principally employed, etc.). The plain language of the statute is not consistent with the theory that the law requires an applicant to establish domicile as an eligibility requirement. Moreover, the legislative history of the statutes that underlay Penal Law § 400.00 evinces an intent to ensure that an applicant applies in his or her place of residence, rather than an intent to limit licenses to applicants who make their domicile in New York. The residency language was added in order to discourage forum-shopping. Most conclusively, Penal Law § 400.00 itself contemplates that licenses may be issued to individuals who do not make their domicile in New York. Since a handgun license may be issued, under Penal Law § 400.00 (7), to "an alien, or to a person not a citizen of and usually a resident" in New York State, it is clear that there is no requirement of domicile.

 

42 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Chenango Forks Cent. Sch. Dist. v. New York State Pub. Empl. Rels. Bd.


No. 104


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


21 N.Y.3d 255; 993 N.E.2d 386; 970 N.Y.S.2d 900; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 1429; 2013 NY Slip Op 4039; 195 L.R.R.M. 3011


April 25, 2013, Argued 
June 6, 2013, Decided


DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant school district sought judicial review in the Appellate Division (New York) of a decision by the New York State Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) that the district violated the Public Employees Fair Employment Act (Taylor Law), Civil Service Law § 209-a(1)(d) by unilaterally discontinuing Medicare Part B premium reimbursement. The Appellate Division affirmed the decision, and the district sought further review.


OVERVIEW: In grievance proceedings, an arbitrator said the district's past practice of reimbursing premiums was not shown. In unfair labor practice proceedings, an administrative law judge did not defer to the arbitrator, and the PERB agreed. The court of appeals held this was reasonable because (1) his findings on past practice under the Taylor Law fell outside his authority, (2) his decision as to past practice under the Taylor Law was repugnant to that statute, as he found no mutual understanding sufficient to establish a binding past practice, but a binding past practice under the Taylor Law did not require mutual understanding, and (3) he did not rule there was no past practice under the Taylor Law, as he only said historical practices did not show a contract right to reimbursement of the premiums. Substantial evidence supported PERB's decision because the district's statutory permission to reimburse the premiums, under N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1, came from the definition of "terms and conditions of employment" (Civil Service Law § 201(4)) and the bargaining right in certain binding past practices.


OUTCOME: The Appellate Division's judgment was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Civil Service -- Public Employment Relations Board -- Improper Employer Practice -- Discontinuing Reimbursement of Medicare Part B Premiums of Certain Retirees

1. Respondent Public Employment Relations Board's determination that petitioner School District had committed an improper employer practice by discontinuing petitioner's practice of reimbursing Medicare Part B premiums of certain retirees, made after the arbitrator in a related contract grievance arbitration ruled that petitioner was not contractually obligated to reimburse the premiums, was not based upon an error of law or arbitrary and capricious, and was supported by substantial evidence. In order for respondent in an improper practice proceeding to defer to an arbitration award it must be satisfied that the issues raised by the improper practice charge were fully litigated in the arbitration proceeding, that arbitral proceedings were not tainted by unfairness or serious procedural irregularities, and that the determination of the arbitrator was not clearly repugnant to the purposes and policies of the Taylor Law. It was reasonable for respondent not to defer to any finding of the arbitrator that there was no binding past practice under the Taylor Law: identity of issues was lacking and, to the extent the arbitrator purported to determine there was no past practice within the meaning of the Taylor Law, he exceeded his authority and his finding was repugnant to that statute. Moreover, respondent's decision in regard to past practice was supported by substantial evidence. Petitioner's knowledge of the payments was shown by the managerial oversight necessary to make them, as well as the memorandum circulated to its faculty and staff, announcing termination of petitioner's practice of reimbursing the premiums. Respondent Union's and bargaining unit employees' knowledge was established by the testimony given at the hearing.

Constitutional Law -- Gift of Public Funds -- Reimbursement of Medicare Part B Premiums of Certain School District Retirees 

2. Reimbursement by petitioner School District of the Medicare Part B premiums of certain retirees was not an unconstitutional gift of public funds (see NY Const, art VIII, § 1). Respondent Public Employment Relations Board, in determining that petitioner had committed an improper employer practice by discontinuing petitioner's practice of reimbursing Medicare Part B premiums of certain retirees, found that the practice was a binding past practice under the Taylor Law. Although school districts may not "give or loan any money or property" (NY Const, art VIII, § 1) unless expressly authorized by law or pursuant to a contract term, the statutory permission here came from the definition of "terms and conditions of employment" (Civil Service Law § 201 [4]) and the bargaining right in certain binding past practices. As respondent Union had the right to reimbursement under the Taylor Law, the reimbursement could not be an unconstitutional gift of public funds.

 

43 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Greater N.Y. Taxi Assn. v. State


No. 98, No. 99, No. 100


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


21 N.Y.3d 289; 993 N.E.2d 393; 970 N.Y.S.2d 907; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 1431; 2013 NY Slip Op 4044


and submitted April 24, 2013, Argued 
June 6, 2013, Decided


DISPOSITION: For Each Case: Judgment, insofar as appealed from, reversed, with costs, and judgment granted to defendants declaring that Chapter 602 of the Laws of 2011, as amended by Chapter 9 of the Laws of 2012, is constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs sued defendant State of New York and others, challenging the constitutionality of the HAIL Act, a law regulating medallion taxicabs (or "yellow cabs") and livery vehicles in New York City. The supreme court (New York) entered a judgment nullifying the HAIL Act, and declaring that it violated the municipal home rule, double enactment and exclusive privileges clauses of the New York Constitution. Defendants appealed.


OVERVIEW: The court concluded that the HAIL Act addressed a matter of substantial state concern. This was not a purely local issue. The Act bore a reasonable relationship to the substantial state interest of increasing the supply of accessible yellow cabs in New York City. Efficient transportation services in the state's largest city and international center of commerce was important to the entire state. The Act plainly furthered all of these significant goals. Because the Act addressed substantials state concerns and bore a reasonable relationship to those concerns, the supreme court erred in concluding that the Act violated the municipal home rule clause. The court rejected plaintiffs' arguments that the Act violated the double enactment clause. The Act did not violate the exclusive privileges clause.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the supreme court was reversed, and judgment was granted to defendants.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Statute Regulating Medallion Taxicabs and Livery Vehicles in City of New York -- Municipal Home Rule Clause 

1. Chapter 602 of the Laws of 2011, as amended by chapter 9 of the Laws of 2012 (HAIL Act), which regulates medallion taxicabs and livery vehicles and addresses certain mobility deficiencies in the City of New York, does not violate NY Constitution, article IX, § 2 (b) (2) (Municipal Home Rule Clause). Although the HAIL Act is a special law and the Municipal Home Rule Clause could be read to direct that a home rule message was required before the Act's enactment, there is an exception to that requirement where the State possesses a substantial interest in the subject matter and the enactment bears a reasonable relationship to the legitimate, accompanying substantial State concern. In addressing the lack of yellow cabs within the Manhattan central business district that are accessible to the disabled and the general shortage of available yellow cab and livery vehicle transportation in underserved areas of the City, the HAIL Act addresses a substantial state concern. Efficient transportation services in the State's largest city and international center of commerce are important to the entire State. Moreover, the Act bears a reasonable relationship to that substantial State concern. It consists of a series of interlocking provisions to address its stated purposes. The delegation of a portion of the Act's implementation to the Mayor pursuant to section 8 of the Act was within the State legislature's purview and did not transfer any of the City Council's powers to the Mayor. Section 9's requirement calling for the Taxi and Limousine Commission's establishment of a grant program to distribute up to $54 million in grants for the purchase or retrofitting of accessible HAIL vehicles does not interfere with the City Council's budgeting authority. Nor does section 23 of the Act, which requires that penalties for violations of the Act be transferred to the entity that issued the summons for a HAIL vehicle violation, intrude on the City's finances, as the City maintains control over the funds derived from its law enforcement entities that enforce the Act, while the New York State Police receive monies for the summonses they issue.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Statute Regulating Medallion Taxicabs and Livery Vehicles in City of New York -- Double Enactment Clause 

2. Chapter 602 of the Laws of 2011, as amended by chapter 9 of the Laws of 2012 (HAIL Act), which regulates medallion taxicabs and livery vehicles and addresses certain mobility deficiencies in the City of New York, does not violate NY Constitution, article IX, § 2 (b) (1) (Double Enactment Clause). It has not been demonstrated that the HAIL Act "repealed, diminished, impaired or suspended" any power in "a statute of local governments" so as to require reenactment and approval of the Act the year after it was enacted. The HAIL Act, which addresses the lack of yellow cabs within the Manhattan central business district that are accessible to the disabled and the general shortage of available yellow cab and livery vehicle transportation in underserved areas of the City, addresses a matter of substantial state concern and bears a reasonable relationship to that concern. The Double Enactment Clause is no more exacting on the limits of state power than the Municipal Home Rule Clause, which the Act does not violate.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Statute Regulating Medallion Taxicabs and Livery Vehicles in City of New York -- Exclusive Privileges Clause

3. Chapter 602 of the Laws of 2011, as amended by chapter 9 of the Laws of 2012 (HAIL Act), which regulates medallion taxicabs and livery vehicles and addresses certain mobility deficiencies in the City of New York, does not violate NY Constitution, article III, § 17 (Exclusive Privileges Clause). The Exclusive Privileges Clause, which targets monopolies, may only be violated if the private or local bill is directed at a single entity and it confers a privilege upon the single entity to the exclusion of all others. The HAIL Act's licensing provisions apply to a class consisting of close to 60,000 livery vehicle drivers and owners. Although the Act provides that within the first three years of the first issuance, HAIL licenses may be issued only to owners of for-hire vehicles or for-hire drivers who have been licensed by the Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC) for at least one year and are in good standing with the TLC (HAIL Act § 5 [b]), that does not limit the number of people who may obtain one. In order to qualify, all one needs to do is obtain a TLC license, operate a livery vehicle for one year and maintain good standing with the TLC. Thus, the number of persons who are able to obtain HAIL licenses will likely vary over time. That is not the type of "exclusivity" that the clause was meant to prohibit.

 

44 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Empire State Ch. of Associated Bldrs. & Contrs., Inc. v. Smith


No. 101


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


21 N.Y.3d 309; 992 N.E.2d 1067; 970 N.Y.S.2d 724; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 1432; 2013 NY Slip Op 4038


April 24, 2013, Argued 
June 6, 2013, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a contractor, its owner and employee, a contractors association, and a county, sued defendants, challenging an amendment to New York's Wicks Act. The trial court dismissed the case; plaintiffs appealed. The New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division, held that the county had standing, reinstated the complaint to the extent it sought declaratory relief, and declared the amendment constitutional. Plaintiffs sought further review.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs claimed that the amendment violated N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2 (the Home Rule section) by unjustifiably loosening Wicks Law restrictions to a greater extent for eight counties than for the other counties. The intermediate appellate court held that the county had standing to assert the Home Rule claim, but that that claim failed on the merits. The high court agreed. As the amendment related to both to the property and affairs of local governments and to a matter of substantial statewide concern--the manner of bidding on public construction contracts--N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 3(a)(3), as the high court had interpreted it, established that art. IX, § 2(b)(2) did not prevent the State from enacting the amendment. However, the complaint's allegations that the apprenticeship provisions of Labor Law § 222(2)(e) excluded out-of-state contractors from some public construction work in New York, in violation of the U.S. Constitution's Privileges and Immunities Clause and Commerce Clause, were sufficient to survive defendants' motion to dismiss. Plaintiffs' remaining causes of action were properly dismissed.


OUTCOME: The high court modified the decision of the intermediate appellate court to reinstate plaintiffs' claims alleging that Labor Law § 222(2)(e) violated the U.S. Constitution; as so modified, the judgment was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Special Law Serving Substantial State Concern -- Concurrent Authority of State and Local Legislatures

1. The Home Rule section of the State Constitution (art IX, § 2 [b] [2]) does not require an examination into the reasonableness of the distinctions the legislature has made where it has enacted a law of statewide impact on a matter of substantial state concern but has not treated all areas of the state alike. While the language of article IX, § 2 seems broadly to prohibit, in the absence of either a "home rule message" or a certificate of necessity from the governor, the enactment of any special law, i.e., one which applies to one or more, but not all, counties, in relation to the property, affairs or government of any local government, it was long ago recognized that there must be a sizeable area of overlap in which the state legislature acting by special law and local governments have concurrent powers. Article IX, § 3 (a) (3) of the State Constitution, which provides that "Except as expressly provided, nothing in this article shall restrict or impair any power of the legislature in relation to . . . [m]atters other than the property, affairs or government of a local government," is not a mere redundancy. A great deal of legislation relates both to "the property, affairs or government of a local government" and to "[m]atters other than the property, affairs or government of a local government"--i.e., to matters of substantial state concern. Where that is true, section 3 (a) (3), establishes that section 2 (b) (2) does not prevent the state from acting by special law.

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Special Law Serving Substantial State Concern -- Reasonableness Analysis Not Required -- Public Works Contracts

2. Amendments to the Wicks Law, which requires public entities seeking bids on construction contracts to obtain "separate specifications" for plumbing, electrical and HVAC (heating, ventilating and air conditioning) work where contract costs exceed a certain threshold amount, were not forbidden by the Home Rule section of the State Constitution (art IX, § 2 [b]) notwithstanding that the amendments set differing monetary thresholds for the applicability of the Wicks Law for different counties (L 2008, ch 57, part MM, §§ 1, 2-6, 14) and neither a "home rule message" nor a certificate of necessity from the governor accompanied the legislation. There is a sizeable area of overlap in which the state legislature and local governments have concurrent powers and where there is a matter of substantial state concern the State can act by special law. Inasmuch as it was obvious and undisputed that the manner of bidding on public construction contracts is a matter of substantial state concern, an examination into the reasonableness of the distinctions the legislature made by setting different contract cost thresholds for different counties was not required. The Home Rule provisions were intended to prevent unjustifiable state interference in matters of purely local concern and no such interference occurred here.

Constitutional Law -- Interstate Commerce -- Challenge to Legislation Favoring In-State over Out-of-State Contractors

3. On a CPLR 3211 motion to dismiss, plaintiffs' complaint sufficiently alleged that the apprenticeship requirements in the second sentence of Labor Law § 222 (2) (e), which requires contractors bidding on public construction contracts exceeding certain cost thresholds to "participate in apprentice training programs in the trades of work it employs that have been approved by the department [of labor] for not less than three years and shall have graduated at least one apprentice in the last three years and shall have at least one apprentice currently enrolled in such apprenticeship training program," unconstitutionally excluded out-of-state contractors from some public construction work in New York. The Federal Commerce Clause has a "dormant" aspect, and along with the Privileges and Immunities Clause, limits the power of states to give preferential treatment to their own citizens. If the effect of the second sentence of section 222 (2) (e) is to exclude out-of-state contractors from bidding on certain New York contracts, both the Privileges and Immunities Clause and the dormant Commerce Clause would be violated. While defendants' contention that the challenged provision does not apply to all projects but only to those projects that are undertaken pursuant to project labor agreements is a reasonable one, and minimizes the constitutional problem, if section 222 (2) (e) unconstitutionally discriminates against out-of-state contractors, it is invalid whether it applies to many projects or to relatively few. From the face of the complaint, the statute and the relevant regulations, it could not be concluded that the apprenticeship requirements were not exclusionary.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Substantive Due Process -- Amendments to Wicks Law

4. Amendments to the Wicks Law which set differing monetary thresholds for the applicability of the law for different counties and establish apprenticeship requirements applicable to bidders for public contracts (L 2008, ch 57, part MM) did not deprive plaintiffs either of equal protection or of substantive due process under the Federal or State Constitution. The allegations of the complaint did not show that any provision of the amendments to the Wicks Law divided persons into classes, or deprived any person of property, without a rational basis, or that any such provision infringed any plaintiff's fundamental right or intentionally discriminated against a protected class.

Parties -- Standing -- Citizen Taxpayer Challenge to Amendments to Wicks Law

5. Plaintiffs lacked standing to challenge certain amendments to the Wicks Law which set differing monetary thresholds for the applicability of the law for different counties and establish apprenticeship requirements applicable to bidders for public contracts (L 2008, ch 57, part MM) pursuant to State Finance Law § 123-b, which permits any "citizen taxpayer" to bring an action against a state officer or employee for causing "a wrongful expenditure, misappropriation, misapplication, or . . . other illegal or unconstitutional disbursement of state funds." To the extent that plaintiffs' claims related to state expenditures, they were merely claims that state funds were not being spent wisely, not that it was illegal to spend money at all for the questioned activity. Accordingly, plaintiffs failed to allege a sufficient nexus to fiscal activities of the state to allow for section 123-b standing.

 

45 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



James Sq. Assoc. LP v. Mullen


No. 87


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


21 N.Y.3d 233; 993 N.E.2d 374; 970 N.Y.S.2d 888; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 1401; 2013 NY Slip Op 3935


April 23, 2013, Argued 
June 4, 2013, Decided


DISPOSITION: For Case Nos. 87, 88, 89 and 90. Order, insofar as appealed from, affirmed, with costs. For Case No. 91: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent businesses filed petitions against appellants the New York State Department of Economic Development and the Empire Zone Designation Board, for a declaration that amendments to the New York Empire Zones Program could not be applied retroactively. The trial courts found for the businesses. The Court of Appeals of New York affirmed the judgments. The State of New York appealed. One of the businesses cross-appealed.


OVERVIEW: The New York Legislature enacted New York State's Economic Development Zones Act (Program). Amendments to General Municipal Law § 959, L 2009, ch. 57, Part S-1, § 3, introduced two new criteria that businesses were required to meet to retain their certificates of eligibility for the Program. The Legislature also required the New York Commissioner of Economic Development to review all certified businesses to determine if they were to be decertified under the new criteria, General Municipal Law § 959(w). The businesses were certified under the Program and were issued certificates of eligibility. However, the certification of each of the businesses was revoked retroactively because of the amendments. The state high court found that the retroactive application of the amendments to the Program violated the right of the businesses to due process under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. Furthermore, 5 NYCRR 11.9(c), a regulation by the New York Department of Economic Development, did not conflict with the statutory directive in General Municipal Law § 959 to consider the total performance of an Empire Zone business.


OUTCOME: The judgments were affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Statutes -- Retroactive Application of Statute -- Tax Statute -- Due Process Clause 

1. In five actions and proceedings challenging the retroactive application of certain amendments to General Municipal Law § 959 (L 2009, ch 57, part S-1, § 3) that introduced two new criteria that businesses must meet to retain their certificates of eligibility for the Empire Zones Program and its state tax incentives, plaintiffs' constitutional challenges to the retroactive application were valid Due Process Clause challenges. While the Fifth Amendment's Takings Clause is but one of many constitutional provisions that express principles of antiretroactivity, plaintiffs' claims were not valid Takings Clause challenges, as characterized by the Appellate Division decisions. The test for whether a retroactive tax violates the Due Process Clause is different from the test for whether a retroactive tax is an unconstitutional taking. An aggrieved taxpayer may choose to make a claim that a retroactive tax violates the Due Process Clause under the multi-factor balancing-of-equities test set forth in Matter of Replan Dev. v Department of Hous. Preserv. & Dev. of City of N.Y. (70 NY2d 451, 456, 517 NE2d 200, 522 NYS2d 485 [1987]). The taxpayer additionally may choose to challenge the statute under the Takings Clause, but must prove that the tax amounted to flagrant abuse and the seizure of property, a more difficult task.

Statutes -- Retroactive Application of Statute -- Tax Statute -- Due Process Clause 

2. The retroactive application of certain amendments (the 2009 Amendments) to General Municipal Law § 959 (L 2009, ch 57, part S-1, § 3) that introduced two new criteria that businesses must meet to retain their certificates of eligibility for the Empire Zones Program and its state tax incentives violated the due process rights of plaintiffs, businesses which were certified under the Program and issued certificates of eligibility by the State prior to the retroactive application date of January 1, 2008. The three important factors in determining whether a retroactive tax infringes on a taxpayer's due process rights are the taxpayer's forewarning of a change in the legislation and the reasonableness of reliance on the old law, the length of the retroactive period, and the public purpose for retroactive application. The first factor weighed in favor of plaintiffs as they had no warning and no opportunity at any time in 2008 to alter their behavior in anticipation of the impact of the 2009 Amendments. In addition, the 2009 Amendments were not meant to cure an unintended error by the legislature, but rather to increase tax receipts for the state budget. Plaintiffs appeared to have conducted their business affairs in a manner consistent with existing Program requirements in 2008, justifiably relying on the receipt of the tax benefits that were then in effect. The second factor also benefitted plaintiffs since the length of retroactivity, regardless of whether the period of retroactivity was deemed to span 16 or 32 months, was excessive. Moreover, on the third factor, the State failed to set forth a valid public purpose for the retroactive application.

Taxation -- Exemptions -- Decertification of Empire Zone Business Enterprise -- Statutory Procedures 

3. Defendant Department of Economic Development's decertification of plaintiff, a commercial real estate company that had obtained certification as an Empire Zone business in 2000, because plaintiff failed the 1:1 benefit-cost test based upon a review of the business annual reports (BARs) plaintiff had filed for 2001-2007, was not arbitrary and capricious. Although plaintiff maintained that its benefit-cost ratio would have been greater than 4:1 if its year 2000 investments were included in the State's evaluation, defendant rationally decided to tally investments beginning in 2001, the first full year of the Empire Zones Program. General Municipal Law § 959 (w) states that defendant's decertification review would be based on at least three BARs that the business had prepared and filed with the Empire Zones Program. Defendant had promulgated regulations in 5 NYCRR 11.9 (c) (2) stating that it would review the BARs from the years 2001 to 2007. Defendant's regulation does not conflict with the statutory directive in General Municipal Law § 959 to consider an Empire Zone business's total performance. The statute did not require that defendant look at all available BARs in making a decertification decision under the 1:1 test.

 

46 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Matter of Bezio v. Dorsey


No. 65


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


21 N.Y.3d 93; 989 N.E.2d 942; 967 N.Y.S.2d 660; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 859; 2013 NY Slip Op 3118


March 19, 2013, Argued 
May 2, 2013, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent department brought a proceeding requesting an order allowing medical personnel to insert a tube and take other reasonable steps to provide hydration and nutrition to appellant inmate, who was refusing to eat. The trial court granted the department's application. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department, found that the case was moot but ruled in favor of the department on a single issue. The inmate appealed.


OVERVIEW: The inmate initiated a hunger strike in order to secure transfer to another facility, among other things. After the order was issued by the trial court, the inmate resumed eating solid food but pursued an appeal of the order. The intermediate appellate court found that the inmate's claim that the State did not have the right to secure a force-feeding order was not moot, and ruled in favor of the department on the merits. The appellate court held that the intermediate appellate court did not err in applying the mootness exception. When a policy or regulation impinged on a prisoner's constitutional rights, the action was valid if it was reasonably related to legitimate penological interests. The trial court's order withstood scrutiny. Among other things, a prisoner hunger strike could have had a significant destabilizing impact on the institution, and a suicide could have had an agitating effect on other prisoners. The department had a duty under the Eighth Amendment to safeguard the lives of individuals in its institutions. The department had attempted less intrusive means without success. The inmate's constitutional challenge was properly rejected.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Review

1. In a proceeding requesting a court order permitting medical personnel to insert a nasogastric tube and take other reasonable steps necessary to provide hydration and nutrition to respondent inmate, who was on a hunger strike, respondent's claim that the force-feeding order violated his constitutional right to refuse medical treatment was preserved for review. Although respondent did not reference the Due Process Clause or articulate his constitutional objections in the hearing court with the specificity and clarity that he did in the Appellate Division or in the Court of Appeals, that was a consequence of the fact that respondent addressed several arguments pro se, having been assigned counsel only shortly before the hearing, which was conducted expeditiously out of concern for preservation of his health. Respondent did argue that "putting a tube in my nose, that's cruel and unusual punishment," and it was evident that he viewed the insertion of a nasogastric feeding tube as an unconstitutional invasion of his bodily integrity.

Appeal -- Academic and Moot Questions

2. In an appeal from an order permitting medical personnel to insert a nasogastric tube and take other reasonable steps necessary to provide hydration and nutrition to respondent inmate, who was on a hunger strike, the Appellate Division did not err in applying the mootness exception to respondent's claim that the force-feeding order violated his constitutional right to refuse medical treatment. Although respondent resumed eating solid food after the order was issued, the issue of a hunger-striking inmate's constitutional right to refuse medical treatment fell within the exception to the mootness rule since it was novel, likely to recur and, given the exigencies involved in addressing a hunger strike, would typically evade review.

Prisons and Prisoners -- Medical and Surgical Treatment -- Court-Ordered Forced Feeding

3. In a proceeding in which petitioner, the superintendent of a correctional facility, sought a court order permitting medical personnel to insert a nasogastric tube and take other reasonable steps necessary to provide hydration and nutrition to respondent inmate, who was on a hunger strike, respondent's claim that the force-feeding order violated his constitutional right to refuse medical treatment was properly rejected. Petitioner had sought a forced-feeding order because respondent's conduct, according to his doctor, had created a substantial risk of imminent death or serious permanent injury. Even assuming the constitutional right respondent asserted existed, and that petitioner's intervention therefore resulted in the curtailment of such a right, the propriety of petitioner's action would be valid if it was reasonably related to legitimate penological interests. Factors to consider under such a standard include the extent to which the right asserted by the inmate is compatible with incarceration; whether the challenged prison action or policy is consistent with the institutional interests that are cited to justify it; whether other means are available to the inmate to exercise the right in question; whether accommodation of the inmate's asserted right will adversely impact the prison population, employees or the allocation of prison resources; and whether, viewed in a pragmatic light, it is feasible for prison authorities to address their institutional concerns through other means. Applying that test, the order permitting petitioner to intervene to prevent respondent's death by feeding via nasogastric tube, if necessary, withstood scrutiny. Taking action to interrupt an inmate hunger strike not only serves to preserve life and prevent a suicide but also to maintain institutional order and security. Petitioner could not effectuate those interests other than by seeking a judicial order permitting feeding by nasogastric tube--less intrusive means had been attempted without success.

 

47 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Matter of City of Yonkers v Yonkers Fire Fighters, Local 628, IAFF, AFL-CIO


No. 48


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


20 N.Y.3d 651; 988 N.E.2d 481; 965 N.Y.S.2d 746; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 580; 2013 NY Slip Op 2162; 195 L.R.R.M. 2503


February 13, 2013, Argued 
April 2, 2013, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner city sued respondent union, seeking a permanent stay of arbitration of a dispute relating to a collective bargaining agreement (CBA). The trial court dismissed the suit. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department, reversed, and granted the petition, holding that Civil Service Law § 201(4) and Retirement and Social Security Law § 470 barred the arbitration. The union appealed.


OVERVIEW: In the CBA, the city agreed to bear the cost of firefighters' pensions, pursuant to state law. The CBA ended in June 2009. The legislature enacted Retirement and Social Security Law art. 22, effective in 2010, which required new firefighters to contribute 3 percent of wages toward their pensions. The city then required firefighters who were hired after the CBA had ended to pay 3 percent of their wages towards their pensions. In response, the union filed an improper practice charge which led to the arbitration. Whether the arbitration was negotiation barred by § 201(4) and § 470 depended on whether the CBA was "in effect" under L 2009, ch. 504, pt. A, § 8 when art. 22 became effective. The appellate court held that the part of the CBA that required non-contributory plans was rendered unlawful by art. 22. L 2009, ch. 504, pt. A, § 8 made clear that the legislature did not intend to apply the exception to agreements that had expired and could only be deemed to continue through the Triborough Law, Civil Service Law § 209-a(1)(e). The L 2009, ch. 504, pt. A, § 8 exception did not apply to the CBA here. Thus, the arbitration was barred as an impermissible negotiation of benefits.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the intermediate appellate court was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Arbitration -- Matters Arbitrable -- Firefighters' Retirement Benefits 

Arbitration of respondent union's improper practice charge alleging that petitioner municipality erred in failing to apply the parties' collective bargaining agreement (CBA) and noncontributory pension benefits provision to firefighters hired after the CBA had expired was barred, as an impermissible negotiation of pension benefits, by Civil Service Law § 201 (4) and Retirement and Social Security Law § 470. The parties' CBA had expired on June 30, 2009, and, in the absence of a successor CBA, the Triborough doctrine applied and the CBA's terms continued, unless contradicted by statute. The part of the CBA that required noncontributory plans was rendered unlawful by the enactment of Retirement and Social Security Law article 22 (L 2009, ch 504, part A), effective in January 2010, which prohibits such plans. The exception to the prohibition against noncontributory plans for CBAs "in effect" on the effective date of article 22, as set forth in section 8 of part A of chapter 504 of the Laws of 2009, did not apply to the parties' CBA, which had expired prior to article 22's effective date and was only deemed to continue through the Triborough doctrine (see Civil Service Law § 209-a). The legislature, having set forth the section 8 exception for CBAs that are "in effect," expressly stated that eligibility to join a CBA's retirement plan "shall not apply upon termination of such agreement" (L 2009, ch 504, part A, § 8). That language and similar language in the Governor's Program Bill Memorandum in support of the legislation made clear that the legislature did not intend to apply the section 8 exception to CBAs that had expired and could only be deemed to continue through the Triborough doctrine.

 

48 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Overstock.com, Inc. v New York State Dept. of Taxation & Fin.


No. 33, No. 34


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


20 N.Y.3d 586; 987 N.E.2d 621; 965 N.Y.S.2d 61; 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 542; 2013 NY Slip Op 2102


February 6, 2013, Argued 
March 28, 2013, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Petition for certiorari filed at, 08/22/2013


DISPOSITION: For Each Case: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, on-line retailers, challenged Tax Law § 1101(b)(8)(vi) (the Internet tax), alleging that it was unconstitutional on its face under the Commerce Clause and Due Process Clause. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) declared the statute constitutional on its face. Plaintiffs appealed.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs argued that the Internet tax was unconstitutional on its face because it violated the Commerce Clause by subjecting online retailers, without a physical presence in the State, to New York sales and compensating use taxes. They also maintained that the Internet tax violated the Due Process Clause by creating an irrational, irrebuttable presumption of solicitation of business within the State. The appellate court held that the Internet tax was constitutional on its face, finding that the statute plainly satisfied the substantial nexus requirement. Active, in-state solicitation that produced a significant amount of revenue qualified as demonstrably more than a slightest presence. The bottom line was that if a vendor was paying New York residents to actively solicit business in the State, there was no reason why that vendor should not shoulder the appropriate tax burden. The appellate court would not strain to invalidate the statute where plaintiffs had not met their burden of establishing that it was facially invalid. The fact that plaintiffs could posit a potential constitutional infirmity did not require the statute's invalidation on its face.


OUTCOME: The judgment appealed from and the order of the Appellate Division brought up for review were affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Collection of Sales Tax by Out-of-State Internet Vendors -- Commerce Clause 

1. Tax Law § 1101 (b) (8) (vi) (the Internet tax), which subjects online vendors, without a physical presence in New York, to state sales and compensating use taxes if the vendors use in-state residents to solicit business in New York through the residents' websites, is facially valid under the Commerce Clause. The Internet tax is constitutional on its face under either standard for evaluating a facial challenge pursuant to the Commerce Clause--that there is "no set of circumstances" under which the statute would be valid, or the stricter test of whether the statute has a plainly legitimate sweep. The relevant inquiry is whether the tax is applied to an activity with a substantial nexus with the taxing state. Although an in-state physical presence is necessary, it need not be substantial, but demonstrably more than a slightest presence, and the presence requirement will be satisfied if economic activities are performed in New York by the seller's employees or on its behalf. The Internet tax statute satisfies the substantial nexus requirement, as active, in-state solicitation that produces a significant amount of revenue qualifies as demonstrably more than a slightest presence. Further, although not a dispositive factor, vendors are not required to pay the taxes out-of-pocket. Rather, they are collecting taxes that are due, which are exceedingly difficult to collect from the individual purchasers themselves, and as to which there is no risk of multiple taxation. The statutory language allows for a range of possible types of compensation, which would include flat fee arrangements, and although a substantial nexus would be lacking if New York residents were merely engaged to post passive advertisements on their websites, a vendor paying New York residents to actively solicit business in New York should shoulder the appropriate tax burden.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Collection of Sales Tax by Out-of-State Internet Vendors -- Due Process Clause 

2. Tax Law § 1101 (b) (8) (vi) (the Internet tax), which subjects online vendors, without a physical presence in New York, to state sales and compensating use taxes if the vendors use in-state residents to solicit business in New York through the residents' websites, is facially valid under the Due Process Clause. An in-state physical presence is not required in order to satisfy due process. Instead, the focus is on whether a party has purposefully directed its activities toward the forum state and whether it is reasonable, based on the extent of a party's contacts with that state and the benefits derived from such access, to require it to collect taxes for that state. The Internet tax statute says that a seller "shall be presumed to be soliciting business through an independent contractor or other representative" if it enters an agreement under which a New York resident, "for a commission or other consideration, directly or indirectly refers potential customers, whether by a link on an internet website or otherwise." The statutory presumption is not irrational or irrebuttable. It is rational to presume that, given the direct correlation between referrals and compensation, it is likely that residents will seek to increase their referrals by soliciting customers. More specifically, it is not unreasonable to presume that affiliated website owners residing in New York State will reach out to their New York friends, relatives and other local individuals in order to accomplish this purpose. Moreover, the agency charged with enforcing the statute has expressly acknowledged that mere advertising is beyond the scope of the provision, and it has set forth a method (contractual prohibition and annual certification) through which the retailers will be deemed to have rebutted the presumption.

 

49 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Morales


No. 186


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


20 N.Y.3d 240; 982 N.E.2d 580; 958 N.Y.S.2d 660; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 3596; 2012 NY Slip Op 8439


October 9, 2012, Argued 
December 11, 2012, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Decision reached on appeal by People v. Morales, 2016 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 1904 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, Mar. 17, 2016)


DISPOSITION: On the People's appeal, order affirmed. On the defendant's appeal, order reversed and a new trial ordered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People and defendant appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) that, among other things, reduced defendant's convictions for terrorism under Penal Law § 490.25 to first-degree manslaughter, attempted second-degree murder, and second-degree weapon possession.


OVERVIEW: During a fight between defendant and his gang members and a rival gang member and his companions, defendant fired five bullets from a handgun. Three shots hit one of the rivals and paralyzed him. A 10-year-old girl was shot in the head and died. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that the evidence at trial failed to demonstrate that defendant and his fellow gang members committed the acts against the rival gang member and his companions with the conscious objective of intimidating every Mexican-American in the territory identified at trial. The Legislature did not intend for the crime of terrorism to cover the illegal acts of a gang member committed for the purpose of coercing or intimidating adversaries. Accordingly, the evidence was insufficient to establish defendant's guilt under § 490.25. Consequently, without the aura of terrorism looming over the case, the volume of proof regarding unrelated assaults, murders, and other offenses created a reasonable possibility that the jury's findings were prejudicially influenced. Therefore, the spillover effect required reversal of, and a new trial on, the underlying offenses.


OUTCOME: On the People's appeal, the order was affirmed; on defendant's appeal, the order was reversed, and a new trial was ordered.



HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Terrorism -- Intent to Intimidate or Coerce Civilian Population 

1. In the prosecution of defendant gang member for crimes of terrorism predicated upon his alleged commission of manslaughter in the first degree and other crimes during a gang-related fight in which a rival gang member and a young girl were shot, the acts perpetrated by defendant did not demonstrate an "intent to intimidate or coerce a civilian population" within the meaning of Penal Law § 490.25 (1) on the theory that there was an objective to intimidate or coerce the entire Mexican-American community. Even assuming that all of the Mexican-Americans in the area of the Bronx where the gang operated could be considered a "civilian population," the evidence at trial failed to demonstrate that defendant and his fellow gang members committed the criminal acts with the conscious objective of intimidating everyone in that population. Instead, the evidence demonstrated that the gang members arranged the attack because of a man's assumed membership in a rival gang and his refusal to comply with the gang's demand that he leave a party.

Crimes -- Terrorism -- Intent to Intimidate or Coerce Civilian Population 

2. In the prosecution of defendant gang member for crimes of terrorism predicated upon his alleged commission of manslaughter in the first degree and other crimes during a gang-related fight in which a rival gang member and a young girl were shot, the acts perpetrated by defendant were not acts of terrorism within the meaning of Penal Law article 490 and therefore the evidence was insufficient to establish defendant's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. While the jury could have concluded that one of defendant's goals in committing the crimes was to intimidate or coerce another gang, the legislative findings in Penal Law article 490 clearly demonstrate that the legislature was not extending the reach of the terrorism statute to cover gang-on-gang street crimes. Penal Law § 490.00 cites seven notorious acts of terrorism, including the September 11, 2001 attacks, that serve as guideposts for determining whether a future incident constitutes a terroristic act. In addition, the definitional provisions of article 490 were drawn from federal antiterrorism statutes designed to criminalize acts such as detonation of bombs in cities or deliberate assassinations of persons to strike fear and deter individuals from exercising their rights. The concept of terrorism has a unique meaning and its implications risk being trivialized if the terminology is applied loosely in situations that do not match the collective understanding of what constitutes a terrorist act.

Crimes -- Trial -- Effect of Error as to Certain Counts on Other Jointly Tried Counts 

3. In a prosecution where defendant's convictions for crimes of terrorism predicated on first-degree manslaughter, attempted second-degree murder and second-degree weapon possession and for second-degree conspiracy for agreeing to commit first-degree gang assault as a crime of terrorism were based on insufficient evidence, defendant was entitled to a new trial on the underlying offenses specified in the terrorism counts. An error in the proceedings relating to one count requires reversal of convictions on other jointly tried counts if there is a reasonable possibility that the jury's decision to convict on the tainted counts influenced its guilty verdict on the remaining counts in a meaningful way. By proceeding on the terrorism theory, the People were able to introduce evidence about numerous alleged criminal acts committed by members of defendant's gang over the course of three years, which evidence would have otherwise been largely inadmissible. Thus, there was a reasonable possibility that the jury's findings were prejudicially influenced.

 

50 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v Meckwood


No. 182


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


20 N.Y.3d 69; 980 N.E.2d 501; 956 N.Y.S.2d 453; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 3094; 2012 NY Slip Op 7147


September 13, 2012, Argued 
October 25, 2012, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) that affirmed his adjudication as a second violent felony offender, based upon a 1999 Pennsylvania conviction; defendant claimed, among other things, that, because he could have been accorded youthful offender status had he committed that crime in New York, he was entitled to such status for the purpose of enhanced sentencing.


OVERVIEW: Defendant also argued that Penal Law § 70.04(1)(b)(v), the provision that tolled the 10-year look-back period while a person was incarcerated, violated the equal protection laws of the New York State Constitution. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that at the time of the 1999 conviction, defendant, then 18 years old, was not entitled to youthful offender status pursuant to Pennsylvania laws. Therefore, as defendant did not receive youthful offender treatment for the underlying offense, he was not now entitled to a retroactive application of youthful offender status to the foreign felony conviction. Accordingly, the trial court properly assigned the same status to the underlying conviction as did the foreign jurisdiction in which the conviction had been entered. It was not irrational for the Legislature, in § 70.04(1)(b)(iv), to omit periods of incarceration from the 10-year look-back period, in order to assess whether a prior violent felon has abstained from a repeat offense within a 10-year period. Therefore, the statute did not violate defendant's equal protection rights.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second Violent Felony Offender -- Lack of Youthful Offender Status for Predicate Foreign Conviction

1. Defendant was properly adjudicated as a second violent felony offender, predicated upon a prior foreign burglary conviction that occurred when he was 18 years old, notwithstanding that had he committed the crime in New York, he would have been eligible for consideration as a youthful offender, and, if so adjudicated, it could not have been used as a predicate conviction. A prior adjudication as a youthful offender--whether it occurred in New York or another jurisdiction--cannot serve as the basis for multiple offender sentencing provided the foreign youthful offender adjudication is similar to and consistent with New York's youthful offender treatment. However, youthful offender status cannot be retroactively assigned to underlying convictions of foreign jurisdictions even though, had the crimes been committed in New York, such consideration could have been granted. Mere speculation that defendant might have been accorded youthful offender treatment had the predicate offense been committed in New York cannot preclude the use of such a conviction as a predicate felony where such treatment was not and could not have been accorded by the jurisdiction in which the crime was actually committed. Accordingly, the sentencing court properly assigned the same status to the underlying conviction as did the foreign jurisdiction in which the conviction had been entered.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Second Violent Felony Offender -- Tolling Provision -- Exclusion of Period of Incarceration Not Denial of Equal Protection

2. Penal Law § 70.04 (1) (b) (v), which excludes all periods of incarceration from the 10-year enhanced sentencing look-back period between sentencing for the prior felony and commission of the present felony, does not violate the Equal Protection Clause on the ground that repeat offenders with lengthy sentences may receive harsher punishments than repeat offenders with lesser sentences or no periods of incarceration. While the tolling provision, as applied to persons with differing years of incarceration, may result in disparate punishment, there is no equal protection violation under the New York State Constitution, which does not mandate absolute equality of treatment but merely prescribes that, absent a fundamental interest or suspect classification, a legislative classification be rationally related to a legitimate state purpose. Given the absence of a suspect class or a fundamental right at issue, the statutory provision need only be supported by some rational basis to survive constitutional scrutiny. Inasmuch as recidivism evidences a lack of rehabilitation and a greater danger to society, it was not irrational for the Legislature to omit periods of incarceration from the 10-year look-back period. Rather, it was rational to omit periods of incarceration from the look-back period because society has an interest in treating differently individuals who demonstrate good behavior during the time in which they are released and living in society from those who cannot.

 

51 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Matter of 677 New Loudon Corp. v. State of N.Y. Tax Appeals Trib.


No. 157


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


19 N.Y.3d 1058; 979 N.E.2d 1121; 955 N.Y.S.2d 795; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 2736; 2012 NY Slip Op 7046


September 5, 2012, Argued 
October 23, 2012, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Reargument denied by Matter of 677 New Loudon Corp. v. State of New York Tax Appeals Trib., 20 N.Y.3d 1024, 983 N.E.2d 1244, 2013 N.Y. LEXIS 162, 960 N.Y.S.2d 60 (2013)
US Supreme Court certiorari denied by 677 New Loudon Corp. v. N.Y. Tax Appeals Tribunal, 2013 U.S. LEXIS 7373 (U.S., Oct. 15, 2013)


DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer appealed a judgment by the Appellate Division (New York) that upheld a determination by respondent state Tax Appeals Tribunal finding that it did not qualify for the tax exemption in Tax Law § 1105(f)(1) on the admission charges and private dance performance fees that it charged its patrons.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer claimed that the Legislature intended to give the adult entertainment business a tax break because the exotic stage and couch dances that were featured at the premises qualified as musical arts performances, rather than as more generalized amusement or entertainment activities that fell within the broad sweep of the tax. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that the taxpayer's expert testimony was compromised by her opinion that the private performances were the same as the main stage performances despite the fact that she neither observed nor had personal knowledge of what occurred in the private areas. It was not irrational for the Tax Appeals Tribunal to conclude that performances by women gyrating on a pole to music, however artistic or athletic their practiced moves were, was not a qualifying performance entitled to exempt status. Consequently, the charges and fees failed to qualify for the exemption in, and were taxable under, § 1105(f)(1). The taxpayer's remaining constitutional argument was unavailing.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Exemption for Admission Tickets to Dramatic or Musical Arts Performances Not Applicable to Establishments Featuring Exotic Dancers

The operator of an adult "juice bar" failed to meet its burden of proof that a sales tax exemption applied to admission charges and private dance performance fees it collected from patrons. The sales tax is broadly applied to "[a]ny admission charge" in excess of 10% for use of "any place of amusement," with an exception for charges pertaining to "dramatic or musical arts performances" (Tax Law § 1105 [f] [1]), and in order for petitioner to be entitled to the exclusion it was required to prove that the fees constituted admission charges for performances that were dance routines qualifying as choreographed performances. Petitioner failed to meet this burden as it related to the fees collected for "private room" performances as none of the evidence presented depicted such performances, and petitioner's expert's opinion was not based on any personal knowledge or observation of those performances. Furthermore, it was not arbitrary, capricious or an error of law for respondent Tax Appeals Tribunal to find that petitioner had failed to meet the same burden as it pertained to the admission charges for stage performances since respondent discredited the petitioner's expert's opinion that the routines qualified as choreographed performances, a determination well within respondent's province. It is not irrational for the Tax Tribunal to decline to extend a tax exemption to every act that declares itself a "dance performance."

 

52 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Hudson Val. Fed. Credit Union v. New York State Dept. of Taxation & Fin.


No. 154


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


20 N.Y.3d 1; 980 N.E.2d 473; 956 N.Y.S.2d 425; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 2719; 2012 NY Slip Op 6986


September 4, 2012, Argued 
October 18, 2012, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to defendants, by declaring that federal credit unions are not exempt from the New York State mortgage recording tax and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant federal credit union (FCU) appealed a judgment entered by the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, New York, which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the FCU's action against defendants, the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, its Commissioner, and the State of New York (defendants), which sought a declaration that the FCU was exempted from the mortgage recording tax (MRT) imposed by Tax Law § 253.


OVERVIEW: The state's highest court held that if federal credit union mortgages were intended to be excluded from MRTs, such immunity would have been stated in the Federal Credit Union Act, specifically 12 U.S.C.S. § 1768. "Property" in § 1768 could not be construed broadly to encompass mortgage loans. Congress could not have intended § 1768 to exempt the mortgage loans since when the provision was enacted, credit unions could not issue such loans. When Congress granted FCUs the power to offer residential mortgages, it did not amend § 1768 to include mortgages, or articulate an intent to include mortgages in the property exempt from state taxation. There was little danger that the MRT would drive FCUs out of business. The claim that the FCU was a federal instrumentality entitled to exemption from the MRT under the Supremacy Clause, U.S. Const. art. VI, cl. 2, was rejected. FCUs were private associations chartered under federal law. They were wholly owned, funded and managed by their members, and were not so closely connected to the federal government that they could not be viewed as separate entities with respect to mortgage-lending activities.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the appellate court was modified by declaring that federal credit unions were not exempt from the New York State mortgage recording tax. As so modified, the judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Mortgage Recording Tax -- Applicability to Mortgage Loans Issued by Federal Credit Unions

1. Federal credit unions are not exempt from the New York State mortgage recording tax under Tax Law article 11. The Federal Credit Union Act (FCUA), authorizing the formation of federal credit unions, contains an extensive list of tax exemptions for federal credit unions such as plaintiff (see 12 USC § 1768), but makes no mention of mortgages or loans of any kind. Federal tax exemptions in derogation of state taxing authority are, as a general rule, strictly construed and not extended beyond their express provisions. Although section 1768 does provide that the "property" of federal credit unions is exempt, that term does not encompass mortgage loans. Federal credit unions were not empowered to issue mortgage loans to their members when the FCUA was enacted and subsequently amended so as to add the exemption provisions at issue, and therefore Congress could not have intended section 1768 to exempt from state taxation the issuance of mortgage loans. When Congress finally granted federal credit unions the power to offer residential mortgages, it did not amend section 1768 to specifically include "mortgages," nor did it otherwise articulate an intent to include mortgages within the definition of the "property" exempt from state taxation. Moreover, permitting the mortgage recording tax to apply to federal credit unions does not thwart the FCUA's purpose and would not have serious financial ramifications for federal credit unions.

Taxation -- Mortgage Recording Tax -- Applicability to Mortgage Loans Issued by Federal Credit Unions -- Supremacy Clause 

2. Plaintiff federal credit union was not a federal instrumentality entitled to exemption from the New York State mortgage recording tax under the Supremacy Clause. Constitutional tax immunity is appropriate only when the levy falls on the United States itself, or on an agency or instrumentality so closely connected to the United States Government that the two cannot realistically be viewed as separate entities, at least insofar as the activity being taxed is concerned. Federal credit unions are private associations chartered under federal law, and although they are regulated by a federal agency, they are wholly owned, funded and managed by their members. Members elect credit union boards of directors, and those directors have a significant amount of autonomy in administering credit unions' daily operations. Accordingly, federal credit unions are not so closely connected to the United States Government that they cannot realistically be viewed as separate entities with respect to mortgage-lending activities.

 

53 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Town of Oyster Bay v Kirkland


No. 163


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


19 N.Y.3d 1035; 978 N.E.2d 1237; 954 N.Y.S.2d 769; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 2725; 2012 NY Slip Op 6988


September 6, 2012, Argued 
October 18, 2012, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: US Supreme Court certiorari denied by Town of Oyster Bay v Kirkland, 2013 U.S. LEXIS 1938 (U.S., Mar. 4, 2013)


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant town appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) that modified the trial court denial of its motion for injunctive relief by, among other things, declaring that respondent State Division of Human Rights (SDHR) acted within its authority in initiating an administrative complaint against the town under Executive Law art. 15; the town claimed that SDHR engaged in reverse discrimination.


OVERVIEW: After the town created zoning districts for below-market-rate private housing for senior citizens and first-time home-buyers, SDHR filed an administrative complaint alleging that the town's actions denied housing to persons based on their race, color, and national origin, in violation of art. 15. Without waiting for the completion of SDHR's investigation, the town commenced the underlying action. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that SDHR's allegation that the town's residency preferences amounted to discrimination and the town's claim that it would be "reverse discrimination" to eliminate the residency preferences required the resolution of factual issues at the administrative level before they could be passed upon by a court. After such factual review, an administrative law judge could provide the relief ultimately sought by the town by finding that the preferences did not amount to discrimination and dismissing the complaint. This was not a case in which it would be futile to seek relief in the first instance through the administrative process. Therefore, the town should have initially addressed its constitutional claim, along with its defenses, to SDHR.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies -- Municipality's Challenge to State Division of Human Rights Claim of Racial Discrimination

Plaintiff Town's claim that a State Division of Human Rights' complaint, alleging that the Town violated the Human Rights Law (Executive Law art 15) in establishing two zoning districts with residency preferences, constituted unconstitutional "reverse discrimination," and the Division's allegation that the residency preferences amounted to discrimination, required the resolution of factual issues at the administrative level before they could be passed upon by a court. In particular, a factual record of the adverse impact of the municipality's preferences on home buyers from minority communities, and the impact that removing the preferences would have, had yet to be developed. After such factual review, an administrative law judge could provide the relief ultimately sought by the Town by finding that the preferences did not amount to discrimination and dismissing the complaint; this was not a case in which it would be futile to seek relief in the first instance through the administrative process. Therefore, the Town should initially address its claim of unconstitutional "reverse discrimination," along with its defenses, to the Division.

 

54 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Hussein v State of New York


No. 69


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


19 N.Y.3d 899; 973 N.E.2d 752; 950 N.Y.S.2d 342; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 1788; 2012 NY Slip Op 5092


April 26, 2012, Argued 
June 26, 2012, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Dismissed by Maisto v. State of New York, 56 Misc. 3d 295, 51 N.Y.S.3d 800, 2016 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 5011 (Sept. 19, 2016)


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs, and certified question answered in the negative, in a memorandum.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Academic and Moot Questions -- Challenge to School Funding System

In an action alleging that children in certain school districts were being deprived of the opportunity of a sound basic education, an order of the Appellate Division, which affirmed an order denying defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint, was affirmed since plaintiffs' claims were neither moot nor unripe for review.

 

55 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Matter of Smith v. Tormey


No. 100


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


19 N.Y.3d 533; 975 N.E.2d 470; 951 N.Y.S.2d 89; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 1349; 2012 NY Slip Op 4664


April 26, 2012, Argued 
June 12, 2012, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorney brought a CPLR art. 78 proceeding seeking to annul a determination of respondent administrative judge and seeking a judgment that he be paid for legal services rendered in accordance with a county court's order. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, granted the petition in part, holding that the judge exceeded the authority conferred by 22 NYCRR 127.2 (b). The administrative judge appealed.


OVERVIEW: The attorney sought payment for legal work done on a homicide case. The county court granted the attorney's motion, concluding that the extraordinary circumstances of the criminal matter justified, and in fact, necessitated, the assignment of a "second chair" to assure that defendant received effective assistance of counsel. Pursuant to 22 NYCRR 127.2 (b), the county made an application to the administrative judge seeking review of the county court's order directing that the attorney be awarded legal fees. The administrative judge found that it was beyond the purview of county court, in contravention of County Law § 722-b, to appoint the attorney as he never timely applied to be appointed for the assigned counsel program nor was he qualified to be appointed as a second-seated counsel in this matter. The appellate court found that the administrative judge exceeded the authority conferred by 22 NYCRR 127.2 (b) by considering the order of assignment. 22 NYCRR 127.2 (b), which was notably silent on the issue of assignment, only empowered administrative judges to assess the amount of compensation awarded, permitting a reduction of awards deemed excessive.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Attorney and Client -- Assignment of Counsel -- Administrative Judge Not Authorized to Review Validity of Assignment

Respondent Administrative Judge exceeded the authority conferred upon him by 22 NYCRR 127.2 (b) by considering the validity of the County Court order that retroactively assigned petitioner attorney, under County Law article 18-B, to a criminal proceeding, and vacating the order of assignment. Any objection to County Court's determination should have been raised through a CPLR article 78 proceeding seeking a writ of prohibition. Section 127.2 (b), which is notably silent on the issue of assignment, only empowers administrative judges to assess the amount of compensation awarded, permitting a reduction of awards deemed excessive. Certain distinctions between the nature of assigning and compensating counsel warrant different avenues of review. Appellate review of compensation orders is impractical as appellate courts are too removed to assess the propriety of the trial court's discretionary decision-making in fixing compensation. Recognition of such impracticability led to the amendment of section 127.2 (b) so as to provide for review of compensation orders by an administrative judge. An allegation concerning a trial court's overreach, however, raises judicial or quasi-judicial issues amenable to judicial review under CPLR 7803 (2), which is suited for instances where "the body or officer proceeded, is proceeding or is about to proceed without or in excess of jurisdiction."

 

56 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Cohen v. Cuomo


No. 135


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


19 N.Y.3d 196; 969 N.E.2d 754; 946 N.Y.S.2d 536; 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 937; 2012 NY Slip Op 3471


April 26, 2012, Argued 
May 3, 2012, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Motion dismissed by Cohen v Cuomo, 19 NY3d 856, 969 NE2d 779, 2012 N.Y. LEXIS 1216, 946 NYS2d 561 (N.Y., May 31, 2012)
