Penal Law § 70.85 specifies that in cases where PRS was required but not explicitly pronounced at sentencing, the matter may be returned for resentencing pursuant to Correction Law § 601-d, and the court may decide to reimpose the original determinate sentence without PRS "only on consent of the district attorney." Hence, a court may decline to impose PRS during resentencing only when the People issue the statutorily required consent under Penal Law § 70.85.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Resentence -- Timeliness

3. CPL 380.30, which requires that sentences must be imposed "without unreasonable delay," did not cause sentencing courts seeking to correct illegal sentences that had failed to include a mandatory period of postrelease supervision to lose their jurisdiction over defendants who had completed their terms of imprisonment and were released from prison. Even assuming the statute applied, it was not violated because defendants were resentenced within a reasonable time after the Department of Correctional Services notified the courts that defendants were "designated persons" who qualified for resentencing under Correction Law § 601-d.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Resentence -- Postrelease Supervision -- Double Jeopardy 

4. The Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment barred the imposition of postrelease supervision at the resentencing of defendants, who had completed serving their sentences of imprisonment and had been released from prison but whose original sentences failed to include a mandatory term of postrelease supervision. After defendants were released from prison, a legitimate expectation in the finality of a sentence arose and the Double Jeopardy Clause prevented reformation to attach a postrelease supervision component to the original completed sentence. So long as an illegal sentence is subject to correction, a defendant cannot claim a legitimate expectation that the originally imposed improper sentence is final for all purposes. However, there must be a temporal limitation on a court's ability to resentence a defendant. Accordingly, once a defendant was released from custody and returned to the community after serving the period of incarceration that was ordered by the sentencing court, and the time to appeal the sentence had expired or the appeal had been finally determined, there was a legitimate expectation that the sentence, although illegal under the Penal Law, was final and the Double Jeopardy Clause prevented a court from modifying the sentence to include a period of postrelease supervision. This expectation was not altered by the fact that some defendants were released from prison after serving less than the entire term of their determinate sentences or that some defendants signed documents pertaining to postrelease supervision before their release.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Preservation of Issue for Review -- Resentencing 

5. The resentencing of defendant, who had completed serving his sentence of imprisonment and had been released from prison but whose original sentences failed to include a mandatory term of postrelease supervision (PRS), was reviewable despite his failure to raise any objections to the inclusion of a PRS term at the resentencing. Since the Double Jeopardy Clause of the Fifth Amendment protected defendant from being resentenced to a more severe punishment after serving his sentence of imprisonment and being released into the community, the resentencing court did not retain jurisdiction to modify the original judgment that was entered. Because defendant's double jeopardy claim implicated a fundamental mode of proceedings, it was reviewable absent preservation.

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Prohibition -- When Remedy Available--Resentencing of Criminal Defendant

6. A CPLR article 78 proceeding seeking to prohibit the resentencing of defendant in order to correct an illegal sentence by adding a period of postrelease supervision (PRS) was dismissed since the record did not indicate that the resentencing judge had considered whether it was appropriate to impose a term of PRS. The court's order scheduled the matter "for consideration of whether the inmate should be re-sentenced, and that the Clerk arrange for counsel for both parties to appear" on a specific date. Accordingly, there was no need to seek prohibition relief before the court determined the lawfulness of the sentence that was imposed or whether it would accept the served sentence without a term of PRS.

 

82 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Matter of Maron v Silver


No. 16, No. 17, No. 18


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


14 N.Y.3d 230; 925 N.E.2d 899; 899 N.Y.S.2d 97; 2010 N.Y. LEXIS 39; 2010 NY Slip Op 1528


January 12, 2010, Argued 
February 23, 2010, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Reargument dismissed by Larabee v. Governor of N.Y., 16 N.Y.3d 736, 942 N.E.2d 311, 2011 N.Y. LEXIS 71, 917 N.Y.S.2d 101 (2011)
Motion denied by Larabee v. Governor of the State of N.Y., 37 Misc. 3d 748, 950 N.Y.S.2d 892, 2012 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4406 (2012)
Subsequent appeal at, Decision reached on appeal by Larabee v. Governor of the State of N.Y., 2014 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 5169 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, July 10, 2014)


DISPOSITION: Case No. 16: Order modified, without costs, by remitting to Supreme Court, Albany County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein. Case No. 17: Order modified, without costs, by granting judgment declaring that, under the circumstances of this case, as a matter of law, the State defendants' failure to consider judicial compensation on the merits violates the separation of powers doctrine, and by allowing for the remedy discussed in the opinion herein, and, as so modified, affirmed. Case No. 18: On plaintiffs' appeal and defendants' cross appeal, judgment of Supreme Court and order of the Appellate Division modified, without costs, by granting judgment declaring that, under the circumstances of this case, as a matter of law, the State defendants' failure to consider judicial compensation on the merits violates the separation of powers doctrine, and by allowing for the remedy discussed in the opinion herein, and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner judges and defendants, governor and legislators (the State defendants) appealed three orders by the Appellate Division (New York) that affirmed the trial courts' grant of summary judgment in favor of the judges on their separation of powers claim and dismissal of the causes of action attacking the constitutionality of Judiciary Law §§ 221 through 221-i.


OVERVIEW: Beginning in 2006, the judiciary and the state senate unsuccessfully sought salary adjustments for the state's judges. Although the parties were in accord regarding the need to adjust judicial compensation, the Legislature and the Executive failed to come to an agreement on legislation effecting a judicial pay increase. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that because of the constitutional requirement in N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 25(a) that judicial compensation be "established by law," mandamus did not lie. The judges' equal protection cause of action was also properly dismissed. The Legislature's failure to address the effects of inflation did not equate to a per se violation of the Compensation Clause, § 25(a). However, the State defendants' failure to consider judicial compensation on the merits violated the Separation of Powers Doctrine in N.Y. Const. arts. III, IV, VI. Judicial compensation, when addressed by the Legislature in present and future budget deliberations, could not depend on unrelated policy initiatives or legislative compensation adjustments.


OUTCOME: The first order was modified by remitting the matter for further proceedings, the second and third orders were modified, inter alia, by declaring that the State defendants' failure to consider judicial compensation on the merits violated the separation of powers doctrine, and, as so modified, those orders were affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Judges -- Disqualification -- Rule of Necessity

1. The Court of Appeals was required, pursuant to the Rule of Necessity, to hear and dispose of the constitutional issues raised in a hybrid CPLR article 78 proceeding/declaratory judgment action and two related declaratory judgment actions challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998. Although members of the Court of Appeals are paid via the salary schedule delineated in Judiciary Law § 221 and therefore will be affected by the outcome of the appeals, no other judicial body with jurisdiction exists to hear the constitutional issues raised therein.

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Mandamus -- Disbursement of State Funds Appropriated for Judicial Pay Raises

2. In a hybrid CPLR article 78 proceeding/declaratory judgment action challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, mandamus did not lie to compel respondent State Comptroller to disburse all retroactive sums and pay the budgeted raises allocated in the 2006-2007 state budget for judicial salary reform. Chapter 51 of the Laws of 2006, addressing "JUDICIAL COMPENSATION REFORM," contained a $ 69.5 million budget item to adjust judicial compensation "pursuant to a chapter of the laws of 2006." No subsequent chapter law, however, was enacted either amending the Judiciary Law salary schedules or directing the disbursement of the funds. Because judicial compensation was constitutionally required to be "established by law" (NY Const, art VI, § 25 [a]) and no subsequent chapter law was ever enacted, mandamus did not lie.

Judges -- Judicial Salaries - Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation -- Equal Protection

3. In a hybrid CPLR article 78 proceeding/declaratory judgment action challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, Supreme Court properly dismissed petitioners' cause of action alleging that the Judiciary constituted a "suspect class" that had been denied equal protection under the law because judicial pay raises have been historically contingent on or "tied to" salary increases for legislators.

Judges -- Judicial Salaries -- Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation -- Compensation Clause -- Failure to Address Effects of Inflation Not Per Se Violation

4. In a hybrid CPLR article 78 proceeding/declaratory judgment action and related declaratory judgment action challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, the failure to address the effects of inflation did not equate to a per se violation of the Compensation Clause (NY Const, art VI, § 25 [a]). Although the Compensation Clause plainly prohibits the diminution of judicial compensation by legislative act during a judge's term of office, there was no evidence in the history of the Clause's enactment or subsequent amendments that supported a broad interpretation embracing indirect diminishment by neglect, and therefore no evidence that the "no diminishment" rule was intended to affirmatively require that judicial salaries be adjusted to keep pace with the cost of living. The diminution in value of judicial compensation by inflation was a concern when the clause was enacted and amended, but the drafters decided that the best way to combat the effects of inflation was to count on the Legislature to assure the fair and appropriate compensation of the Judiciary.

Judges -- Judicial Salaries -- Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation -- Compensation Clause -- No Discrimination against Judiciary in Violation of Compensation Clause

5. In a declaratory judgment action challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, Supreme Court properly dismissed plaintiffs' cause of action alleging that defendants discriminated against the Judiciary in violation of the Compensation Clause (NY Const, art VI, § 25 [a]) by freezing judicial salaries while repeatedly increasing the salaries of almost all of the remaining state employees to keep pace with the cost of living. Relief was not warranted under United States v Hatter (532 US 557, 121 S Ct 1782, 149 L Ed 2d 820 [2001]), which involved a Social Security tax law that discriminated against federal judges by reducing the compensation of judges only. The situation here did not involve any legislative enactment that directly or indirectly diminished judicial compensation. Moreover, although other state employees had received adjustments to account for inflation, judges were not the only state employees whose salaries have not been adjusted since judicial salaries were last increased.

Legislature -- Immunity from Prosecution -- Immunity under Speech or Debate Clause Not Available in Action Challenging Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation

6. In a hybrid CPLR article 78 proceeding/declaratory judgment action and two related declaratory judgment actions challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, the Assembly, Senate and the State were not immune under the Speech or Debate Clause from plaintiffs' violation of separation of powers claims. The Speech or Debate Clause protects against inquiry into acts that occur in the regular course of the legislative process and into the motivation for those acts, and applies to only "members" and to "any speech or debate in either house" (NY Const, art III, § 11). Such immunity does not apply to either house of the Legislature as a whole. Moreover, no inquiry into acts that occurred in the regular course of the legislative process or the Legislature's motives for such acts was necessary here, as all of the parties acknowledged that the Judiciary was entitled to an increase in compensation, and the State defendants had made proclamations outside of the legislative and executive chambers as to why such an increase had not occurred.

Judges -- Judicial Salaries -- Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation -- Separation of Powers Doctrine

7. In a hybrid CPLR article 78 proceeding/declaratory judgment action challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, petitioners sufficiently stated a cause of action for violation of the Separation of Powers Doctrine. Petitioners alleged that by tying judicial compensation to unrelated legislative objectives and policy initiatives, as opposed to conducting an independent assessment of judicial compensation, the Legislature had disregarded the separation of powers doctrine and threatened the independence of the Judiciary. The compensation provisions in the State Constitution for each branch of government are separately addressed in the article for each respective branch, and not in the article where the powers of the legislative branch are articulated. Although a function of the Legislature is to approve the compensation of each of the three branches, the compensation to be paid to members of each particular branch must be determined separately and distinctly from the others. Whether the Judiciary is entitled to a compensation increase must be based upon an objective assessment of the Judiciary's needs if it is to retain its functional and structural independence. By failing to consider judicial compensation increases on the merits, and instead holding them hostage to other legislative objectives, the Legislature weakens the Judiciary by making it unduly dependent on the Legislature.

Judges -- Judicial Salaries -- Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation -- Separation of Powers Doctrine

8. In two related declaratory judgment actions challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, plaintiffs were entitled to a declaration that, as a matter of law, the State defendants' failure to consider judicial compensation on the merits violated the Separation of Powers Doctrine. The compensation provisions in the State Constitution for each branch of government are separately addressed in the article for each respective branch, and not in the article where the powers of the legislative branch are articulated. Although a function of the Legislature is to approve the compensation of each of the three branches, the compensation to be paid to members of each particular branch must be determined separately and distinctly from the others. Whether the Judiciary is entitled to a compensation increase must be based upon an objective assessment of the Judiciary's needs if it is to retain its functional and structural independence. By failing to consider judicial compensation increases on the merits, and instead holding them hostage to other legislative objectives, the Legislature weakened the Judiciary by making it unduly dependent on the Legislature.

Judges -- Judicial Salaries -- Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation -- Separation of Powers Doctrine - Remedy for Violation of Separation of Powers Doctrine

9. In two related declaratory judgment actions challenging the failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998 resulting in a declaration that, as a matter of law, the State defendants' failure to consider judicial compensation on the merits violated the Separation of Powers Doctrine, it was not necessary to order specific injunctive relief. Deference to the Legislature regarding whether judicial compensation should be adjusted, and by how much, was necessary because it is in a far better position than the Judiciary to determine funding needs throughout the State and priorities for the allocation of the State's resources. Appropriate and expeditious legislative consideration of judicial compensation is, however, expected, and when addressed in present and future budget deliberations it cannot depend on unrelated policy initiatives or legislative compensation adjustments.

Judges -- Judicial Salaries -- Legislature's Failure to Increase Judicial Compensation -- Separation of Powers Doctrine -- Constitutional Inadequacy of Compensation  

10. The Legislature has a constitutional duty and obligation to provide the Judiciary with compensation adequate in amount and commensurate with the duties and responsibilities of the judges involved. Moreover, adequate judicial compensation is necessary to ensure that the public will have its matters heard by competent judges and that judges will be free to issue decisions in accordance with the law without fear of retribution by the other two branches of government. The Compensation Clause's language that compensation "shall not be diminished" (NY Const, art VI, § 25 [a]) is not the opposite of an "adequate compensation" guarantee. The argument that the current salaries are inadequate when compared to other legal positions in the public and private sectors, as raised by plaintiffs in a declaratory judgment action challenging the Legislature's failure to adjust judicial compensation since 1998, is, however, one that is best addressed in the first instance by the Legislature.

 

83 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v Pierce


No. 27


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


14 N.Y.3d 564; 930 N.E.2d 176; 904 N.Y.S.2d 255; 2010 N.Y. LEXIS 23; 2010 NY Slip Op 1347


January 14, 2010, Argued 
February 16, 2010, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order reversed, defendant's guilty plea vacated, superior court information dismissed and case remitted to Supreme Court, Erie County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant waived indictment and pled guilty to a superior court information (SCI) charging him with fourth degree grand larceny, an offense for which he had been held for action by a grand jury in a superior court felony complaint, and third degree criminal possession of stolen property. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, affirmed the conviction. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: The People filed a superior court felony complaint charging defendant with the same fourth-degree grand larceny offense for which he had been held for action of the grand jury. Defendant waived indictment and agreed to be prosecuted by SCI for the larceny offense and a third-degree stolen property charge. The People argued that joinder was proper under CPL 200.20(2)(c) because the two offenses were the same or similar in law. The issue was whether the possession of stolen property count that was not charged in the felony complaint was the same or similar in law to the grand larceny offense so that its inclusion in the SCI on a joinder theory complied with CPL 195.20. The stolen property offense stemmed from defendant's possession of a stolen car. The grand larceny charge arose defendant's improper withdrawal of funds using a fraudulently obtained bank card. The appellate court held that the possession of stolen property charge was not sufficiently similar in law to be properly included in the waiver of indictment and the SCI. This improper inclusion in a waiver of indictment and SCI was a jurisdictional defect that required reversal of the conviction and dismissal of the SCI.


OUTCOME: The order of the intermediate appellate court was reversed, the guilty plea was vacated, the superior court information was dismissed, and the case was remitted for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Information - Jurisdictional Validity of Superior Court Information Containing Offense Not Joinable with Offense Charged in Original Felony Complaint

1. Reversal of defendant's conviction following his waiver of indictment and plea of guilty to a superior court information (SCI) charging him with grand larceny in the fourth degree, an offense for which he had been held for action by the grand jury in a superior court felony complaint, and criminal possession of stolen property in the third degree, a charge included on the theory that it was joinable with the grand larceny offense under CPL 195.20 and 200.20 (2) (c), was not warranted under People v Zanghi (79 NY2d 815, 588 N.E.2d 77, 580 N.Y.S.2d 179 [1991]). Under certain circumstances a defendant may waive indictment and consent to be prosecuted by SCI pursuant to CPL 195.10 if the SCI charges the defendant with either the same crime as the felony complaint or a lesser included offense of that crime. The waiver of indictment and SCI were deemed invalid in Zanghi because the SCI did not charge defendant with either of the offenses that had been included in the felony complaint, and the SCI charge was not a lesser included offense of either crime. Here, the exact offense charged in the superior court felony complaint was included in the waiver of indictment and charged in the SCI. Although the SCI here also contained another charge arising from a separate incident--criminal possession of stolen property in the third degree, an offense of higher grade or degree than the grand larceny offense--that, standing alone, did not establish the invalidity of the waiver of indictment and SCI under Zanghi.

Crimes - Information - Jurisdictional Validity of Superior Court Information Containing Offense Not Joinable with Offense Charged in Original Felony Complaint

2. Reversal of defendant's conviction following his waiver of indictment and plea of guilty to a superior court information (SCI) charging him with grand larceny in the fourth degree, an offense for which he had been held for action by the grand jury in a superior court felony complaint, and criminal possession of stolen property in the third degree, a charge arising from a separate incident but included on the theory that it was joinable with the grand larceny offense, was warranted. The criminal possession offense was not properly joined with the grand larceny charge under CPL 195.20 and 200.20 (2) (c). CPL 200.20 (2) (c) permits joinder of charges involving a single defendant and arising from different criminal transactions if "such offenses are defined by the same or similar statutory provisions and consequently are the same or similar in law." Here, the stolen property offense stemmed from the police discovering defendant in possession of a car that had previously been reported stolen, and the grand larceny charge arose from an incident in which defendant allegedly obtained a bank card by false pretenses and then withdrew funds from the victim's account without authorization. The only similarity was that both offenses involve misappropriated property. The crimes did not have comparable elements and the essential nature of the criminal conduct was quite distinct. The improper inclusion of the criminal possession offense in the waiver of indictment and SCI was a jurisdictional defect that, when raised on direct appeal, required reversal of the conviction and dismissal of the SCI.

 

84 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v Konstantinides


No. 198


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


14 N.Y.3d 1; 923 N.E.2d 567; 896 N.Y.S.2d 284; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 4485; 2009 NY Slip Op 9311


November 17, 2009, Argued 
December 17, 2009, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Writ of habeas corpus denied Konstantinides v. Griffin, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 80618 (E.D.N.Y., July 25, 2011)


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) that affirmed his convictions and his persistent violent felony offender sentence; defendant claimed, inter alia, that he was deprived of his right to conflict-free representation and that the trial court did not hold a hearing to determine the constitutionality of one of his two prior felony convictions.


OVERVIEW: After a high-speed chase in which defendant fired a weapon, an attorney for whom defendant had worked for a time while on parole (attorney number two) joined the defense team to assist attorney number one. During the trial, the People discovered that attorney number two had attempted to bribe and/or threatened potential witnesses and asked the trial judge to disqualify him. When the trial resumed, the second attorney remained at the defense table. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that the second attorney's continued representation of defendant created a potential conflict of interest. However, defendant failed to establish that the conflict operated on the defense. Defendant was fully informed of the potential conflict. In light of the first attorney's active participation, defendant failed to establish that the potential conflict with the second attorney entitled him to a new trial. Defendant's unsupported allegations regarding his plea and witnesses were insufficient to entitle him to a CPL 400.15(5) hearing on the constitutionality of his prior conviction.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Effective Representation -- Potential Conflict of Interest

1. The potential conflict of interest that existed when one of defendant's attorneys was accused in court of joining with defendant in attempts to suborn perjury and to bribe a potential witness did not deprive defendant of the effective assistance of counsel. Defendant was fully informed of the potential conflict, and neither defendant nor his other attorney, who did not suffer from any alleged conflict, complained that the potentially conflicted attorney's continued representation of defendant operated on the defense. Further, defendant was simultaneously represented by his conflict-free attorney who was singlemindedly devoted to defendant's best interests. In light of the conflict-free attorney's active participation, defendant failed to establish that the potential conflict operated on the defense such that he was entitled to a new trial.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Effective Representation -- Potential Conflict of Interest 

2. Defendant failed to establish that the potential conflict of interest that existed when one of his attorneys was accused in court of joining with defendant in attempts to suborn perjury and to bribe a potential witness operated on the defense such that defendant was entitled to a new trial. Notwithstanding defendant's argument that the conflicted attorney, who presented the defense case, had to decide which witnesses to call and what questions to ask them, knowing that those decisions could affect his livelihood and liberty, defendant did not point to any evidence elicited by the conflicted attorney that was harmful to him. Defendant's allegations that the conflicted attorney did not present evidence that would have been helpful to his defense were speculative and unsubstantiated. There was no reason to believe that the prosecutor's application to disqualify the conflicted attorney dissuaded the defense from calling a witness who allegedly would have testified that the gun which defendant was charged with possessing belonged to an acquaintance of defendant. Defendant never attempted to show that the witness actually existed, and was willing to provide truthful and beneficial testimony. While the record on appeal was insufficient to establish that the witness might have given relevant and honest testimony, nothing prevented defendant from raising an ineffective assistance claim in a CPL 440.10 motion.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Effective Representation -- Potential Conflict of Interest 

3. Defendant's conviction of weapons crimes was not reversed notwithstanding the trial judge's failure to place on the record the follow-up discussions that must have taken place after the prosecutor asked the trial judge to disqualify one of defendant's attorneys due to a potential conflict of interest that existed because of the attorney's alleged attempts to suborn perjury and to bribe a potential witness. Defendant was not relieved of his obligation to demonstrate that the potential conflict of interest actually operated on the defense.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Effective Representation -- Potential Conflict of Interest 

4. Although defendant was not required to show that a potential conflict of interest, established when one of defendant's attorneys was accused in court of joining with defendant in attempts to suborn perjury and to bribe a potential witness, affected the trial's outcome, any potential conflict between defendant's and the conflicted attorney's interests, in fact, had no impact on defendant's conviction for weapons crimes. Defendant was acquitted of kidnapping--the only charge where any truthful testimony from the potential witness casting doubt on the credibility of defendant's acquaintance, whom he was with at the time of the charged crimes, would have been relevant--and attempted murder charges were ultimately dismissed after the jury failed to reach a verdict on those counts. Any possible testimony from the potential witness that the gun belonged to or was owned by the acquaintance would not negate evidence which conclusively established that defendant possessed a weapon with the intent to use it, and thus was guilty of the firearms crimes that he was convicted of committing.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel -- Effective Representation -- Potential Conflict of Interest 

5. A per se rule mandating reversal in situations where a defense attorney is accused of criminal misconduct directly related to the representation of the defendant is not necessary to protect a defendant's right to conflict-free representation. A defendant does not have to establish that the conflict affected the outcome of the proceedings; a defendant must only show that the conflict operated on the defense. Here, defendant failed to make this minimum showing.

Crimes -- Sentence -- Persistent Violent Felony Offender -- Constitutionality of Prior Conviction -- Hearing 

6. Defendant was not improperly denied a hearing to challenge a prior conviction on constitutional grounds in connection with his adjudication as a persistent violent felony offender. Defendant's unsupported allegations that he wanted to call numerous witnesses who, he claimed, would demonstrate that his "guilty pleas were coerced" and that his attorney was "ineffective" were insufficient to entitle defendant to a hearing on the constitutionality of his prior conviction (see CPL 400.15). Defendant did not explain how his guilty pleas were coerced or in what way his attorney was ineffective. Nor did defendant indicate what information the named witnesses would provide on these issues.

 

85 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wrotten


No. 199


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


14 N.Y.3d 33; 923 N.E.2d 1099; 896 N.Y.S.2d 711; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 4472; 2009 NY Slip Op 9267


November 17, 2009, Argued 
December 15, 2009, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: US Supreme Court certiorari denied by Wrotten v New York, 130 S Ct 2520, 177 L Ed 2d 316, 2010 U.S. LEXIS 4566 (U.S., June 7, 2010)


DISPOSITION: Order reversed and case remitted to the Appellate Division, First Department, for consideration of the facts (see CPL 470.25[2][d]; 470.40[2][b]) and issues raised but not determined on the appeal to that court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) that reversed and vacated defendant's conviction for second-degree assault; the People claimed that the trial court had authority to admit the complainant's testimony via real-time, two-way video.


OVERVIEW: Shortly after defendant hit the 83-year old complainant with "something," the complainant moved to California to be near his children. The trial court held that the complainant was unavailable because he could not travel to New York without endangering his health. Therefore, it allowed the complainant to testify at trial live from a courtroom in California via two-way video. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that because CPL art. 65 addressed only a single, discrete circumstance, it left the trial court's pre-existing authority unaffected. The statutes providing for preservation of pre-trial testimony did not implicitly preclude the admission of live video testimony. Therefore, because the trial court did not abuse its inherent power and statutory authority under Judiciary Law § 2-b by permitting the real-time, two-way video, defendant's federal and state confrontation rights were not impaired.


OUTCOME: The order was reversed, and the case was remitted for consideration of the facts and issues raised, but not determined, on appeal.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Right of Confrontation -- Live Two-Way Televised Testimony -- Authority of Trial Court to Permit Televised Testimony of Adult Witness

1. Supreme Court had the authority to permit the adult complainant to testify at defendant's trial via live, two-way televised testimony following a finding of necessity. Although the Legislature has primary authority to regulate court procedure, the State Constitution permits the courts latitude to adopt procedures consistent with general practice as provided by statute. By enacting Judiciary Law § 2-b (3), the Legislature has explicitly authorized the courts' use of innovative procedures where "necessary to carry into effect the powers and jurisdiction possessed by [the court]." There is no specific statutory authority evincing legislative policy proscribing televised testimony, and, in fact, the CPL requires live video testimony of a child witness in a prosecution of a sex crime after a judicial finding of "vulnerability" (CPL art 65). Because article 65 addresses only a single, discrete circumstance and otherwise leaves courts' preexisting authority unaffected (see CPL 65.10 [3]), testimony via two-way televised transmission of a witness found to be elderly, infirm and physically incapable of appearing in court, as complainant was found to be by the trial court here, is presumably left to the trial court's discretion. Nor do the statutes providing for preservation of pretrial testimony implicitly preclude the admission of live video testimony. The CPL does not purport to list all instances where live video testimony is permissible or all possible solutions to the problem of an unavailable witness.

Crimes -- Right of Confrontation -- Live Two-Way Televised Testimony -- Authority of Trial Court to Permit Televised Testimony of Adult Witness -- Exercise of Authority Following Finding of Necessity Permissible under Confrontation Clause

2. The exercise of Supreme Court's authority to permit live, two-way televised testimony of the adult complainant following a finding of necessity was permissible under the Confrontation Clauses of both the Federal and State Constitutions (see NY Const, art I, § 6; US Const 6th Amend). Assuming without deciding that two-way video does not always satisfy the Confrontation Clause's face-to-face confrontation requirement, complainant's testimony here would nonetheless be admissible under the federal standard if findings of necessity and reliability were made by Supreme Court. Live two-way video may preserve the essential safeguards of testimonial reliability, and so satisfy the Confrontation Clause's primary concern with ensuring the reliability of the evidence against a criminal defendant by subjecting it to rigorous testing in the context of an adversary proceeding before the trier of fact, provided all of the other elements of the confrontation right are preserved. Those traditional indicia of reliability, which include testimony under oath, the opportunity for contemporaneous cross-examination, and the opportunity for the judge, jury and defendant to view the witness's demeanor as he or she testifies, were all present here. Moreover, if Supreme Court's findings were supported by clear and convincing evidence, the requirement that an important public policy be furthered by the proposed procedure was satisfied. The public policy of justly resolving criminal cases while at the same time protecting the well-being of a witness can require live, two-way video testimony in the rare case where a key witness cannot physically travel to court in New York and where, as here, defendant's confrontation rights have been minimally impaired.

 

86 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Matter of Goldstein v New York State Urban Dev. Corp.


No. 178


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


13 N.Y.3d 511; 921 N.E.2d 164; 893 N.Y.S.2d 472; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 4090; 2009 NY Slip Op 8677


October 14, 2009, Argued 
November 24, 2009, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Reargument denied by Matter of Goldstein v. N. Y. State Urban Dev. Corp., 2010 N.Y. LEXIS 65 (N.Y., Feb. 18, 2010)
Related proceeding at Matter of New York State Urban Dev. Corp. (Atlantic Yards Land Use Improvement & Civic Project - Phase 1), 26 Misc 3d 1228[A], 2010 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 364 (2010)


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner owners appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) in favor of respondent condemnor; the owners claimed, inter alia, that the proposed taking of their property violated N.Y. Const. art. I, § 7(a), art. XVIII, § 6, and EDPL 207(C)(1) as it was not for a public use.


OVERVIEW: The condemnor sought to use its eminent domain power to take certain privately owned properties for inclusion in a 22-acre mixed-use development proposed, and to be undertaken, by a private developer. The project would include a sports arena, various infrastructure improvements, and residential purposes, more than a third of which were to be affordable either for low and or middle income families. Although the area in which the project was to be situated was found to be substandard and unsanitary, two blocks and a fraction of a third had not previously been designated as blighted. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that the owners had every right to include in their federal action a supplemental state law cause of action. Any limitation upon the sovereign power of eminent domain in the urban renewal context was a matter for the Legislature, not the courts. All that was at issue was a reasonable difference of opinion as to whether the area in question was in fact substandard and unsanitary, which was not a sufficient predicate to supplant the condemnor's determination. Accordingly, the public taking requirements of §§ 7(a), 6, and 207(C)(1) were not violated.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Commencement of Action after Termination of Prior Action -- Judicial Review of Eminent Domain Determination

1. Petitioners' proceeding pursuant to EDPL 207 challenging the condemnation of their properties, commenced more than 30 days after the determination's completion and publication but within six months of the dismissal of petitioners' federal court action challenging the determination, was timely. Although EDPL 207 (A) provides that a proceeding challenging an EDPL 204 condemnation determination must be filed in the appropriate Appellate Division within 30 days following the determination's completion and publication, the CPLR generally applies to EDPL proceedings, and CPLR 205 (a) effectively tolls the running of a statutory period to permit refiling within six months when an action has been timely commenced but dismissed on grounds other than those enumerated in the statute. Here, petitioners' initial challenge to respondent's determination was made in a timely federal court action asserting both federal constitutional claims and a pendant state claim seeking review of the determination pursuant to EDPL 207. The court rejected the federal claims and declined to exercise its supplemental jurisdiction over the state law claim, which was dismissed "without prejudice to its being re-filed in state court" and not upon any of the grounds enumerated in CPLR 205 (a). The EDPL does not, by prescribing a special limitations period within which review of condemnation determinations must be sought, strip a litigant of the benefit of CPLR 205 (a). Nor should policy considerations favoring expedition in condemnation proceedings deny litigants the remedial benefit of CPLR 205 (a), which itself implements the "vitally important" policy preference for the determination of actions on the merits. In actuality, it was not the availability of CPLR 205 (a) that delayed the condemnation here, but rather the availability of a federal forum. Moreover, the 30-day filing period prescribed in EDPL 207 (A) is merely a limitation upon the time within which a challenge to a condemnation determination may be brought, not a condition of maintaining any such challenge.

Eminent Domain -- Public Use -- Land Use Improvement Project -- Rehabilitation of Substandard and Insanitary Areas

2. The determination authorizing the condemnation of petitioners' properties for inclusion in a land use improvement project proposed by a private developer upon findings by respondent urban development corporation that the area in which the project was to be situated was "substandard and insanitary" did not constitute a taking for the benefit of a private party in violation of article I, § 7 (a) of the State Constitution. The Legislature has the power to provide for the rehabilitation of "substandard and insanitary areas" (NY Const, art XVIII, § 1), and it may grant the power of eminent domain to any public corporation for such purpose (NY Const, art XVIII, § 2). Respondent has been vested with the condemnation power by the Legislature, and sought to exercise the power here for the constitutionally recognized public purpose or "use" of rehabilitating a blighted area. Although there might have been a reasonable difference of opinion as to whether the area in question was in fact "substandard and insanitary" within the meaning of article XVIII, such a difference did not furnish a ground to afford petitioners relief. Whether a matter should be the subject of a public undertaking is ordinarily the province of the Legislature, and the actual specification of the uses identified by the Legislature as public has been largely left to quasi-legislative administrative agencies. Judges may not substitute their views as to the adequacy with which the public purpose of blight removal has been made out unless there is no room for reasonable difference of opinion as to whether an area is blighted.

Eminent Domain -- Public Use -- Land Use Improvement Project -- Occupancy Not Limited to Low Income Individuals

3. In a proceeding to review respondent urban development corporation's determination authorizing the condemnation of petitioners' properties for inclusion in a land use improvement project upon respondent's findings that the area in which the project was to be situated was "substandard and insanitary," the housing units to be built as part of the project were not required to be reserved for low income tenants under article XVIII, § 6 of the State Constitution. The principal, and independent, objectives of article XVIII were to facilitate the clearance of slums and the construction of low rent housing (NY Const, art XVIII, § 1). The commitment of public funds to a land use improvement project involving housing construction does not effect a linkage of the article's otherwise independent purposes. Although article XVIII, § 6, in referring to projects receiving state aid, states that occupancy "shall be restricted to persons of low income" and preference "given to persons who live or shall have lived in" the substandard and unsanitary area undergoing rehabilitation, the intention behind that provision was to provide for replacement of the housing units lost during slum clearance. Here, however, the project was not directed at the wholesale eradication of slums, but rather at alleviating relatively mild conditions of urban blight principally attributable to a large and uninhabited subgrade rail cut. The contemplated clearance would not cause direct displacement of large concentrations of low income individuals. The creation of low income housing, although a generally worthy objective, is not constitutionally required under article XVIII, § 6 as an element of a land use improvement project that does not entail substantial slum clearance.

 

87 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Matter of Walton v New York State Dept. of Correctional Servs.


No. 149


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


13 N.Y.3d 475; 921 N.E.2d 145; 893 N.Y.S.2d 453; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 4081; 2009 NY Slip Op 8665


October 13, 2009, Argued 
November 23, 2009, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, family members and legal services providers of inmates, appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) that dismissed as time barred their CPLR art. 78 action against respondent Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) for refund of a portion of a telephone charge allocated as a DOCS commission.


OVERVIEW: Under the DOCS' telephone calling system, the petitioners were charged a certain rate by the service provider, a percentage of which was paid to DOCS as a commission. The petitioners claimed that the commission constituted an illegal tax or fee, amounted to a government taking without just compensation, and violated their equal protection, free speech, and association rights. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that the petitioners' constitutional challenges under N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1, and art. I, §§ 1, 7(a), 8, and 11 lacked merit. The obligation to pay the commission was imposed on the provider, not the petitioners. Therefore, it was not a tax. A takings could not occur in the absence of government compulsion. The petitioners were in control of the length of the calls and, thus, the costs incurred. The hardship alleged by the petitioners was not a constitutionally significant curtailment of the free speech and association guarantee. Finally, the petitioners failed to show that DOCS engaged in an action that treated two similarly-situated classes of individuals differently. Accordingly, their art. 78 petition was properly dismissed.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Separation of Powers -- Power to Tax - Challenge to Commissions Paid on Collect Calls by Inmates

1. The collection by the Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) of a commission which represented a percentage of the revenues generated on each collect call placed by an inmate in a DOCS facility was neither a tax, in violation of the Separation of Powers Doctrine embedded in the New York Constitution (NY Const, art III, § 1; art XVI, § 1), nor an improper fee. The contractual obligation of the telephone services provider to remit the commission to DOCS constituted a permissible voluntary contractual arrangement between a governmental entity and the private sector. A per-call calculation commission is a standard method of compensating the owner of the property where a payphone is located. Although the provider intended to collect the total rate from call recipients, including the portion covering the commission, it owed the commission to DOCS regardless of whether it actually received payment from these consumers. The commission was not transformed into a tax or fee just because the provider passed this cost on to call recipients along with its other reasonable operating expenses. Notably, DOCS could not have collected the commission directly from the call recipient, which distinguished this scenario from a tax. The contractual arrangement related to DOCS' performance of a governmental function--the administration of the prison system--but it lacked the hallmarks of a tax or fee because DOCS did not compel petitioners to purchase services from the telephone services provider, nor are telephone services a government benefit. Finally, even if the DOCS commission were viewed as a tax, petitioners' claim for refunds would be barred because they failed to pay the rate under protest.

Constitutional Law -- Taking of Property -- Challenge to Commissions Paid on Collect Calls by Inmates

2. The collection by the Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) of a commission which represented a percentage of the revenues generated on each collect call placed by an inmate in a DOCS facility was not a "taking" without just compensation in violation of New York Constitution, article I, § 7 (a). A "taking" cannot occur in the absence of government compulsion. Petitioners, legal services providers who represent prisoners and individuals who had accepted collect telephone calls from family members incarcerated in DOCS facilities, were not compelled to pay anything to DOCS or to the telephone services provider, nor was their money or other property confiscated by the state. The acceptance of collect calls was voluntary action and, by taking the calls, petitioners agreed to pay the associated rate. Nor was there any appropriation of private property without "just compensation" because, in exchange for their payments, petitioners received telephone services. The New York Constitution did not require DOCS to ensure that petitioners received telephone services at the lowest possible expense.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Challenge to Commissions Paid on Collect Calls by Inmates

3. In a combined declaratory judgment action and proceeding pursuant to CPLR article 78 challenging the collection by the Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) of a commission which represented a percentage of the revenues generated on each collect call placed by an inmate in a DOCS facility, petitioners, legal services providers who represent prisoners and individuals who had accepted collect telephone calls from family members incarcerated in DOCS facilities, failed to state a viable claim under the Free Speech and Association Clause (NY Const, art I, § 8). Notwithstanding petitioners' allegation that the increased cost of inmate calls resulting from the DOCS commission impaired their constitutionally protected right to speak to and associate with their incarcerated loved ones or clients, petitioners did not allege that the commission was so high that it substantially impaired the limited right of inmates to contact and associate with family members or legal services providers and that the commission bore no reasonable relationship to legitimate penological aims. While inmates have a constitutional right to communicate with the outside world, this does not equate to a right to use a specific means for such communication--the telephone--much less to guarantee telephone services at a particular cost. Inasmuch as alternate means of communication were available to New York inmates and their families, with mail offered at low or no cost, the additional expense associated with the DOCS commission on telephone calls did not imperil the right of inmates to communicate with others.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Challenge to Commissions Paid on Collect Calls by Inmates

4. In a combined declaratory judgment action and proceeding pursuant to CPLR article 78 challenging the collection by the Department of Correctional Services (DOCS) of a commission which represented a percentage of the revenues generated on each collect call placed by an inmate in a DOCS facility, petitioners, legal services providers who represent prisoners and individuals who had accepted collect telephone calls from family members incarcerated in DOCS facilities, failed to state a cognizable equal protection claim (NY Const, art I, § 11). Petitioners alleged that they had been forced to pay DOCS commissions, which were used by DOCS to fund the New York prison system, even though they were situated no differently from other New York residents. There was no category of individuals situated similarly to petitioners that could be used as a basis for comparison. All recipients of inmate calls were treated the same way under the contract between DOCS and the telephone services provider.

 

88 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Godfrey v. Spano


No. 147


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


13 N.Y.3d 358; 920 N.E.2d 328; 892 N.Y.S.2d 272; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 4050; 2009 NY Slip Op 8474; 107 Fair Empl. Prac. Cas. (BNA) 1358


October 13, 2009, Argued 
November 19, 2009, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In two cases, appellant taxpayers challenged actions by respondents officials and department that recognized out-of-state same-sex marriages for public employee benefits purposes. One case was dismissed and the department was awarded summary judgment the other action. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department, and the Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Third Department, affirmed. The taxpayers appealed.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers in the first case claimed, pursuant to General Municipal Law § 51, that one of the officials illegally legislated in the areas of marriage and domestic relations by issuing an executive order relating to recognition of out-of-state same-sex marriages. However, the taxpayers alleged no fraud. Further, the complaint did not identify a specific impact that the executive order had on a public employee or private individual in the county. This lack of specificity was fatal to the claim. The county already insured same-sex domestic partners and dependents of county employees before the executive order. In the other case, the taxpayers invoked State Finance Law § 123-b and the separation of powers doctrine. However, the department had offered health benefits to domestic partners since the mid-1990s, and the taxpayers failed to state a claim. Although the taxpayers alleged that the department's actions violated Civil Service Law § 164, the statute itself refuted the claim. The President of the Civil Service Commission had broad discretion to define who qualified for coverage. There was no conflict between the Civil Service Law and the department's challenged memorandum.


OUTCOME: The judgments were affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Taxpayer's Action -- Recognition of Out-of-State Same-Sex Marriages for Purposes of Public Employee Health Insurance Coverage 

1. In an action challenging an Executive Order (Westchester County Executive Order No. 3 of 2006) which recognized out-of-state same-sex marriages for purposes of public employee health insurance coverage and other benefits, plaintiff taxpayers failed to allege an unlawful expenditure of taxpayer funds, and thus did not state a cognizable claim under General Municipal Law § 51. Plaintiffs did not identify any specific impact that the Executive Order had on any public employee or private individual in the County, and failed to specify a circumstance where taxpayer funds were expended as a result of the Executive Order that would not have been expended in the absence of the order. The County had already insured same-sex domestic partners and dependents of county employees before the Executive Order was issued, requiring only that applicants for domestic partner coverage have lived with their domestic partners in a committed financially interdependent relationship for at least a year.

State -- Taxpayer's Action -- Recognition of Out-of-State Same-Sex Marriages for Purposes of Public Employee Health Insurance Coverage

2. In an action challenging a Policy Memorandum issued by the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Civil Service which recognized out-of-state same-sex marriages for purposes of public employee health insurance coverage and other benefits, plaintiff taxpayers failed to state a cause of action under State Finance Law § 123-b since they failed to allege an unlawful expenditure of taxpayer funds. Plaintiffs made conclusory allegations that defendants "are expending and will expend State funds and/or resources supplied from New York State tax revenue," without claiming specific expenditures that would not otherwise have been incurred. While a taxpayer may bring suit under this statute to prevent the unlawful expenditure of state funds "whether or not such person is or may be affected or specially aggrieved" (State Finance Law § 123-b [1]), there must be some specific threat of an imminent expenditure. The Department of Civil Service had offered New York State Health Insurance Program benefits to domestic partners since the mid-1990s.

Constitutional Law -- Separation of Powers -- Recognition of Out-of-State Same-Sex Marriages for Purposes of Public Employee Health Insurance Coverage

3. A Policy Memorandum issued by the Commissioner of the New York State Department of Civil Service recognizing out-of-state same-sex marriages for purposes of public employee health insurance coverage and other benefits, was not in conflict with Civil Service Law § 164, which provides for health insurance to the spouses and dependent children of state officers and employees. It was clear, from the plain language of the statute and from the legislative history, that the Legislature intended to give the Department of Civil Service--guided by the collective bargaining process--complete discretion to determine the limits of dependent coverage, provided that, at a minimum, spouses and dependent children were covered.

 

89 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Skelos v. Paterson


No. 183


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


13 N.Y.3d 141; 915 N.E.2d 1141; 886 N.Y.S.2d 846; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 3578; 2009 NY Slip Op 6585


September 11, 2009, Argued 
September 22, 2009, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, without costs, the motion for an injunction denied and certified question answered in the negative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff senators sued defendants, the governor, secretary of state, and nominee for the office of lieutenant-governor, challenging the governor's appointment of the nominee as lieutenant-governor. The trial court preliminarily enjoined the nominee from exercising the powers of the office of lieutenant-governor. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Second Department, affirmed. The governor, secretary of state, and nominee appealed.


OVERVIEW: The governor relied on Public Officers Law § 43 in making the appointment. The intermediate appellate court held that the appointment was unlawful because no provision of the New York Constitution or of any statute provided for the filling of a vacancy in the office of lieutenant-governor other than by election, and only the temporary president of the senate was authorized to perform the duties of that office during the period of the vacancy. The intermediate appellate court certified a question. The appellate court found that, while, generally, election was the preferred means of filling vacancies in elective office, the elective principle was not preeminent when it came to filling a vacancy in the office of lieutenant-governor. Public Officers Law § 43 afforded the governor the authority to fill a vacancy in that office by appointment. N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 6 was not a limitation on gubernatorial appointment pursuant to § 43, but merely stated what was to occur while there was a vacancy; it did not, and could not have, consistent with the command of N.Y. Const. art. XIII, § 3, been understood to state that the vacancy may not have been filled.


OUTCOME: The order of the intermediate appellate court was reversed, the motion for an injunction was denied, and the certified question was answered in the negative.



HEADNOTES

Governor -- Powers of Governor -- Authority to Appoint Lieutenant Governor to Fill Vacancy

The Governor had the authority, pursuant to Public Officers Law § 43, to fill a vacancy in the office of Lieutenant Governor by appointment. The State Constitution specifies that "[t]he legislature shall provide for filling vacancies in office" (NY Const, art XIII, § 3), and expressly contemplates that vacancies in elective office may be filled by appointment. In pursuance of the constitutional mandate imposed by article XIII, § 3, the Legislature enacted Public Officers Law §§ 41, 42 and 43, three comprehensive and complementary provisions. Public Officers Law § 43, the catchall provision for vacancies not otherwise covered by sections 41 and 42, was applicable here and states that if a vacancy in an elective office occurs "otherwise than by expiration of term, with no provision of law for filling the same," the Governor "shall appoint a person to execute the duties thereof until the vacancy shall be filled by an election." Here, the position of Lieutenant Governor became vacant when the previous Governor resigned and the current Governor, who was the Lieutenant Governor at that time, became Governor for the remainder of his predecessor's term. There was no provision of law, apart from Public Officers Law § 43, for filling the vacancy. Although article IV, § 6 of the State Constitution authorizes the temporary president of the Senate to perform all the Lieutenant Governor's duties if the Lieutenant Governor is not able to do so or the office is vacant, that direction applies only "during [the] vacancy or inability." It cannot fill or end the vacancy, and is not a limitation upon gubernatorial appointment pursuant to Public Officers Law § 43. Nor does article XIII, §3's proviso that "no person appointed to fill a vacancy [in elective office] shall hold his or her office by virtue of such appointment longer than the commencement of the political year next succeeding the first annual election after the happening of the vacancy" prevent the Governor from appointing a Lieutenant Governor, as that provision demands only that a vacancy in an elective office be filled by election in the shortest space of time reasonably possible. Moreover, although election is generally the preferred means of filling vacancies in elective office, the elective principle is not preeminent when it comes to filling a vacancy in the office of Lieutenant Governor.

 

90 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Matter of New York Charter Schools Assn., Inc. v. DiNapoli


No. 108


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


13 N.Y.3d 120; 914 N.E.2d 991; 886 N.Y.S.2d 74; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 2547; 2009 NY Slip Op 5204


June 2, 2009, Argued 
June 25, 2009, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and order and judgment of Supreme Court, Albany County, reinstated.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The trial court permanently enjoined respondents, the State of New York, the Office of the New York State Comptroller, and the Comptroller, from auditing appellant charter schools, holding that General Municipal Law § 33(2) and Education Law § 2854(1)(c), which authorized such audits, violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1. The New York Appellate Division reversed. The schools appealed.


OVERVIEW: Education Law § 2854(1)(c) required charter schools to be subject to the State Comptroller's audit just like other public schools. General Municipal Law § 33 required the Comptroller to cause the accounts of all charter schools in the State to be examined by March 31, 2010. The schools contended that assignment to the Comptroller of the power and duty to audit charter schools violated N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 because charter schools were not political subdivisions of the State, nor was the task of auditing charter schools an administrative duty that was incidental to the Comptroller's constitutionally prescribed functions. The high court agreed. Audits of charter schools--which were not political subdivisions--could not be construed as incidental to the audits of school districts. N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 stated that the legislature could assign to the Comptroller no administrative duties, "excepting such as may be incidental to the performance of" the functions set forth therein. The plainly expressed constitutional prohibition of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1 did not support an expansive reading of the term "incidental."


OUTCOME: The order of the intermediate appellate court was reversed and the order and judgment of the trial court was reinstated.



HEADNOTES

State -- Comptroller -- Assignment to Comptroller of Authority to Audit Charter Schools Unconstitutional 

Assignment to the State Comptroller of the power and duty to audit charter schools violated article V, § 1 of the New York State Constitution. Article V, § 1 gives the Legislature the authority to delegate to the Comptroller the power and duty to supervise the accounts of any political subdivision of the State, and provides that the Comptroller shall not be assigned administrative duties, except those incidental to the performance of his or her functions. Charter schools are not political subdivisions of the State, nor is the task of auditing charter schools an administrative duty incidental to the Comptroller's constitutionally prescribed functions. Accordingly, the provisions of General Municipal Law § 33 (2) and Education Law § 2854 (1) (c), to the extent that they direct the Comptroller to conduct audits of charter schools, are unconstitutional. The Legislature has designated the Board of Regents and the charter entities as the public agents authorized to supervise and oversee charter schools. Audits of charter schools--not political subdivisions--cannot be construed as incidental to the audits of school districts authorized by the Legislature (L 2005, ch 267; General Municipal Law § 33 [2]). The plainly expressed constitutional prohibition of article V, § 1 does not support such an expansive reading of the term "incidental." The Comptroller, as the State's chief fiscal officer, has not been authorized to audit the management and operations of an entity--not a political subdivision--solely on the basis that it receives State funds and performs a governmental function. An audit of the performance of charter schools could not be considered to be within an audit of the monies paid by a school district acting as a mere conduit by forwarding the funds necessary to pay a student's tuition.

 

91 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Davis


No. 86


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


13 N.Y.3d 17; 912 N.E.2d 1044; 884 N.Y.S.2d 665; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 1850; 2009 NY Slip Op 4739


April 29, 2009, Argued 
June 11, 2009, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order by the Appellate Term (New York), which affirmed his conviction of failing to comply with a posted sign indicating a city park's closing time; defendant claimed, inter alia, that assignment of his case to a judicial hearing officer (JHO) pursuant to CPL 350.20 was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant apparently signed a form explaining that his case was being referred to a JHO for trial and/or final disposition and sentence. The form explicitly stated that defendant had the right to adjudicate the case before a criminal court judge. Further, the form listed the scope of the JHO's authority as derived from CPL 350.20. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that since consent was a prerequisite to JHO adjudication, nothing in N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 15(a) prohibited the Legislature from enacting CPL 350.20. Upon balancing the interests of the parties, the contested procedures, and the government's stake in the outcome, CPL 350.20 did not violate either the federal or state due process clause. CPL 350.20's consensual JHO adjudication procedure adequately protected defendant's interest in a fair trial. Accordingly, defendant's constitutional arguments failed.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Trial -- Assignment to Judicial Hearing Officer -- State Constitution

1. CPL 350.20, which permits class B misdemeanors to be tried and determined by judicial hearing officers (JHOs) "upon agreement of the parties," does not violate the provision of the New York Constitution establishing the New York City Criminal Court and setting certain qualifications for that court's judges (NY Const, art VI, § 15 [a]). Consensual JHO adjudication was intended to contribute to the goal of reducing pernicious calendar congestion, thereby fostering the more efficient administration of criminal justice. The jury trial rights of the defendant here, who was charged with a class B misdemeanor, were not threatened, as he would have had a bench trial had the parties not consented to have the matter adjudicated by a JHO. As the Legislature envisioned when enacting CPL 350.20, the trial of defendant's case represented the sort of referral upon the consent of the parties that has long been permitted in this state. Nothing in article VI, § 15 (a) prohibited the Legislature from enacting CPL 350.20.

Crimes -- Trial -- Assignment to Judicial Hearing Officer -- Due Process

2. CPL 350.20, which permits class B misdemeanors to be tried and determined by judicial hearing officers (JHOs) "upon agreement of the parties," does not violate the Due Process Clauses of the State or Federal Constitutions. Defendant's due process interest in his class B misdemeanor prosecution was not that of having his case determined by a "judge," but rather that of having a fair trial in a fair tribunal. There is nothing in the nature of a consensual JHO adjudication that gives rise to any substantial concern that the presiding JHO would lack the neutrality that is a fundamental command of due process. Prospective JHOs are carefully evaluated prior to appointment for potentially renewable one-year terms and are subject to performance evaluations and removal for unsatisfactory performance. Those and other safeguards, when combined with the consensual nature of JHO adjudication under CPL 350.20 and the availability of appellate review, adequately protected defendant's due process right to a fair tribunal. Moreover, the governmental interest in ensuring the maintenance of a carefully-vetted, highly-qualified staff of JHOs standing ready to fairly and efficiently adjudicate petty criminal cases is substantial.

Crimes -- Trial -- Assignment to Judicial Hearing Officer -- Validity of Consent

3. The consent to adjudication of defendant's class B misdemeanor trial by a judicial hearing officer (JHO) pursuant to CPL 350.20 was valid, as defense counsel participated fully in the trial held before a JHO without objection and the court file contained a JHO consent form signed by defendant. Unlike other statutes governing waivers of rights in criminal proceedings, CPL 350.20 (1) requires the "parties['] agreement," not defendant's personal consent. Moreover, the decision whether to agree to JHO adjudication of a petty criminal case represents the sort of tactical decision best left to the determination of counsel. It was not necessary for the trial court to have engaged defendant in an oral colloquy regarding whether he understood the effect of the signed JHO consent form.

Crimes -- Information -- Sufficiency of Allegations of Violation of New York City Parks and Recreation Department Rules

4. The information charging defendant with being in a New York City park after the park's posted closing time in violation of New York City Parks and Recreation Department Rules (56 RCNY) § 1-03 (c) (2), prepared by the police officer who had observed defendant in the park after hours, was facially sufficient. Although the rule contains qualifying language stating that a person may disregard a park sign "upon order by a Police Officer or designated Department employee," it was not necessary that the information state whether that portion of the rule applied to defendant. The qualifying language was not a true "exception" that must be pleaded by the People, but rather a "proviso" that defendant was required to raise as a bar to prosecution.

 

92 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Anonymous v. City of Rochester


No. 81


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


13 N.Y.3d 35; 915 N.E.2d 593; 886 N.Y.S.2d 648; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 2010; 2009 NY Slip Op 4697


April 28, 2009, Argued 
June 9, 2009, Decided


DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondents father and son brought an action against appellant city, and others, challenging the constitutionality of Rochester, N.Y., City Code ch. 45, which established a nighttime curfew for juveniles. The trial court dismissed the action. The Supreme Court of New York, Appellate Division, Fourth Department, reversed, ruling that the ordinance was unconstitutional. The city appealed.


OVERVIEW: The father and the son challenged the curfew on constitutional and non-constitutional grounds. The appellate court addressed only the arguments addressing the substantive due process rights of minors to enjoy freedom of movement and the substantive due process rights of parents to control the upbringing of their children. Because the purpose of the curfew was, in part, to prevent victimization of minors, it was within the realm of the government's legitimate concern. Intermediate scrutiny was proper. However, the curfew was constitutionally infirm. The proof offered by the city failed to show the necessary nexus between the curfew and the stated purposes of Rochester, N.Y., City Code ch. 45. Incidents cited by the city would not have been prevented by the curfew because two of the victims were killed during hours outside the curfew and the third was already subject to an individualized curfew. The crime statistics produced by the city did not support the curfew's objectives. Further, the curfew imposed an unconstitutional burden on a parent's substantive due process rights. The curfew was not substantially related to the stated goals of promoting parental supervision.


OUTCOME: The order of the intermediate appellate court was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Academic and Moot Questions

1. An action challenging the validity of a city ordinance which established a nighttime curfew for minors under the age of 17 was not rendered moot when plaintiff turned 17, because he could still be detained under the curfew if, to a police officer, he appeared to be under 17 and failed to offer proof of his age.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Ordinance -- Juvenile Curfew

2. A city ordinance establishing a juvenile nighttime curfew violated plaintiff minor's federal and state constitutional due process rights to freedom of movement, and plaintiff parent's federal and state constitutional due process rights to control the upbringing of his children. Notwithstanding that the City, pursuant to its broad police powers, had the authority to enact a curfew ordinance, the ordinance was constitutionally infirm under the applicable intermediate scrutiny analysis, pursuant to which defendants were required to show that the ordinance was substantially related to the achievement of important government interests. While defendants' governmental interest was to prevent minors from perpetrating and becoming victims of crime during nighttime hours, the proof offered by the City failed to support the aims of the curfew. The incidents that led to the enactment of the ordinance, the deaths of three minors, would not have been prevented by the curfew and thus did not provide the necessary nexus between the curfew and the ordinance's stated purpose. Further, the crime statistics produced by defendants did not support the objectives of the curfew. Moreover, the curfew imposed an unconstitutional burden on a parent's substantive due process rights because it failed to offer parents enough flexibility or autonomy in supervising their children. An exception allowing for parental consent to the activities of minors during curfew hours is of paramount importance to the due process rights of parents. Absent such exception, the challenged curfew was not substantially related to the stated goals of promoting parental supervision.

 

93 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Koehler v. Bank of Bermuda Ltd.


No. 82


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


12 N.Y.3d 533; 911 N.E.2d 825; 883 N.Y.S.2d 763; 2009 N.Y. LEXIS 1751; 2009 NY Slip Op 4297


April 28, 2009, Argued 
June 4, 2009, Decided


DISPOSITION: Following certification of a question by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and acceptance of the question by this Court pursuant to section 500.27 of the Rules of Practice of the New York State Court of Appeals, and after hearing argument by counsel for the parties and consideration of the briefs and the record submitted, certified question answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit filed a certified question to decide whether it could order defendant bank, over which it had personal jurisdiction, to deliver stock certificates owned by defendant judgment debtor (or cash equal to their value) to plaintiff judgment creditor, pursuant to CPLR art. 52, when the stock certificates were located outside New York.


OVERVIEW: After the judgment creditor was awarded a default judgment in Maryland against the judgment debtor, his former business partner, the creditor duly registered the judgment in New York. Thereafter, the creditor filed a petition against the bank to deliver the certificates, which the debtor had pledged as collateral for a loan, to him. However, the bank revealed that the stock certificates were no longer in its possession. The obligations for which the bank had held the certificates as collateral had been satisfied and the bank--despite the District Court's turnover order--had transferred the stock to a Bermudan company existing for the debtor's benefit. The District Court then dismissed the creditor's petition, inter alia, for lack of in rem jurisdiction over the debtor's shares. The Court of Appeals found that because the New York court had personal jurisdiction over the bank, it could order it to turn over out-of-state property regardless of whether the bank was a judgment debtor or a garnishee, pursuant to CPLR 5225(b).


OUTCOME: The certified question was answered in the affirmative.



HEADNOTES

Creditors' Suits--Turnover Order--Turnover of Out-of-State Assets Held by Garnishee
