Rather, the Legislature intended to criminalize the activities of adults who engage minors in sexually infused communication. The statute has been correctly construed to criminalize the use of any "sexually explicit communications," and is not void for vagueness.

 

113 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


E.S. v. P.D.


No. 7


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


8 N.Y.3d 150; 863 N.E.2d 100; 831 N.Y.S.2d 96; 2007 N.Y. LEXIS 118; 2007 NY Slip Op 1336


January 3, 2007, Argued 
February 15, 2007, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order, insofar as appealed from, affirmed, with costs.



CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent grandmother, under Domestic Relations Law § 72 and Family Ct Act § 651, sought reasonable visitation with her grandchild. Appellant father opposed her request and sought an order barring her contact with the child. The trial court granted judgment to the grandmother, and ordered visitation. The Appellate Division (New York) affirmed, modifying certain terms of the visitation schedule, and the father sought further review.


OVERVIEW: After the child's mother's cancer diagnosis, the grandmother moved into the child's home to care for him, continuing after the mother died, until the father asked her to leave. The court of appeals held she had standing to seek visitation under Domestic Relations Law § 72(1), due to the mother's death. Findings that the grandmother's visitation with the child was in his best interest were supported. The trial court considered the father's right to rear the child but found the grandmother had a close relationship with the child and respected her and the father's separate roles in the child's life, and that no credible evidence supported his claim that she sought to usurp his parental role. When the Appellate Division affirmed these findings, the court of appeals could not revisit them. It was strongly presumed that the father's wishes were in the child's best interests, under § 72(1), but the grandmother rebutted this presumption, and the child's best interests were properly considered. Section 72(1) was not unconstitutional facially or as applied as it was interpreted to defer to a parent's wishes, and it was presumed that the father's wishes were in the child's best interests.


OUTCOME: The lower court's judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Visitation Rights of Grandparents 

1. Section 72 (1) of the Domestic Relations Law was properly applied in granting petitioner grandmother visitation with her grandchild. Petitioner had automatic standing to seek visitation under section 72 (1) based upon the death of the child's mother, and record evidence supported the determination of the courts below that visitation between petitioner and the child was in the child's best interest. Supreme Court was properly mindful of respondent father's right to rear the child as he saw fit, but determined that the grandmother had established an extraordinarily close relationship with the child during the nearly five-year period that she had lived with him and respondent, and that the relationship with the grandmother was central to the child's well-being.

Appeal -- Court of Appeals 

2. In a proceeding pursuant to Domestic Relations Law § 72 (1) in which petitioner sought reasonable visitation with her grandchild, findings of fact made by the trial court which were expressly affirmed by the Appellate Division and had the requisite evidentiary support were conclusive and binding on the Court of Appeals.

Parent and Child -- Visitation Rights of Grandparents -- Facial Constitutionality of Grandparent Visitation Statute 

3. Domestic Relations Law § 72 (1), which provides a procedural mechanism for grandparents to acquire standing to seek visitation with a minor grandchild, was not rendered facially unconstitutional by the decision of the United States Supreme Court in Troxel v Granville (530 US 57, 120 S Ct 2054, 147 L Ed 2d 49 [2000]). The statute at issue in Troxel permitted any person to petition for visitation rights and authorized the trial court to grant such rights in the best interest of the child. The Supreme Court held that application of the statute violated the mother's due process right to make decisions concerning the care, custody and control of her children. Section 72 (1) accords deference to a parent's decisions.

Parent and Child -- Visitation Rights of Grandparents -- Constitutionality of Grandparent Visitation Statute as Applied 

4. Domestic Relations Law § 72 (1) was constitutionally applied to award petitioner grandmother reasonable visitation with her grandchild. Although the trial court, mindful of respondent father's parental prerogatives, employed the strong presumption that the father's wishes represented the child's best interests, as required by the statute, the grandmother surmounted the presumption. For over three years following the death of the child's mother, the grandmother was the child's surrogate, live-in mother. Following consideration of the circumstances bearing upon whether it was in the child's best interest for his relationship with the grandmother to continue--e.g., the reasonableness of the father's objections to the grandmother's access to the child, her caregiving skills and attitude toward the father, the law guardian's assessment, the child's wishes--the court granted visitation.

 

114 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Barton


No. 176


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


8 N.Y.3d 70; 861 N.E.2d 75; 828 N.Y.S.2d 260; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 3709; 2006 NY Slip Op 9499


November 14, 2006, Argued 
December 19, 2006, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order by the County Court (New York) that reversed a city court's declaration that Rochester, N.Y., City Code § 44-4(H) was unconstitutional; defendant claimed that § 44-4(H) was overbroad because it was not limited to panhandlers who acted aggressively or solicited motorists successfully or actually walked into a lane of stopped or moving traffic.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was ticketed for violating § 44-4(H) when he allegedly waded into traffic on a highway exit ramp, soliciting money from motorists. The appellate court found that § 44-4(H) served the governmental interests of eliminating a source of distraction for motorists and promoting the free and safe flow of traffic. Further, it was not a blanket ban; it left open ample alternative avenues to communicate any message of indigency or need through begging. It was narrowly tailored and content neutral. Therefore, § 44-4(H) was not overbroad.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Ordinance Addressing Aggressive Panhandling -- Challenge to Ordinance as Overbroad

1. Assuming that panhandling is speech or expressive conduct safeguarded by the First Amendment, entitled to protection tantamount to that afforded eleemosynary appeals by organized charities, defendant, who was charged with violating a municipal ordinance designed to address aggressive panhandling by prohibiting the solicitation of any occupant of a motor vehicle that is on a street or other public place, was entitled to challenge the ordinance as overbroad on behalf of others whose constitutionally-protected expression was potentially "chilled" by the provision's very existence, even though defendant's own conduct may have been unshielded by the First Amendment.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Ordinance Addressing Aggressive Panhandling

2. A municipal ordinance designed to address aggressive panhandling by prohibiting the solicitation of any occupant of a motor vehicle that is on a street or other public place is not unconstitutionally overbroad. Content-neutral regulations of time, place and manner of expression are enforceable if they are narrowly tailored to serve a significant government interest and leave open ample alternative channels of communication. The governmental interests served by the ordinance--to eliminate a source of distraction for motorists and thus promote the free and safe flow of traffic--are significant. Further, the ordinance is not a blanket ban and leaves open ample alternative avenues to communicate any message of indigency or need through begging. Because the ordinance focuses on specific conduct that the municipality has an interest in controlling in order to further a significant content-neutral government interest, it is narrowly tailored.

 

115 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


State of N.Y. ex rel. Harkavy v. Consilvio


No. 140


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


7 N.Y.3d 607; 859 N.E.2d 508; 825 N.Y.S.2d 702; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 3580; 2006 NY Slip Op 8639


October 11, 2006, Argued 
November 21, 2006, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Related proceeding at Frank v. State of New York, 21 Misc. 3d 387, 863 N.Y.S.2d 862, 2008 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 5278 (2008)
Related proceeding at Bailey v. Pataki, 2013 U.S. App. LEXIS 3200 (2d Cir. N.Y., Feb. 14, 2013)



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, without costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant prisoners appealed an order by the Appellate Division (New York) that, inter alia, reversed the trial court's order for conditional release from involuntary commitment to respondent psychiatric center.


OVERVIEW: The prisoners were nearing the end of their sentences for various felony sex offenses when they were examined by two physicians for the purpose of involuntary commitment. The physicians certified that each prisoner suffered from a mental illness and that, without inpatient psychiatric treatment, each posed a high risk of re-committing sexual crimes if released into the community. The prison superintendents completed applications for involuntary commitment on medical certification, pursuant to Mental Hygiene Law § 9.27. As the prisoners' prison terms expired, they were each transported to the psychiatric center, where each was further examined by a third physician who also found involuntary commitment necessary. The Court of Appeals found, inter alia, that because the prisoners were still inmates at the time the applications for involuntary commitment were initiated, they were subject to the provisions of Correction Law § 402 rather than Mental Hygiene Law § 9.27.


OUTCOME: The order was reversed, and the matter was remitted for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Incapacitated and Mentally Disabled Persons -- Involuntary Commitment -- Involuntary Transfer of Convicted Sex Offenders to State Psychiatric Facility at Conclusion of Prison Terms

In the absence of a clear legislative directive in regard to inmates nearing their release from incarceration, Correction Law § 402 is the appropriate method for evaluating an inmate for postrelease involuntary commitment to a mental facility. Once the sentence expires, however, any further proceedings concerning the continued need for hospitalization are governed by the Mental Hygiene Law. Section 402 prescribes precommitment procedural requirements, including court supervision, pretransfer notice and an opportunity to be heard within a reasonable period of time prior to the inmate's proposed release date. By providing that Correction Law § 402 applies to inmates "undergoing a sentence of imprisonment," the Legislature intended those procedures to be used to evaluate for commitment all imprisoned persons, regardless of when an inmate is scheduled to be released. Accordingly, the procedures set forth in Correction Law § 402, rather than Mental Hygiene Law article 9, should have been utilized in involuntarily committing certain sex offenders who, though nearing the end of their prison sentences, were still in the custody of the Department of Correctional Services when all the preliminary paperwork and examinations relating to commitment were completed. Moreover, prison superintendents are proper persons to execute the applications for involuntary commitment.

 

116 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Campaign for Fiscal Equity, Inc. v. State of New York


No. 136


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


8 N.Y.3d 14; 861 N.E.2d 50; 828 N.Y.S.2d 235; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 3566; 2006 NY Slip Op 8630


October 10, 2006, Argued 
November 20, 2006, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff organizations sued the State, seeking a declaration its public school financing system was unconstitutional. After remand from the State's high court, the trial court confirmed the recommendations of referees. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) reversed and directed the Governor and the Legislature to appropriate additional operating and capital funds. Both sides appealed.


OVERVIEW: The organizations claimed New York City public school students were not receiving a sound basic education as guaranteed by the N.Y. Constitution's Education Article. The high court ordered the State to ascertain the cost of providing such education and to ensure a system of accountability to measure the effectiveness of its reforms. The intermediate appellate court held that the trial court erred by relying on the referees' report. The high court agreed; the trial court should have determined whether the State's estimate of the costs was reasonable, and whether the State plan incorporated that expenditure in its proposed budget and would, if enacted, ensure a system of accountability. Instead, the trial court appointed referees to recommend which competing compliance proposal to adopt. As the Governor's proposed reform plan was not unreasonable or irrational, it was entitled to judicial deference. But the intermediate appellate court erred in ordering the State to appropriate more operating funds than the State's estimate required, and its order requiring a capital improvement plan was unnecessary in view of subsequent legislation appropriating funds for such improvements.


OUTCOME: The high court modified the order of the intermediate appellate court by reducing the amount of additional operating funds the State was required to provide to the amount the State had determined was necessary, instead of the amount the Governor had proposed to spend. It vacated the intermediate appellate court's order that the New York Governor and the Legislature implement a capital improvement plan. As modified, the judgment was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Schools -- State Aid to School Districts -- Remedy for Failure to Provide Sound Basic Education -- Compliance -- Appointment of Referees to Hear and Report

1. Supreme Court erred in appointing a panel of referees "to hear and report with recommendations" on whether the State had complied with the mandate of the Court of Appeals (Campaign for Fiscal Equity v State of New York, 100 NY2d 893, 801 NE2d 326, 769 NYS2d 106 [2003]) that children in New York City's public schools be provided with a sound basic education, as required by the Education Article of the New York Constitution. The State, not Supreme Court, was ordered by the Court of Appeals to ascertain the cost of a sound basic education in New York City. Supreme Court should not have endorsed an examination in which the cost of a sound basic education in New York was calculated anew, when the state budget plan had already reasonably calculated that cost. Supreme Court, accordingly, erred in confirming the report of the referees.

Schools -- State Aid to School Districts -- Remedy for Failure to Provide Sound Basic Education -- Compliance -- Reasonableness of State's Plan 

2. The Governor's proposed State Education Reform Plan reasonably concluded that additional annual operating funds in the amount of $ 1.93 billion, appropriately adjusted with reference to the latest version of the Geographic Cost of Education Index and inflation since 2004, would ensure children in New York City's public schools the opportunity for a sound basic education, as required by the Education Article of the New York Constitution (Campaign for Fiscal Equity v State of New York, 100 NY2d 893, 801 NE2d 326, 769 NYS2d 106 [2003]). Judicial deference to the Legislature's financing plan was justified by the Judiciary's limited access to the controlling economic and social facts and by respect for the doctrine of separation of powers. The use of a cost-effectiveness filter was rationally defensible, and the conclusion that New York City could attain minimal constitutional standards while spending less than the higher-spending group of successful school districts was not irrational. Further, the weightings utilized for children with special needs also had record support.

Schools -- State Aid to School Districts -- Remedy for Failure to Provide Sound Basic Education -- Compliance -- Capital Improvement Plan Unnecessary

3. In determining whether the State was in compliance with the Court of Appeals mandate (Campaign for Fiscal Equity v State of New York, 100 NY2d 893, 801 NE2d 326, 769 NYS2d 106 [2003]) that children in New York City's public schools be provided the opportunity for a sound basic education, as required by the Education Article of the New York Constitution, the Appellate Division's directive that the Governor and Legislature implement a capital improvement plan was unnecessary inasmuch as the Legislature has set forth a capital construction program designed to allow the State to remedy inadequacies in New York City schools facilities (L 2006, ch 58, part A; ch 61, part I).

Schools -- State Aid to School Districts -- Remedy for Failure to Provide Sound Basic Education -- Compliance -- Additional Accountability Mechanisms Unnecessary

4. In determining whether the State was in compliance with the Court of Appeals mandate (Campaign for Fiscal Equity v State of New York, 100 NY2d 893, 801 NE2d 326, 769 NYS2d 106 [2003]) that children in New York City's public schools be provided the opportunity for a sound basic education, as required by the Education Article of the New York Constitution, the Appellate Division properly struck Supreme Court's requirement of state costing-out studies every four years and requirement that the New York City Department of Education prepare a comprehensive "sound basic education" plan, to ensure accountability. Minimally adequate accountability mechanisms were already in place for the evaluation of New York schools.

 

117 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Matter of Nazareth Home of the Franciscan Sisters v. Novello


No. 124


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


7 N.Y.3d 538; 858 N.E.2d 1131; 825 N.Y.S.2d 426; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 3328; 2006 NY Slip Op 7600


September 14, 2006, Argued; 
October 24, 2006, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:
Reargument denied by Nazareth Home of the Franciscan Sisters v Novello, 7 NY3d 922, 860 NE2d 993, 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 3885, 827 NYS2d 691 (N.Y., Dec. 21, 2006)



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs. Certified question not answered upon the ground that it is unnecessary.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner nursing homes filed a proceeding under CPLR art. 78 against respondents, the Commissioner of Health of the State of New York, and others, to challenge the amount of Medicaid reimbursement that they received during 2004, claiming in part that the rates violated the mandate in Public Health Law § 2807(3). The Appellate Division (New York) affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the proceeding and the nursing homes appealed.


OVERVIEW: The nursing homes contended that the Medicaid reimbursement they received from the State was not close to the actual costs expended for the care of Medicaid-eligible residents. The nursing homes challenged the rate setting methods used by the New York State Department of Health (DOH). The trial court dismissed the nursing homes' petition and the dismissal was affirmed by the appellate division. Affirming, the court held that the DOH acted within the scope of their statutory authority conferred under Public Health Law § 2807-c(10) when they used the CPI as the trend factor for rate setting. The court noted that the DOH was directed to update the base year from 1983, but the update would be phased in over two years in the future. Based on the statutory guidelines, the court concluded that the Commissioner acted rationally in setting the 2004 Medicaid reimbursement rates. The DOH had advanced ample explanation for setting the rates prospectively based on the 1983 costs, as adjusted and trended forward. The rate-setting methodology used by the DOH did not result in an unconstitutional taking because the nursing homes had voluntarily agreed to participate in the price-regulated program.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate division.


HEADNOTES

Health -- Medicaid Reimbursement Rates 

1. Respondent Commissioner of Health acted rationally in setting 2004 Medicaid reimbursement rates for petitioner nursing homes. Pursuant to article 28 of the Public Health Law, the Department of Health (DOH) establishes Medicaid reimbursement rates for nursing homes using the Resource Utilization Group-II (RUG-II) case mix reimbursement methodology (see generally 10 NYCRR subpart 86-2), a cost containment device that encourages facilities to economize. A nursing home's reimbursement rate reflects its allowable costs in a base year, 1983, as adjusted to reflect patient conditions and care needs and regional differences in wages and fringe benefits, and trended forward to account for inflation. Within the parameters set by the Legislature, DOH has advanced ample explanation for setting rates prospectively based on 1983 costs, as adjusted in various ways and trended forward.

Health -- Medicaid Reimbursement Rates 

2. Respondent Commissioner of Health acted rationally in setting 2004 Medicaid reimbursement rates for petitioner nursing homes. Despite the fact that petitioners' Medicaid reimbursement rates covered only about 76% of their actual 2002 Medicaid costs, the reimbursement rates were reasonable and adequate as required by Public Health Law § 2807 (3). Section 2807 (3) does not require rates to cover every nursing home's actual costs. Rates are "reasonable and adequate" so long as they reimburse the necessary costs (i.e., "costs which must be incurred") of "efficiently and economically operated facilities" (EEOFs). The Department of Health (DOH) used the findings from its study of EEOFs to confirm that its overall rates complied with Public Health Law § 2807 (3), and thus had a rational basis for concluding that its 2004 reimbursement rates were reasonable and adequate. DOH's rate-setting methodology took each of the statutory factors in section 2807 (3) into account, and the Commissioner was entitled to great deference in her determination that the rates were reasonable under the statute.

Constitutional Law -- Taking of Property -- Medicaid Reimbursement Rates 

3. In setting Medicaid reimbursement rates for petitioner nursing homes, the Department of Health did not violate the Takings Clause of the Fifth and Fourteenth amendments of the United States Constitution. While petitioners contended that New York effectively required them to provide care to the indigent and then failed to reimburse them for their actual costs, thus forcing them to use their own assets to meet this public responsibility, where a service provider voluntarily participates in a price-regulated program or activity, there is no legal compulsion to provide service and thus there can be no taking.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws 

4. In setting Medicaid reimbursement rates for petitioners, nursing homes operating in western New York, the Department of Health (DOH) did not violate the Equal Protection clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and article I, § 11 of the New York Constitution. While petitioners claimed that DOH's rate-setting methodology favored nursing homes in the New York City area, they failed to show any intentional action by DOH to discriminate against facilities in western New York.

 

118 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Catholic Charities of Diocese of Albany v. Serio


No. 110


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


7 N.Y.3d 510; 859 N.E.2d 459; 825 N.Y.S.2d 653; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 3201; 2006 NY Slip Op 7517; 35 A.L.R.6th 735


September 6, 2006, Argued;  
October 19, 2006, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:
Reargument denied by Catholic Charities of Diocese of Albany v. Serio, 8 N.Y.3d 866, 863 N.E.2d 1019, 2007 N.Y. LEXIS 168, 831 N.Y.S.2d 767 (2007)
US Supreme Court certiorari denied by Catholic Charities v. Dinallo, 2007 U.S. LEXIS 10204 (U.S., Oct. 1, 2007)



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff faith-based social service organizations challenged the validity of legislation requiring health insurance policies that provided coverage for prescription drugs to include coverage for contraception. The Appellate Division (New York) affirmed a Supreme Court decision rejecting the organizations' challenge, granting summary judgment dismissing the complaint, and declaring the legislation valid. The organizations appealed.


OVERVIEW: At issue were provisions of the Women's Health and Wellness Act (WHWA) requiring that an employer health insurance contract which provided coverage for prescription drugs include coverage for the cost of contraceptive drugs or devices (Insurance Law § 3221(1)(16), § 4303(cc)). The organizations argued that the provisions requiring coverage of contraception violated the Free Exercise Clauses of the New York and U.S. Constitutions, and the Establishment Clause of the U.S. Constitution. The appeals court found that by the Smith test, the First Amendment had not been offended. Religious beliefs were not the target of the WHWA, and it was not that law's object to interfere with the organizations' exercise of religion. In interpreting N.Y. Const. art. I, § 3, the court found that the burden the WHWA placed on the organizations' religious practices was a serious one, but it did not literally compel them to purchase contraceptive coverage for their employees, in violation of their religious beliefs; it only required that policies that provided prescription drug coverage include coverage for contraceptives. The organizations were not required to purchase prescription drug coverage at all.


OUTCOME: The order of the Appellate Division was affirmed with costs.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Religion -- Mandated Insurance Coverage for Contraceptives -- "Religious Employer" Exception -- Free Exercise

1. The Women's Health and Wellness Act (WHWA) (L 2002, ch 554), which requires that an employer health insurance contract that provides coverage for prescription drugs include coverage for the cost of contraceptives, does not violate the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution to the extent that its exemption from contraceptive coverage for "religious employers" (see Insurance Law § 3221 [l] [16] [A]; § 4303 [cc] [1]) does not extend to plaintiffs, faith-based social service organizations. The burden on plaintiffs' religious exercise is the incidental result of a neutral law of general applicability. Religious beliefs were not the "target" of the WHWA, and it was not that law's "object" to interfere with plaintiffs' or anyone's exercise of religion. The object of the WHWA was to make broader health insurance coverage available to women, to improve women's health and to eliminate disparities between men and women in the cost of health care.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Religion -- Mandated Insurance Coverage for Contraceptives -- "Religious Employer" Exception -- Free Exercise -- Hybrid Rights Exception

2. The Women's Health and Wellness Act (WHWA) (L 2002, ch 554), which requires that an employer health insurance contract that provides coverage for prescription drugs include coverage for the cost of contraceptives, does not violate the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution to the extent that its exemption from contraceptive coverage for "religious employers" (see Insurance Law § 3221[l] [16] [A]; § 4303 [cc] [1]) does not extend to plaintiffs, faith-based social service organizations. The "hybrid rights" exception, pursuant to which the First Amendment has been held to bar application of a neutral, generally applicable law to religiously motivated action where there is a challenge to free exercise in conjunction with other constitutional protections, was inapplicable here. Plaintiffs' claim that the challenged legislation interfered with their rights of free speech and association was insubstantial. The legislation does not interfere with plaintiffs' right to communicate, or to refrain from communicating, any message they like; nor does it compel them to associate, or prohibit them from associating, with anyone. While it does burden plaintiffs' exercise of religion, that alone does not call the validity of a generally applicable and neutral statute into question.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Religion -- Mandated Insurance Coverage for Contraceptives -- "Religious Employer" Exception -- Free Exercise -- Doctrine of Church Autonomy

3. The Women's Health and Wellness Act (WHWA) (L 2002, ch 554), which requires that an employer health insurance contract that provides coverage for prescription drugs include coverage for the cost of contraceptives, does not violate the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution to the extent that its exemption from contraceptive coverage for "religious employers" (see Insurance Law § 3221 [l] [16] [A]; § 4303 [cc] [1]) does not extend to plaintiffs, faith-based social service organizations. The right of free exercise does not relieve an individual of the obligation to comply with a valid and neutral law of general applicability which, as here, does not target religious beliefs as such. The doctrine of church autonomy, which prevents states from interfering in matters of internal church governance or determining ecclesiastical questions, was not applicable here since church autonomy was not at issue. The Legislature has not attempted through the WHWA to lend its power to one or the other side in controversies over authority or dogma. The WHWA merely regulates one aspect of the relationships between plaintiffs and their employees.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Religion -- Mandated Insurance Coverage for Contraceptives -- "Religious Employer" Exception -- Free Exercise -- "Ministerial Exception"

4. The Women's Health and Wellness Act (WHWA) (L 2002, ch 554), which requires that an employer health insurance contract that provides coverage for prescription drugs include coverage for the cost of contraceptives, does not violate the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution to the extent that its exemption from contraceptive coverage for "religious employers" (see Insurance Law § 3221[l] [16] [A]; § 4303 [cc] [1]) does not extend to plaintiffs, faith-based social service organizations. The right of free exercise does not relieve an individual of the obligation to comply with a valid and neutral law of general applicability which, as here, does not target religious beliefs as such. The "ministerial exception," which exempts religious institutions from complying with title VII of the Civil Rights Act with respect to their ministers, was inapplicable. The existence of a limited exemption for ministers from antidiscrimination laws does not translate into an absolute right for a religiously-affiliated employer to structure all aspects of its relationship with its employees in conformity with church teachings.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Religion -- Mandated Insurance Coverage for Contraceptives -- "Religious Employer" Exception -- State Free Exercise Clause

5. The Women's Health and Wellness Act (WHWA) (L 2002, ch 554), which requires that an employer health insurance contract that provides coverage for prescription drugs include coverage for the cost of contraceptives, does not violate the Free Exercise Clause of the New York Constitution (art I, § 3) to the extent that its exemption from contraceptive coverage for "religious employers" (see Insurance Law § 3221[l] [16] [A]; § 4303 [cc] [1]) does not extend to plaintiffs, faith-based social service organizations. Where the State has not set out to burden religious exercise, but seeks only to advance, in a neutral way, a legitimate object of legislation, the New York Free Exercise Clause does not require the State to demonstrate a "compelling" interest in response to every claim by a religious believer to an exemption from the law. The WHWA does not literally compel plaintiffs to purchase contraceptive coverage for their employees, in violation of their religious beliefs. Moreover, when, as here, a religious organization chooses to hire employees who do not share its religious beliefs, it must, to some degree, be prepared to accept neutral regulations imposed to protect those employees' legitimate interests in doing what their own beliefs permit. Finally, in view of the State's substantial interest in fostering equality between the sexes and in providing women with better health care, the legislation at issue did not constitute an unreasonable interference with plaintiffs' exercise of their religion.

Constitutional Law -- Establishment of Religion -- Mandated Insurance Coverage for Contraceptives -- "Religious Employer" Exception

6. The Women's Health and Wellness Act (WHWA) (L 2002, ch 554), which requires that an employer health insurance contract that provides coverage for prescription drugs include coverage for the cost of contraceptives, does not violate the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution to the extent that its exemption from contraceptive coverage for "religious employers" (see Insurance Law § 3221 [l] [16] [A]; § 4303 [cc] [1]) does not extend to plaintiffs, faith-based social service organizations. Although in another case the Establishment Clause was violated by a statute designed to exempt from certain regulatory requirements all religious faiths except a disfavored one, here the WHWA was not designed to favor or disfavor any particular religion. Legislative accommodation to religious believers is a long-standing practice consistent with First Amendment principles. A legislative decision not to extend an accommodation to all kinds of religious organizations does not violate the Establishment Clause.

 

119 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Hernandez v. Robles


No. 86, No. 87, No. 88, No. 89:


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


7 N.Y.3d 338; 855 N.E.2d 1; 821 N.Y.S.2d 770; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 1836; 2006 NY Slip Op 5239


May 31, 2006, Argued; 
July 6, 2006, Decided



DISPOSITION: In each case: Order affirmed, without costs.



CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff same-sex couples sued defendants, city license-issuing authorities, the New York Department of Health, and New York State, seeking a declaration that restricting marriage to opposite-sex couples violated the New York Constitution. The Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court reversed a trial court decision granting the couples summary judgment and affirmed a decision granting defendants summary judgment. The couples appealed.


OVERVIEW: The couples claimed that by limiting marriage to opposite-sex couples, New York statutory law violated the New York Constitution's Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses (N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 6 and 11, respectively). The high court disagreed. As the parties acknowledged, N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law arts. 2 and 3 clearly limited marriage to opposite-sex couples. As to the due process challenge, the legislature could have rationally decided (1) that, for the welfare of children, it was more important to promote stability, and that same-sex relationships were more unstable than opposite-sex ones; and (2) that it was better for children to grow up with both a mother and a father. Even assuming, as the couples asserted, that there was no conclusive scientific evidence to support the latter contention, the legislature could rationally proceed on the common-sense premise that children did best with a mother and father in the home. As to the equal protection challenge, the restriction of marriage to opposite-sex couples was subject only to rational basis scrutiny, and the definition of marriage to exclude same-sex couples was not irrationally underinclusive or overinclusive.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the intermediate appellate court was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Marriage -- Same Sex Marriage -- Constitutionality of Marriage Laws

New York's Domestic Relations Law limits marriage to opposite-sex couples, and this limitation is valid under the due process and equal protection provisions of the New York Constitution. Although the right to marry is a fundamental right, deeply rooted in this Nation's history and tradition, the right to marry someone of the same sex is not such a fundamental right. By defining marriage as it has, the New York Legislature has not restricted the exercise of a fundamental right. Where no fundamental right is at issue, legislation is valid under the Due Process Clause if it is rationally related to legitimate government interests. Since there is a rational relationship between the government's interest in protecting the welfare of children and the limitation of marriage to opposite-sex couples, that limitation does not deprive same sex couples of due process of law. Further, under the applicable rational basis scrutiny, the restriction of marriage to opposite-sex couples does not violate the Equal Protection Clause. Permitting marriage by all opposite-sex couples does not create an irrationally overnarrow or overbroad classification. Whether same sex marriages should be recognized is a question for the Legislature.

 

120 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Matter of Shondel J. v. Mark D.


No. 46


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


7 N.Y.3d 320; 853 N.E.2d 610; 820 N.Y.S.2d 199; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 1837; 2006 NY Slip Op 5238


May 11, 2006, Argued; 
July 6, 2006, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent mother commenced a proceeding against appellant alleged father, seeking orders of filiation and support. DNA testing established that appellant was not the child's biological father. The family court entered an order of filiation and awarded child support retroactive to the date the mother filed the action. The Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court affirmed. Appellant sought further review.


OVERVIEW: The child was born in Guyana. Appellant executed an affidavit declaring he was "convinced" he was the child's father and accepting all paternal responsibilities, including child support. He signed a Guyana registry, stating that he was her father and authorizing the change of her last name to his. The family court found that appellant held himself out as the child's father and behaved in every way as if he was, and that the child justifiably relied on his representations, accepting him as her father and treating him as such. The high court noted that it was bound by these findings, as they were supported by the record. Under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 418(a), appellant was estopped from denying paternity because the child justifiably relied on his representation of paternity, to her detriment. Appellant's fraud defense failed, as the child was the party in whose favor estoppel was being applied and there could be no claim she was guilty of fraud. Moreover, there was every reason to believe that the mother also thought appellant was the biological father. That appellant renounced his paternity and terminated his relationship with the child did not preclude the application of estoppel.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Children Born out of Wedlock -- Paternity Proceeding -- Equitable Estoppel

1. Respondent, who represented himself as the father of a child born out of wedlock, was equitably estopped from denying paternity even though a blood genetic marker test later confirmed that he was not the child's biological father, and was required to pay child support, since the child justifiably relied on respondent's representation of paternity by forming a bond with him, to the child's detriment. Based upon established precedents, the affirmed findings of fact herein and the legislative recognition of paternity by estoppel, it was in the best interests of the child to equitably estop respondent from denying paternity. Pursuant to Family Court Act § 418 (a), Family Court may deny biological paternity testing based on "res judicata, equitable estoppel or the presumption of legitimacy of a child born to a married woman," if denial is in the best interests of the child. Although the child's biological paternity had been addressed before Family Court conducted its trial on the issue of estoppel, Family Court was authorized to decide the estoppel issue.

 

121 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Feingold


No. 96


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


7 N.Y.3d 288; 852 N.E.2d 1163; 819 N.Y.S.2d 691; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 1830; 2006 NY Slip Op 5233


June 7, 2006, Argued 
July 5, 2006, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Related proceeding at Lexington Ins. Co. v. Feingold, 2007 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4782 (2007)



DISPOSITION: Order modified by reducing defendant's conviction to reckless endangerment in the second degree and remitting to Supreme Court, New York County, for resentencing and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged an order of the Appellate Division (New York) that affirmed a trial court judgment that convicted him, after a nonjury trial, of reckless endangerment in the first degree pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 120.25. The trial court found that defendant's state of mind was not one of depraved indifference when he attempted suicide by sealing his apartment and turning on the gas, resulting in an explosion.


OVERVIEW: Defendant survived the explosion and no one else was injured, but neighboring apartments were damaged. The trial court found that defendant did not act out of a lack of regard for the lives of others but because of his depression and his focus upon himself. The appellate court reversed the intermediate appellate court's order, holding that depraved indifference to human life was a culpable mental state. Because the depraved indifference language was identical in § 120.25 and in N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25(2) pertaining to depraved indifference murder, the court analyzed caselaw pertaining to depraved indifference murder. It determined that People v. Register, 60 N.Y.2d 270 (1983), and People v. Sanchez, 98 N.Y.2d 373 (2002), which held that depraved indifference included no mens rea element beyond mere recklessness, were no longer to be followed. Although a factfinder could reasonably have inferred from defendant's actions that he had the requisite mental state, he could not be found to be depravedly indifferent when the trial court explicitly found that he was not. His conviction was therefore reduced to reckless endangerment in the second degree.


OUTCOME: The appellate court modified the trial court order by reducing defendant's conviction to reckless endangerment in the second degree and remitting the case to the trial court for resentencing. As so modified, the order was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Court of Appeals -- Preservation of Issue for Review 

1. In a prosecution for reckless endangerment, the People's contention that defendant's argument that depraved indifference is a mens rea was unpreserved because he did not plainly present it to the trial court was rejected. The trial judge's decision demonstrated that he specifically confronted and resolved this issue. Thus, preservation was adequate.

Crimes -- Murder -- Depraved Indifference Murder 

2. To the extent that People v Register (60 NY2d 270, 457 NE2d 704, 469 NYS2d 599 [1983]) and People v Sanchez (98 NY2d 373, 777 NE2d 204, 748 NYS2d 312 [2002]) hold that the term "depraved indifference" as used in the statute defining murder in the second degree (Penal Law § 125.25 [2]) refers not to the mens rea or the actus reus of the crime but to the factual setting in which the risk creating conduct must occur, they should no longer be followed.

Crimes -- Reckless Endangerment -- Depraved Indifference Reckless Endangerment 

3. Defendant, who engaged in conduct that created the obvious danger of a major gas explosion in an occupied apartment building, was improperly found guilty of reckless endangerment in the first degree pursuant to Penal Law § 120.25 where Supreme Court found, in defendant's nonjury trial, that his state of mind was not one of depraved indifference. Section 120.25 provides that a person violates the statute "when, under circumstances evincing a depraved indifference to human life, he recklessly engages in conduct which creates a grave risk of death to another person." Depraved indifference to human life, which is best understood as an utter disregard for the value of human life, is a culpable mental state. The factfinder here specifically determined that defendant did not act with depraved indifference.

 

122 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Garson


No. 28


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


6 N.Y.3d 604; 848 N.E.2d 1264; 815 N.Y.S.2d 887; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 616; 2006 NY Slip Op 2409


February 7, 2006, Argued  
March 30, 2006, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected November 4, 2011.
Related proceeding at Matter of Garson, 47 A.D.3d 148, 844 N.Y.S.2d 894, 2007 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11883 (N.Y. App. Div. 2d Dep't, 2007)
Subsequent appeal at People v. Garson, 69 A.D.3d 650, 892 N.Y.S.2d 511, 2010 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 88 (N.Y. App. Div. 2d Dep't, Jan. 5, 2010)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People appealed the judgment of the Appellate Division (New York) which affirmed the dismissal of six counts charging defendant judge with receiving reward for official misconduct in the second degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 200.25. The issue was whether evidence that a judge violated the Rules Governing Judicial Conduct, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, part 100, was legally sufficient to support six counts under N.Y. Penal Law § 200.25.


OVERVIEW: The People presented evidence to a grand jury that defendant engaged in a course of conduct where on numerous occasions he violated his duty as a public servant for which he received benefits of cash and other gratuities. The People presented evidence that defendant and an attorney developed a relationship wherein the attorney gave defendant gifts expecting and receiving preferential treatment in return. The Court of Appeals held that it was reasonable for the grand jury to find that defendant violated his explicit duty not to initiate, permit, or consider ex parte communications concerning a pending proceeding as prohibited by N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 100.3(B)(6). The evidence supported an inference that defendant, in referring potential clients to the client, lent the prestige of his judicial office for the sake of advancing private interests. The evidence was legally sufficient, in accordance with N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 70.10, and supported every element of counts one through six of the indictment charging defendant with violating his duties as a public servant and then accepting benefits in exchange for those violations in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 200.25.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the lower appellate court was modified to reinstate the six counts.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Indictment -- Sufficiency of Evidence before Grand Jury -- Receiving Reward for Official Misconduct

Evidence that a judge accepted a benefit for violation of his duty as a public servant, as defined by the Rules of Judicial Conduct (22 NYCRR part 100 [Rules]), was legally sufficient to support six counts of receiving reward for official misconduct in the second degree (Penal Law § 200.25). The Rules set forth a constitutionally mandated duty upon the judiciary and, when combined with the additional factor of receiving a reward, a violation of that duty may serve as a basis for prosecution under Penal Law § 200.25. Here, the People set forth evidence that defendant, a Justice of the Supreme Court, engaged in substantive ex parte conversations with an attorney appearing in a case pending before him, in violation of the rule that prohibits a judge from engaging in unauthorized ex parte communications (22 NYCRR 100.3 [B] [6]). There was also evidence before the grand jury that defendant accepted "referral fees" from a lawyer in violation of the rule that prohibits a judge from lending "the prestige of judicial office to advance the private interests of the judge or others" (22 NYCRR 100.2 [C]).

 

123 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Boyer


No. 36


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


6 N.Y.3d 427; 846 N.E.2d 461; 813 N.Y.S.2d 31; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 570; 2006 NY Slip Op 2290


February 9, 2006, Argued  
March 28, 2006, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, defendant's motion to preclude identification testimony granted and a new trial ordered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People made voluntary disclosures to defendant, but failed to mention a pretrial identification and served no N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 710.30(1)(b) notice. Defendant's motion to preclude any identification testimony was denied. Defendant's conviction of attempted burglary was affirmed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York) (intermediate court). Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that a police officer was improperly allowed to testify to his identifications of defendant as no § 710.30(1)(b) notice was given. The state's highest court refused to extend the confirmatory identification exception from Wharton to situations where a police officer's initial encounter with a suspect and subsequent identification of that suspect were temporally related, such that the two might be considered part of a single police procedure. To do so would run afoul of § 710.30 and would eliminate the protections offered by a Wade hearing even when the initial police viewing was fleeting, unreliable, and susceptible of misidentification. The officer viewed defendant at night, while defendant stopped for a few seconds on a fire escape, some 40-to-50 feet above the ground. This was in stark contrast to the face-to-face viewing in Wharton. Moreover, the officer was not placed on the scene specifically to make an identification and was not focused on identifying the suspect to a backup team. Whether the identification resulted from any impropriety was the very determination requiring a Wade hearing. The People were required to serve a § 710.30(1)(b) notice.


OUTCOME: The order of the intermediate court was reversed. Defendant's motion to preclude identification testimony was granted and a new trial was ordered.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Disclosure -- Notice of Intention to Offer Evidence -- Confirmatory Identification by Police Officer -- Temporally Related Initial Encounter and Subsequent Identification

The "confirmatory identification" exception to the notice and hearing requirements of CPL 710.30 should not be extended to situations where a police officer's initial encounter with a suspect and subsequent identification of that suspect are temporally related, such that the two might be considered part of a single police procedure. Such an exception would eliminate the protections offered by a Wade hearing even when the initial police viewing--albeit part of a single police procedure--was fleeting, unreliable and susceptible of misidentification. Here, it could not be concluded that the circumstances of the officer's initial viewing--at night, while defendant stopped for a few seconds on a fire escape some 40 to 50 feet above the ground--were such that, as a matter of law, the subsequent identification could not have been the product of undue suggestiveness. Thus, the officer's out-of-court and in-court identifications should have been precluded due to the lack of CPL 710.30 notice.

 

124 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



CWM Chem. Servs., L.L.C. v. Roth


No. 3


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


6 N.Y.3d 410; 846 N.E.2d 448; 813 N.Y.S.2d 18; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 515; 2006 NY Slip Op 2233; 62 ERC (BNA) 1825; 36 ELR 20060


February 14, 2006, Argued  
March 23, 2006, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order, insofar as appealed from, modified, without costs, by granting judgment declaring in accordance with the opinion herein and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) entered an order that agreed with the trial court that a disposal tax included in a state law discriminated against interstate commerce in violation of the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution; however, it also found that the remedy was to eliminate in-state exemptions on cleanup and process wastes from the disposal tax. Plaintiff taxpayer appealed.


OVERVIEW: The trial court and the appellate division held, and the State did not contest, that the State Superfund's disposal tax, a part of the statutory financing scheme for the cleanup of inactive hazardous waste disposal sites in New York State, unlawfully discriminated against interstate commerce and, thus, violated the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution. The taxpayer, in appealing to the instant court, asserted that the appellate division's remedy to address that constitutional infirmity of eliminating in-state exemptions on cleanup and process wastes from the disposal tax altogether was improper. Rather, the taxpayer asserted that the disposal tax should be severed from those special assessments. The instant court agreed. It found that the problem was how to cure the constitutional infirmity while remaining true to the legislature's intent. It then concluded that striking N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0923(2)'s disposal tax in its entirety was the option that best furthered the multiple legislative purposes of the special assessments and declared that the disposal tax was so stricken.


OUTCOME: The instant court granted judgment declaring that the disposal tax was stricken in its entirety.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Commerce Clause -- Special Assessments on Disposal of Hazardous Wastes

1. The disposal tax imposed by the State's Hazardous Waste Remedial Fund (ECL 27-0923 [2]) as part of the statutory financing scheme for the cleanup of inactive hazardous waste disposal sites in New York State unlawfully discriminated against interstate commerce in violation of the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution and was stricken in its entirety pursuant to the applicable severability clause (L 1985, ch 38, § 19). ECL 27-0923 (2) (d) was facially discriminatory in violation of the Commerce Clause insofar as it exempted from taxation the disposal of hazardous waste generated in New York State which had been taxed pursuant to ECL 27-0923 (1), without exempting from taxation the disposal of hazardous waste generated in another state which had been taxed pursuant to any other state's similar generation tax. The best available option to cure the constitutional infirmity was to sever the disposal tax from the special assessments imposed upon the generation and disposal of hazardous waste. Such an approach preserved the generator tax as a revenue stream and did not significantly curtail revenues for funding hazardous waste cleanups.

Taxation -- Tax Refund

2. Plaintiff, the owner and operator of a hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility, which successfully challenged the disposal tax imposed by the State's Hazardous Waste Remedial Fund (ECL 27-0923 [2]), was required to pursue administratively (see Tax Law art 27) its claim for a refund. A state has great flexibility in responding to a determination that it has levied an impermissibly discriminatory tax, and Supreme Court was not mandated to consider plaintiff's request for a refund in plaintiff's declaratory judgment action.

 

125 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Baumann & Sons Buses, Inc.


No. 42


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


6 N.Y.3d 404; 846 N.E.2d 457; 813 N.Y.S.2d 27; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 516; 2006 NY Slip Op 2234


February 15, 2006, Argued  
March 23, 2006, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  
Reargument denied by People v Baumann & Sons Buses, Inc., 7 N.Y.3d 742, 853 N.E.2d 247, 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 1463, 819 N.Y.S.2d 876 (N.Y., June 8, 2006)



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed on the ground that the reversal by the Appellate Term was not "on the law alone or upon the law and such facts which, but for the determination of law, would not have led to reversal" (CPL 450.90 [2] [a]).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People of the State of New York appealed an order from the Appellate Term (New York), which reversed a conviction against defendant, a corporate bus company, and dismissed the information against it. Defendant had been convicted of violating Islip, N.Y., Code § 35-3(D).


OVERVIEW: After a nonjury trial, the trial court found that defendant had continuously operated approximately 50 bus engines for several hours, which engine noise was audible beyond the real property where it originated and thereby disturbed a complainant. On appeal, the conviction was reversed. The appellate term held that Islip, N.Y., Code § 35-3(D) was an anti-noise ordinance that was designed to prevent noises constituting a public nuisance and a wrong against the community, rather than involving an individual concern. Accordingly, the appellate term found that the information was defective because it did not allege that there was a public nuisance from the noise. On further review, the court noted that the appellate term's decision was based on an unpreserved error, and as such, it was deemed to have been rendered in the interest of justice under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.15. The information was sufficient to assert a charge against defendant based on the clear language of the town ordinance. Further, the constitutionality of the ordinance was not raised. Accordingly, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.05(2), the issue was not properly preserved for further review by the court.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the appeal.


HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Court of Appeals -- Preservation of Issue for Review -- Reversal on Basis of Unpreserved Error

An intermediate appellate court's reversal of a conviction on the basis of an unpreserved error, and therefore as a matter of discretion in the interest of justice, is not appealable to the Court of Appeals. Accordingly, because the validity of an ordinance prohibiting unreasonable engine noise was not challenged before the trial court, the issue of whether an anti-noise statute requires an element of public nuisance, as concluded by the Appellate Term in reversing defendant's conviction under the ordinance, was unpreserved for review by the Court of Appeals (see CPL 470.05 [2]). Although a claim that an accusatory instrument is facially insufficient presents a jurisdictional question exempt from the requirement of preservation, that was not the error alleged in this case, where the information contained allegations sufficient to establish, if true, every element of the offense as defined in the ordinance. Inasmuch as a challenge to the constitutionality of a statute must be preserved, the Court of Appeals will not consider a constitutional claim in the guise of an argument that the accusatory instrument was facially insufficient.

 

126 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Matter of Council of City of N.Y. v. Bloomberg


No. 6


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


6 N.Y.3d 380; 846 N.E.2d 433; 813 N.Y.S.2d 3; 2006 N.Y. LEXIS 149; 2006 NY Slip Op 1111; 36 Employee Benefits Cas. (BNA) 2732


January 4, 2006, Argued  
February 14, 2006, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city council challenged a decision from the Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York), which dismissed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding filed against respondents, a mayor and a city, to compel enforcement of the New York City Equal Benefits Law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 6-126.


OVERVIEW: The Equal Benefits Law prohibited the city from entering into contracts with any person that failed to provide its employees' domestic partners with equal benefits. The mayor refused to enforce the law, and the city council filed a proceeding to compel enforcement. The supreme court granted the petition, but the appellate division concluded that the law was preempted by state and federal law. The council then sought review. In affirming the appellate division, the reviewing court determined that it was permitted to rule on the validity of the Equal Benefits Law because it was raised as a defense in the case. Next, the Equal Benefits Law was preempted by N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 103(1) because it was plainly in tension with the requirement that the city give contracts to the lowest bidder. Under N.Y. Const. art. 9, § 2c(ii) and N.Y. Gen. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(1)(ii), the city was not allowed to adopt laws of this nature where the legislature restricted such. The Equal Benefits Law was also preempted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, 29 U.S.C.S. § 1001 et seq., because it prescribed the terms of benefit plans. Finally, the market participant exception did not apply.


OUTCOME: The decision was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Proceeding against Body or Officer -- Mandamus

1. In a CPLR article 78 proceeding against the Mayor of the City of New York and the City of New York seeking a judgment requiring them to implement and enforce New York City's Equal Benefits Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 6-126), the Mayor was entitled to raise the invalidity of the Equal Benefits Law as a defense, notwithstanding that an article 78 proceeding does not lie to challenge a legislative act. A petitioner who is challenging the validity of legislation may not use an article 78 proceeding for that purpose. However, an officer against whom an article 78 proceeding for a writ of mandamus is brought may defend on the ground that the legislation he or she has been asked to enforce is invalid.

Local Laws -- Preemption by State -- Equal Benefits Law

2. New York City's Equal Benefits Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 6-126), which prohibits the City from entering into contracts in excess of $ 100,000 with a contractor that does not provide to its employees' domestic partners employment benefits equal to those provided to spouses, conflicts with, and is preempted by, General Municipal Law § 103. Under section 103, contracts for public work over $ 20,000 and purchase contracts over $ 10,000 are to be awarded "to the lowest responsible bidder." The Equal Benefits Law violates this requirement by excluding from public contracting any "responsible bidder" that does not provide equal benefits to domestic partners and spouses. Further, the grant of power to municipalities to legislate concerning certain subjects, including some that affect persons employed by any contractor or subcontractor performing work, labor or services for the municipality (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [c] [ii] [9]; Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [ii] [a] [10]), is expressly made subject to contrary state legislation such as General Municipal Law § 103.

Statutes -- Federal Preemption -- Equal Benefits Law

3. New York City's Equal Benefits Law (Administrative Code of City of NY § 6-126), which prohibits the City from entering into contracts in excess of $ 100,000 with a contractor that does not provide to its employees' domestic partners employment benefits equal to those provided to spouses, is preempted by the federal Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (29 U.S.C. § 1001 et seq. [ERISA]), except to the extent that it governs benefits that are outside ERISA's scope. ERISA governs employee benefit plans and their fiduciaries (see 29 U.S.C. § 1001 [b]), and supersedes state laws insofar as they relate to any employee benefit plan of the kind governed by ERISA (29 U.S.C. § 1144 [a]). The Equal Benefits Law seemingly seeks to do exactly what ERISA prohibits--to prescribe the terms of benefit plans. Moreover, the market participant exception to federal preemption, which has been recognized where the State acts as a market participant with no interest in setting policy, is inapplicable to the Equal Benefits Law because, in enacting the law, the Council of the City of New York was setting policy.

 

127 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



For the People Theatres of N.Y., Inc. v. City of New York


No. 181


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


6 N.Y.3d 63; 843 N.E.2d 1121; 810 N.Y.S.2d 381; 2005 N.Y. LEXIS 3349; 2005 NY Slip Op 9575


November 17, 2005, Argued  
December 15, 2005, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: On remand at For the People Theatres of NY, Inc. v. City of New York, 2010 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 615 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., Mar. 29, 2010)



DISPOSITION: Order modified, without costs, by denying defendants' cross motions for summary judgment and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division, granted plaintiff adult use business owners leave to appeal its decision granting cross-motions by defendants, a city and its officials, in the owners' declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of the definition of "adult use" in New York City, N.Y., Zoning Reg. § 12.10, as amended in 2001, and certified a question as to the correctness of its ruling.


OVERVIEW: The zoning ordinance as enacted in 1995 allowed some latitude to mixed-use businesses, and was applied less restrictively to business owners who devoted less than 40 percent of their floor space to adult activities. The ordinance had been upheld as not violative of the First Amendment or N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8. Convinced that the 60/40 formula was resulting in sham compliance, the city amended the ordinance in 2001, to broaden its definition of adult establishment use. The owners challenged the amended ordinance, arguing that they had expended considerable time and money to comply with the 1995 ordinance, only to find themselves potentially in violation of the amended law. The court noted that it generally deferred to legislative determinations where based on recognized studies linking adult uses and neighborhood deterioration, but held that in response to the city's showing, the owners had nonetheless raised triable issues as to whether their compliance was in fact a sham. Therefore, summary judgment should not have been granted to the city.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order for the most part, but modified it to deny the grant of summary judgment in favor of the city and its officials. It remitted the matter to the trial court for further proceedings.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Zoning Amendments Restricting Adult Establishments

A question of fact was presented as to whether New York City's adult use zoning regulations, as amended in 2001 to limit superficial compliance unanticipated when the 1995 Ordinance regulating adult businesses was initially enacted, served a public purpose other than censorship and therefore did not infringe upon plaintiffs' rights of free speech under the federal and state constitutions. Because the reasonable discretion accorded most local legislative actions extends to adult use zoning, in enacting the 2001 amendments, the City was entitled to rely principally on the same evidence of negative secondary effects that supported the original ordinance. The City was not required, however, to relitigate the secondary effects of adult uses, or to produce empirical studies connecting businesses with the required 60/40 allocation to adverse secondary effects. There was a triable question of fact as to whether 60/40 businesses were so transformed in character that they no longer resembled the kinds of adult uses found to create negative secondary effects or whether these businesses' technical compliance with the 60/40 formula was merely a sham.

 

128 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Green


No. 153


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


5 N.Y.3d 538; 841 N.E.2d 289; 807 N.Y.S.2d 321; 2005 N.Y. LEXIS 3220; 2005 NY Slip Op 8845


October 17, 2005, Argued  
November 21, 2005, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the affirmation by the Appellate Division (New York) of his conviction for robbery. The issue was whether defendant, who claimed that he believed in good faith that the property was his, was entitled to a "claim-of-right" jury instruction in a prosecution for robbery of a compact disc player.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and two acquaintances approached the victim, and defendant snatched a compact disc player out of the victim's hand. Defendant walked away and allegedly began listening to a CD in the disc player. One of defendant's acquaintances then told the victim to give him his money and then repeatedly punched the victim. Defendant testified that shortly before taking the disc player from the victim, he had borrowed a friend's compact disc player which was stolen from him by a group of six or seven members of a gang. According to defendant, he first approached the victim because the victim was holding a disc player and resembled one of the individuals who had taken the disc player from him. Defendant's requested to charge the jury on the "claim-of-right" defense under N.Y. Penal Law § 155.15(1) was denied. The appellate court held the trial court properly refused to charge the jury on the "claim of right" defense since such a defense was only available in a larceny prosecution, not in a robbery prosecution, as public policy considerations militated against encouraging the use of forcible self-help to recover property.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Instructions -- Claim of Right Instruction Not Available in Robbery Prosecution

1. In the prosecution of defendant for robbery of a compact disc player, defendant was not entitled to a "claim-of-right" jury instruction even though he in good faith believed that the disc player was his. The Legislature has limited the availability of the statutory claim-of-right defense to prosecutions for larceny by trespass or embezzlement (see Penal Law § 155.15 [1]), and public policy considerations militate against encouraging the use of forcible self-help to recover property. Although a good-faith but mistaken claim of right might defeat a robbery prosecution, and a defendant is free to make that argument to the jury, that defendant is not entitled to such an instruction by the court, which would aid the defendant by underscoring one aspect of the proof, or lack of proof.

Crimes -- Appeal -- Matters Reviewable--Refusal to Charge Remote Lesser Included Offense

2. Defendant, having been convicted of second-degree robbery after the court had also charged third-degree robbery as a lesser included offense, was foreclosed from challenging the trial court's refusal to charge the more remote lesser included offense of petit larceny.

 

129 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Red Hook/Gowanus Chamber of Commerce v. N.Y. City Bd. of Stds. & Appeals


No. 168


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


5 N.Y.3d 452; 839 N.E.2d 878; 805 N.Y.S.2d 525; 2005 N.Y. LEXIS 2700; 2005 NY Slip Op 7831


September 8, 2005, Argued;  
October 25, 2005, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  
On remand at, Motions ruled upon by Matter of Red Hook/Gowanus Chamber of Commerce v. New York City Bd. of Stds. & Appeals, 11 Misc. 3d 1081A, 816 N.Y.S.2d 700, 2006 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 836 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., Apr. 18, 2006)



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and matter remitted to Supreme Court, Kings County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant organization filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 action against appellees, the city board of standards and appeals (BSA) and the city, to oppose the BSA's decision to grant a landowner a hardship variance. The trial court granted the organization's motion to amend its petition to add the landowner as a party, and denied the city's motion to dismiss. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York) reversed. The organization appealed.


OVERVIEW: Under New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 25-207(a), the organization had 30 days in which to challenge the decision by the BSA. On the last day, the organization filed its petition naming only the BSA and the city as defendants. The organization omitted the landowner from the suit. The city moved to dismiss the petition because the organization had failed to name a necessary party within the statute of limitations period. However, the trial court permitted the organization to amend its petition to add the landowner as a defendant. The intermediate appellate court found that the organization's failure to adequately explain why it did not include the landowner as a defendant in a timely manner precluded it under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1001(b) from proceeding in the landowner's absence. The Court of Appeals of New York found that the landowner was a necessary party, and should have been joined in the proceeding at its inception. Further, the trial court erred in treating the landowner as united in interest with the city. However, the discretionary factors under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1001(b) should have been addressed to determine whether the action could proceed in the landowner's absence.


OUTCOME: The order of the intermediate appellate court was reversed, with costs, and the matter was remitted to the trial court, for further proceedings to address the discretionary factors under a statute.



HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions -- Defendants United in Interest

1. In a proceeding to review a determination granting respondent landowner's application for a use variance, Supreme Court erred in treating the landowner as united in interest with respondent City when it denied the City's motion to dismiss the petition on the ground that petitioner had failed to name a necessary party, the landowner, within the statute of limitations period. The landowner was a necessary party and should have been joined in the proceeding at its inception. Further, the interest of the landowner and the City in maintaining the status of the variance did not create a unity of interest such that an action against the landowner related back to the filing date of the petition. The status of the landowner's property represented a potential loss of millions of dollars, while the City was necessarily concerned with regulatory and administrative consequences. Such divergent long-term interests could not be guaranteed to protect the landowner from future prejudice in the case.

Parties -- Necessary Parties

2. The Appellate Division erred in dismissing a proceeding to review a determination granting respondent landowner's application for a use variance, based on the fact that petitioner had offered no adequate explanation for its failure to name the landowner, a necessary party, as a respondent prior to the expiration of the statute of limitations, where the trial court, having granted petitioner's motion to amend the petition and join the landowner, did not address the discretionary factors in CPLR 1001 (b). When, as here, a necessary party can be joined only by consent or appearance, a court has discretion to determine whether to allow the action to proceed and must consider the five factors enumerated in CPLR 1001 (b). One of those factors--"whether and by whom prejudice might have been avoided" (CPLR 1001 [b] [3])--includes inquiry into why a litigant failed to name a necessary party prior to the expiration of the statute of limitations. While an unexplained expired statute of limitations is very strong indication that an action should be dismissed, it is a factor in, not preclusion of, the requisite analysis. The Appellate Division gave no indication that it had considered all of the CPLR 1001 (b) factors, and it is not for the Court of Appeals in the first instance to weigh the factors. Accordingly, the matter was remitted to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

130 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Shulman


No. 130


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


6 N.Y.3d 1; 843 N.E.2d 125; 809 N.Y.S.2d 485; 2005 N.Y. LEXIS 2703; 2005 NY Slip Op 7827


September 6, 2005, Argued  
October 25, 2005, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  
US Supreme Court certiorari denied by Shulman v. New York, 126 S. Ct. 1623, 164 L. Ed. 2d 339, 2006 U.S. LEXIS 2562 (U.S., Mar. 27, 2006)



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified by vacating the sentence imposed upon the conviction of murder in the first degree and remitting to County Court, Suffolk County, for resentencing in accordance with CPL 470.30 (5) (c) and Penal Law §§ 60.06 and 70.00(5) and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant challenged a judgment of the Suffolk County Court (New York), convicting him of first-degree murder under N.Y. Penal Law § 125.27(1)(a)(xi) and sentencing him to death.


OVERVIEW: Appellant was convicted of beating three female victims to death with a blunt object and then dismembering their bodies to evade their identification. On appeal, the court held that the trial court did not err by rejecting appellant's challenge for cause under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.20(1)(b) a juror who worked as a corrections officers at a prison because the trial court took into consideration all the answers the juror provided and his willingness to put aside whatever his personal opinions were and take the law as the trial court gave it to him. The trial court did not err by rejecting appellant's challenge to a second juror based on her answers of "I think I can" and that she would "try" when responding to questions about her ability to put her opinion aside because her other answers dispelled any doubt about her ability to deliberate impartially. The trial court did not err by rejecting appellant's request to instruct the jurors to disregard his postmortem conduct when determining whether he committed first-degree "similar fashion" murder because the court determined that there was no reason to hold that similarity had to be shown by the killing act alone.


OUTCOME: Appellant's convictions were affirmed. Appellant's death sentence was vacated and the case was remanded for resentencing.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Arrest -- Probable Cause -- Capital Murder 

1. In the prosecution of defendant for capital murder, the evidence offered by the People at the suppression hearing demonstrated prima facie that it was more probable than not that defendant murdered the three women whose deaths were being investigated and thus there was probable cause for his arrest. One of the victims was last seen alive in defendant's company, two of the victims were both killed by being severely beaten about the face and head and were disposed of as trash, minus hands or limbs, suggesting a common killer, and the trace evidence associated with the bodies of two of the victims was also present in the security booth where defendant worked. Defendant did not work as scheduled on the day that one victim's body was discovered, or on the day that another victim was last seen alive. Moreover, defendant was known to entertain prostitutes, including one of the victims, in his room, and another prostitute had seen a work bench or table with tools, including a hacksaw and a hammer, on a porch adjacent to his room.
