In the context of an arrest for driving while intoxicated, the risk of erroneous deprivation of a vehicle seized as an instrumentality of the crime is heightened when the driver is not the owner or sole user of the seized vehicle.

 

162 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Twin Lakes Dev. Corp. v. Town of Monroe


No. 135


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


1 N.Y.3d 98; 801 N.E.2d 821; 769 N.Y.S.2d 445; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 3949



November 20, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  
US Supreme Court certiorari denied by Twin Lakes Dev. Corp. v. Monroe, 541 U.S. 974, 158 L. Ed. 2d 469, 124 S. Ct. 1883, 2004 U.S. LEXIS 2589 (U.S., Apr. 5, 2004)



DISPOSITION: Order of the Appellate Division affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff real estate developer sought to invalidate two fee provisions established by defendant town that required residential subdivision permit applicants to pay fees in lieu of dedicating a portion of their property for recreational purposes and to reimburse the town for consulting costs related to processing. The trial court granted summary judgment to the town and the appellate court (New York) affirmed. At issue was N.Y. Town Law § 277(4).


OVERVIEW: After paying consulting costs and the town's fixed, per-lot recreation fee in lieu of dedicating a portion of property for recreational purposes "under protest," the developer claimed that the requirements equated to a taking and violated due process. On appeal, the court upheld the fee provisions. The developer failed to establish that the per-lot fee constituted a taking because when enacting the current fees, the town made explicit findings that the demand for recreational facilities exceeded existing resources and that continued subdivision development, paired with upward-spiraling land costs, would have exacerbated the problem. Additionally, the statute authorizing the town to impose recreation fees mandated that fees collected in lieu of parkland set-asides were to be deposited into a trust fund to be used strictly for recreational purposes. Thus, the essential nexus between the stated purpose of the condition and the fee per N.Y. Town Law § 277(4)(c) was met. The fee was roughly proportional to the impact the development would have had on the town's recreational needs. As to the consulting fees, the developer was only required to reimburse for fees actually spent.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate court, with costs.



HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Application for Subdivision Approval -- Constitutionality of Fee in Lieu of Parkland Dedication

1. The requirement of Monroe Town Code § 26B-2 (A) (7) that certain subdivision applicants pay a set fee per subdivision lot in lieu of dedicating a portion of their property for recreational purposes did not equate to an unconstitutional taking of property without just compensation (see US Const 5th Amend) with respect to plaintiff's residential subdivision project. When enacting the current fees, defendant Town made explicit findings that the demand for recreational facilities exceeded existing resources and that continued subdivision development, paired with the increasing cost of land, would exacerbate the problem. The fees were required to be deposited into a trust fund used strictly for recreational purposes (see Town Law § 277 [4] [c]). An essential nexus existed between the stated purpose of the condition and the fee. Moreover, defendant's findings regarding plaintiff's subdivision application reflected an individualized consideration of the proposed subdivision's impact, and satisfied Town Law § 277 (4) (c) requirements for determining whether parkland dedication is appropriate.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Application for Subdivision Approval -- Constitutionality of Fee in Lieu of Parkland Dedication

2. Plaintiff developer's due process rights were not violated by the imposition of per-lot recreation fees in connection with its residential subdivision project under Monroe Town Code § 26B-2 (A) (7) without a hearing to review the reasonableness of the fee amount. The Town Code provision requires that certain subdivision applicants pay a set fee per subdivision lot in lieu of dedicating a portion of their property for recreational purposes. The per-lot fee was neither a special assessment nor a tax, but rather was generally applicable to any property owner seeking to divide his or her property. Defendant adopted the local law through a legislative process, and revisited the fee schedule on a yearly basis, at which time concerned property owners could voice objections.

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Application for Subdivision Approval -- Constitutionality of Consultant Fee Payment Requirement

3. The requirement of Monroe Town Code § 26B-2 (A) (11) (a) that certain subdivision applicants pay the consulting fees incurred by defendant Town in processing their residential subdivision applications did not violate due process in connection with plaintiff developer's application on the ground that no opportunity existed to challenge the reasonableness of the fees. Under the Town Code provision, applicants are required to reimburse defendant only for fees actually expended. The Code provision expressly limits the fees to those that are reasonable, and defendant interprets the fees as subject to the audit provisions of Town Law §§ 118 and 119. Moreover, plaintiff did not allege that the fees were, in fact, unreasonable.

 

163 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Med. Soc'y v. Serio


No. 107


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 854; 800 N.E.2d 728; 768 N.Y.S.2d 423; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 3314


September 10, 2003, Argued  
October 21, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected December 16, 2003.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, a medical society and others (the challengers), appealed from an affirmance, by the Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York), of a trial court decision upholding the validity of revisions to no-fault insurance regulations, codified at N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 11, pt. 65, promulgated by respondents, New York State's Superintendent of Insurance and his agency.


OVERVIEW: New York's Insurance Law established a no-fault system, and authorized the promulgation of regulations to effect a system that would ensure prompt compensation for losses, reduce burdens on courts, and result in lowered insurance premiums. When the agency determined that rampant insurance fraud was driving up premiums, the Superintendent revised certain regulations, changing certain time limits for submitting expense claims and requiring the insurance companies themselves to develop standards for dealing with late-filed claims to assure fairness to injured persons. The high court held that all these changes fell within the constitutional and statutory delegations of authority to the Superintendent, who was entitled to fill in the gaps left blank by the legislature, and that they had been properly adopted. The challengers also argued that the standards developed by companies constituted administrative rules in themselves, that should have been adopted in accordance with New York's State Administrative Procedure Act. The high court found that the standards in question were simply guidelines applied on a case-by-case basis, and were not true rules.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the intermediate appellate court's decision.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law -- Rule Making -- Separation of Powers

1. The broad grant of regulatory power contained in Insurance Law § 301, pursuant to which the Superintendent of Insurance is given power to make regulations interpreting the provisions of the Insurance Law, does not cede to the executive branch fundamental legislative or policymaking authority. Thus, section 301 does not violate the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers.

Administrative Law -- Rule Making -- Scope of Authority

2. The Superintendent of Insurance did not exceed the scope of his constitutional authority by engaging in inherently legislative activity in promulgating revised regulations reducing the time frames for claiming and proving entitlement to no-fault automobile insurance benefits. The regulations were not promulgated on a blank slate without any legislative guidance, nor did the revised regulations effectuate a profound change in social and economic policy. The Superintendent prescribed rules and regulations consistent with the enabling legislation.

Administrative Law -- Rule Making -- Scope of Authority

3. The absence of a specific statutory delegation of authority to establish time frames does not bar the Superintendent of Insurance from promulgating revised regulations that reduce the time frames for claiming and proving entitlement to no-fault automobile insurance benefits. The Legislature's failure to enact time limits evinces a legislative preference to yield to administrative expertise in filling in an interstice in the statutory scheme by the setting of such limits.

Administrative Law -- Rule Making -- Scope of Authority

4. Insofar as revised regulations reducing the time frames for claiming and proving entitlement to no-fault automobile insurance benefits create not a new category of exclusion, but rather merely a condition precedent with which all claimants must comply in order to receive benefits under the no-fault statute, the reduced time limits do not unlawfully create a new class of exclusion from coverage. The expert judgment of the Superintendent of Insurance that the reduced time frames will not have the effect of excluding a significant number of legitimate claims is not to be second-guessed by the courts, and his determination that the revised regulations are the most effective means of advancing the legislative intent of providing prompt payment of benefits as the loss is incurred, while reducing rampant abuse, was neither irrational nor unreasonable, nor arbitrary or capricious.

Administrative Law -- Rule Making -- Filing with Department of State

5. In directing no-fault automobile insurers to establish objective standards for reviewing late-filed claims (see 11 NYCRR 65-3.5 [l]), the Superintendent of Insurance did not improperly delegate rulemaking authority to private companies within the meaning of the State Administrative Procedure Act. Since these standards encompass case-specific mitigating factors and vest the decisionmakers with significant discretion with which to independently exercise their professional judgment, the standards constitute not "rules" but guidelines, and such guidelines need not be filed with the Department of State pursuant to NY Constitution, article IV, § 8, which mandates that agency regulations be filed with the Department of State prior to becoming effective.

Administrative Law -- Rule Making -- Self-Regulation by Private Parties

6. In directing no-fault automobile insurers to establish objective standards for reviewing late-filed claims (see 11 NYCRR 65-3.5 [l]), the Superintendent of Insurance did not improperly delegate rulemaking authority to private companies. Self-regulation by private parties is not forbidden, as long as the delegation of authority is properly circumscribed by agency oversight. Here, the challenged regulations provide that insurer standards will come under review by the Insurance Department, the actual rulemaking authority.

Administrative Law -- Rule Making -- Compliance with State Administrative Procedure Act

7. Revised regulations reducing the time frames for claiming and proving entitlement to no-fault automobile insurance benefits were promulgated in substantial compliance with the State Administrative Procedure Act. Accordingly, petitioners' contentions that respondents failed to analyze alternative approaches raised in public comments, failed to supply an adequate Regulatory Impact Statement (RIS) and Regulatory Flexibility Analysis (RFA) that described the "needs and benefits" of the revised regulations, failed to amend the RIS and RFA, and failed to provide a "best estimate" of the costs of the proposed regulations, are rejected.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Interest on Overdue Payments

8. 11 NYCRR 65-3.9 (a), which provides that the interest due on overdue no-fault insurance payments shall be calculated as simple interest, does not conflict with the enabling statute, Insurance Law § 5106 (a), since the statute is silent as to whether the interest is to be simple or compounded.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Limitation on Attorney Fees Paid to Health Care Providers

9. 11 NYCRR 65-4.6 (i), which provides that attorney fees are no longer to be paid to a health care provider who submits claims in excess of the applicable fee schedules established pursuant to Insurance Law § 5108, except when the charges involve interpretation of the schedules or inadvertent miscalculation or error, constitutes a permissible "limitation[] promulgated by the Superintendent in regulations" within the meaning of the enabling legislation (Insurance Law § 5106 [a]). The regulation was adopted in order to deter health care providers from overcharging by filing claims in excess of the amount to which they are statutorily entitled.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Assignment to Health Care Providers of Benefits for Non-Health-Related Services

10. In promulgating revised regulations which no longer permit the assignment to health care providers of no-fault insurance benefits for non-health-related services (11 NYCRR 65-3.11 [a]), the Superintendent of Insurance rationally and reasonably determined that the restriction is necessary to reduce abuses in the payment of benefits for such services, particularly with respect to questionable claims for transportation or housekeeping expenses, and that permitting assignment of such claims thus contravenes public policy.

Insurance -- No-Fault Automobile Insurance -- Arbitration of Disputed Claims

11. Revised regulations providing that arbitrators may issue subpoenas on their own initiative, and "may raise any issue that the arbitrator deems relevant to making an award that is consistent with the Insurance Law and department regulations" (11 NYCRR 65-4.4 [e]) do not undermine Insurance Law § 5106 (b). The statute states that "[e]very insurer shall provide a claimant with the option of submitting any dispute involving the insurer's liability to pay * * * benefits * * * the amount thereof or any other matter which may arise [with respect to overdue benefits] * * * to arbitration pursuant to simplified procedures to be promulgated or approved by the superintendent." The statute requires only that insurers provide claimants with the option of arbitration. Once a claimant resorts to arbitration, the statute neither entitles the claimant to withhold relevant evidence nor precludes inquiry into issues the arbitrator deems relevant.

 

164 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Stuart


No. 87


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 412; 797 N.E.2d 28; 765 N.Y.S.2d 1; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 1773


June 5, 2003, Argued  
July 2, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected September 26, 2003.



DISPOSITION: Appellate term's order was affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment from the Appellate Term (New York), which affirmed defendant's conviction for two counts of fourth-degree stalking in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 120.45.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued on appeal that the legislature's failure to define the statutory words "no legitimate purpose" rendered the anti-stalking statute unconstitutionally vague and that the vagueness problem was exacerbated because the statute did not contain a specific intent requirement. The court disagreed and upheld his conviction. The statute did contain a mens rea requirement of intent; before a person could be convicted, he must have intended to engage in a course of conduct targeted at a specific person. The legislature's decision to require intent as to a particular course of conduct--as opposed to a specific result of fear or harm--was purposeful; the law focused on what the offenders did, not what they meant by it or intended, as trying to discern the specific motivations of stalkers, many of whom were emotionally disturbed, would prove difficult. The ordinary understanding of the phrase "no legitimate purpose," namely, the absence of a reason or justification, when read in conjunction with the other statutory provisions, gave defendant adequate notice that his unrelenting pursuit of the complainant was unlawful, particularly after she told him she wanted no contact with him.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Stalking Statute Not Void for Vagueness

 Penal Law § 120.45 (1) and (2), which provides that a person is guilty of stalking in the fourth degree if he or she "intentionally, and for no legitimate purpose," engages in a course of conduct directed at a specific person when the offender knows or reasonably should know that the offender's conduct either is likely to place the victim in reasonable fear of material harm, or causes material harm where such conduct consists of certain actions done after the offender was clearly told to stop, is not unconstitutionally vague as applied to defendant's conduct, and accordingly is not invalid on its face. Defendant approached the complainant and gave her unsolicited gifts on two occasions, and then, despite being told that she did not want any further contact with him, defendant followed the complainant to various locations almost every day during a five-week period. While the statute does not require that the offender intend a specific result, such as fear or harm, the offender must have intended to engage in a course of conduct targeted at a specific person. Defendant could not reasonably have failed to realize that his intentional course of conduct directed at the complainant was unlawful. Nor does the phrase "no legitimate purpose" render the statute unconstitutionally vague, as it is commonly understood to mean the absence of a reason or justification to engage someone, other than to hound, frighten, intimidate, or threaten. Defendant has offered no explanation for having inflicted himself on complainant, nor has he attempted to show that his intrusive behavior involved some valid purpose other than hounding her to the point of harm.

 

165 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Mangano


No. 67


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 569; 796 N.E.2d 470; 764 N.Y.S.2d 379; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 1782


May 1, 2003, Argued  
July 2, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Subsequent civil proceeding at Mangano v. Cambariere, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 72595 (S.D.N.Y., Sept. 27, 2007)



DISPOSITION: Appellate term's order was reversed and informations were dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A jury in the trial court convicted defendant of four of the five counts of harassment in the second degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(1) (effective Aug. 1998). The Appellate Term (New York) affirmed the convictions. Defendant appealed the order.


OVERVIEW: A city restricted on-the-street overnight parking. Residents with overnight guests could leave a message on a telephone answering machine to avert ticketing. Defendant made five calls to the answering machine to register guests, and, after providing license plate numbers, defendant rained invective on two city employees, wished them and their families ill health, and complained of their job performance, as well as tickets that defendant had received. Defendant argued that the version of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(1) (effective Aug. 1998) in effect at the time of the incidents was unconstitutionally overbroad and vague on its face and as applied. The reviewing court held that, while defendant's messages were crude and offensive, they were made in the context of complaining about government actions, on a telephone answering machine set up for a purpose of receiving complaints from the public. The reviewing court found that the messages did not fall within any of the proscribable classes of speech or conduct. Therefore, the reviewing court held that the convictions had to be reversed.


OUTCOME: The order was reversed, and informations were dismissed.



HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Aggravated Harassment -- Telephone Messages to Government Answering Machine

In a prosecution for aggravated harassment arising out of five messages defendant left on a village parking violations bureau's answering machine, informations charging defendant with aggravated harassment should be dismissed. Defendant was charged under Penal Law § 240.30 (1), which at the time of arrest provided that a person is guilty of aggravated harassment in the second degree when, with the intent to harass, annoy, threaten or alarm another person, he or she "[c]ommunicates, or causes a communication to be initiated by mechanical or electronic means or otherwise, with a person, anonymously or otherwise, by telephone * * * in a manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm." Defendant's messages, in which defendant rained invective on two village employees, wished them ill health and complained about job performance and past tickets, were crude and offensive but made in the context of complaining about government actions, on a telephone answering machine set up for the purpose (among others) of receiving complaints from the public. Defendant's messages do not fall within any of the proscribable classes of speech or conduct.

 

166 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Kellogg v. Travis


No. 93 SSM 9


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 407; 796 N.E.2d 467; 764 N.Y.S.2d 376; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 1718



July 1, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected September 19, 2003.



DISPOSITION: Order of the appellate division affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff felon challenged the constitutionality of an amendment to New York's DNA identification index law, N.Y. Exec. Law § 995-c, which required him, as a violent felony offender, to submit a DNA sample. The Appellate Division (New York) affirmed a decision upholding application of the statute to the felon. The felon appealed.


OVERVIEW: While serving parole for a 1994 conviction for two offenses, the felon was directed to submit a DNA sample pursuant to a 1999 amendment of N.Y. Exec. Law § 995-c. Because he was told that his refusal would result in re-incarceration, the felon complied under written protest. He argued that application of the law to his case violated the Ex Post Facto Clause of the United States Constitution, U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, as well as the caveat of N.Y. Gen. Constr. Law § 93 that ambiguous statutes should not be construed so as to exact a retroactive punishment. The court rejected both arguments. The felon's ex-post-facto argument failed because the DNA identification index was to be used in future investigations, not as a punishment for past crimes. There was no indication that the extraction of DNA samples was required as a way of increasing the punishment of persons convicted of the designated offenses. The felon's second argument failed because the General Construction Law placed no restraint on the state legislature beyond the restrictions in the Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the decision of the appellate division should be affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Ex Post Facto Law - 1999 Amendment to DNA Identification Index Law

1. The 1999 amendment to the DNA identification index law, which requires criminals convicted of certain violent felony and other offenses who were still serving their sentences at the time the amendment was enacted to submit a DNA sample, even though they were convicted before the effective date of the amendment, is not an unconstitutional ex post facto law (see US Const, art I, § 10). The amendment is not a penal statute subject to the prohibition on ex post facto laws. The DNA identification index is to be used in future investigations, not as punishment for past crimes.

Statutes - Retroactive Application of Statute - 1999 Amendment to DNA Identification Index Law

2. The 1999 amendment to the DNA identification index law, which requires criminals convicted of certain violent felony and other offenses who were still serving their sentences at the time the amendment was enacted to submit a DNA sample, even though they were convicted before the effective date of the amendment, does not violate the General Construction Law's caveat that ambiguous statutes should not be construed so as to exact a retroactive punishment (General Construction Law § 93). The General Construction Law places no restraint on the Legislature in enacting laws that have retroactive application beyond the restrictions in the Constitution.

 

167 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Paynter v. State


No. 75


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 434; 797 N.E.2d 1225; 765 N.Y.S.2d 819; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 1672


May 8, 2003, Argued  
June 26, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 17, 2003.



DISPOSITION: Order of the appellate division affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, 15 African-American schoolchildren who purported to represent a class of children, appealed a judgment from the Appellate Division (New York). The appellate division granted the State's motion to dismiss plaintiffs' complaint, which alleged that the concentration of poverty in the Rochester City School District caused the students to receive an inadequate education in violation of the Education Article, N.Y. Const. art. XI, § 1.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs alleged that various State policies, including school residency requirements and nonresident tuition requirements, had resulted in high levels of poverty and racial isolation, which in turn had led to deficient student performance. The appellate division granted the State's motion to dismiss. The court affirmed. Plaintiffs had failed to state a cause of action under the Education Article. Plaintiffs had not claimed that the substandard academic performance in their schools stemmed from a lack of funds or inadequacy in the teaching, facilities, or instrumentalities of learning. Rather, they premised their argument on the State's failure to mitigate demographic factors that might affect student performance. However, allegations of academic failure alone, without allegations that the State had failed in its obligation to provide minimally acceptable educational services, were insufficient to state a cause of action. To embrace plaintiffs' theory that the State was responsible for the demographic makeup of every school district would subvert the important role of local control and participation in education and would make the State responsible for where people chose to live.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the appellate division's judgment.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law--Education Article--High Concentration of Racial Minorities and Poverty in School District

In a class action brought on behalf of students in the Rochester City School District, plaintiffs' allegations that certain state practices and policies have resulted in high concentrations of racial minorities and poverty in the school district, leading to abysmal student performance, are insufficient to state a cause of action under the Education Article of the New York Constitution (NY Const, art XI, § 1). Plaintiffs do not allege that the substandard academic performance in their schools is caused by any deficiency in teaching, facilities or instrumentalities of learning, or any lack of funding. The Education Article provides children with the right to a "sound basic education," and if the State puts adequate resources into the classroom, it satisfies its constitutional promise even if student performance remains substandard.

 

168 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Campaign for Fiscal Equity, Inc. v. State


No. 74


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 893; 801 N.E.2d 326; 769 N.Y.S.2d 106; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 1678


May 8, 2003, Argued  
June 26, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected December 29, 2003.
Motion granted by, Motion denied by Campaign for Fiscal Equity, Inc. v. State, 2005 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 3257 (2005)
Subsequent appeal at Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. State, 29 A.D.3d 175, 814 N.Y.S.2d 1, 2006 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 3598 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, 2006)
Related proceeding at Matter of Pena v. Robles, 12 Misc. 3d 1163A, 819 N.Y.S.2d 211, 2006 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1338 (2006)



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed in part and modified in part; case remitted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the Campaign for Fiscal Equity and others, appealed a judgment from the Appellate Division (New York). The appellate division reversed a judgment of the trial court, which determined that defendants, the State of New York and others, had violated N.Y. Const. art. XI, § 1 by failing to provide New York City's public schoolchildren with a sound basic education.


OVERVIEW: The trial court found that the State had violated art. XI, § 1 and Title VI, provided a template for a sound basic education, and directed the State to put in place systematic reforms. The appellate division reversed. The court affirmed to the extent that plaintiffs' Title VI claims were dismissed and otherwise reversed. Plaintiffs had established a prima facie case of showing a causal link between the funding of New York City schools and students' educational opportunities. Tens of thousands of students were placed in overcrowded classrooms, taught by unqualified teachers, and provided with inadequate facilities and equipment. Test results and the number of students finishing school also showed that students were not receiving a sound basic education. The court modified the trial court's threshold guideline that the State ascertain the actual costs of providing a sound basic education in districts around the State and held instead that the State need only ascertain the actual cost of providing a sound basic education in New York City. Reforms to the current funding system had to ensure that every city school would have the resources necessary to provide a sound basic education.


OUTCOME: The court modified the judgment below. It affirmed the dismissal of plaintiffs' Title VI claims and otherwise reversed the appellate division's order.



HEADNOTES

Schools -- State Aid to School Districts -- Discrimination Cause of Action under Implementing Regulations of Title VI of Civil Rights Act

1. Plaintiff's claim that the State's method of school funding in New York City violates United States Department of Education regulations pursuant to title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USC § 2000d et seq.; 34 CFR 100.3 [b] [2]) was correctly dismissed for the reasons stated by the Appellate Division ( 295 A.D.2d 1, 744 N.Y.S.2d 130).

Schools -- Students -- Sound Basic Education

2. A sound basic education within the meaning of the Education Article of the State Constitution (art XI, § 1) is a meaningful high school education that prepares students to compete for jobs that enable them to support themselves and to function productively as civic participants. A sound basic education should not be pegged to any particular grade level. However, a high school level education is now all but indispensable for the purpose of preparing students to compete for such employment, and students require more than an eighth grade education to function productively as citizens.

Schools -- State Aid to School Districts -- Constitutionality of State's Public School Financing System

3. The State has violated the constitutional mandate to make available a "sound basic education" to all the children of the state (NY Const, art XI, § 1) by establishing an education financing system that fails to afford New York City's public schoolchildren the opportunity for a meaningful high school education. Whether measured by inputs (the resources afforded students) or outputs (test results and graduation rates), New York City schoolchildren are not receiving the constitutionally-mandated opportunity for a sound basic education. The quality of New York City teachers is inadequate, New York City schools have excessive class sizes which negatively affect learning, New York City schools are deficient in instrumentalities of learning, and the rate of school completion in New York City compares unfavorably with both state and national figures. Plaintiffs have established the necessary "causal link" between the present funding system and the poor performance of City schools by showing that increased funding can provide better teachers, facilities and instrumentalities of learning, and that such improved inputs yield better student performance.

Schools -- State Aid to School Districts -- Remedy for Failure to Provide Sound Basic Education

4. With respect to New York City's public schoolchildren, the State has violated the constitutional mandate to provide all the children of the state with a sound basic education (NY Const, art XI, § 1). To remedy the State's violation of the constitutional mandate, defendants must determine the actual cost of providing a sound basic education in New York City and enact appropriate reforms which ensure a system of accountability. The State should be able to build on existing criteria to identify the schools in greatest need and set measurable goals for their improvement. Because City schools are dependent on municipal revenues, it will not be mandated that a new system must ensure the City "sustained and stable funding." Reforms may address governance as well as the school funding system, and state aid should increase where need is high and local ability to pay is low.

 

169 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Saratoga County Chamber of Commerce v. Pataki


No. 42


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 801; 798 N.E.2d 1047; 766 N.Y.S.2d 654; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 1470


March 26, 2003, Argued  
June 12, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected November 7, 2003.
US Supreme Court certiorari denied by Pataki v. Saratoga County Chamber of Commerce, Inc., 540 U.S. 1017, 157 L. Ed. 2d 430, 124 S. Ct. 570, 2003 U.S. LEXIS 8378 (U.S., 2003)
Related proceeding at Dalton v. Pataki, 11 A.D.3d 62, 780 N.Y.S.2d 47, 2004 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 9338 (N.Y. App. Div. 3d Dep't, July 7, 2004)



DISPOSITION: Order modified in part and affirmed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, citizens and legislators opposed to casino gambling (citizens), alleged that an agreement and its later amendment between defendant governor and an Indian tribe violated the separation of powers and the constitutional ban on gambling. Following a remand, the trial court granted the citizens' motion for summary judgment. That judgment was affirmed by the Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York), from which the governor appealed.


OVERVIEW: On appeal from the trial court decision, the interim court held that the governor's unilateral action deprived the legislature of its authority in such areas as the location of the casino, the gaming that could be carried on there, the extent of state involvement in providing regulation, and the fees to be exacted. The governor contested standing as to all of the citizen groups. The appellate court found that, because it concluded that the citizen taxpayers had standing, it was not necessary to address the governor's challenge as to the other citizens. Here, the citizen-taxpayers sufficiently alleged a challenge to the expenditure of state money to withstand the governor's motion to dismiss for lack of standing. The appellate court found further that the citizens' declaratory judgment action fell within the residuary six-year statute of limitations period under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 213(1). Nowhere, however, was there any indication that the delay in bringing the action caused the slightest harm to the tribe. The appellate court found, finally, that the alleged constitutional violation would have been without remedy if the action was dismissed for the tribe's nonjoinder.


OUTCOME: The judgment was modified by vacating that portion pertaining to the 1999 amendment to the original agreement as void and unenforceable and, as so modified, the judgment was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Appeal -- Academic and Moot Questions -- Action Challenging Authority of Governor to Enter into Casino Gambling Compact with Indian Tribe

1. In two actions challenging the authority of the Governor to enter into a casino gambling compact with an Indian tribe in 1993 and a one-year amendment to the compact in 1999 without legislative approval, the portion of plaintiffs' suit that challenges the validity of the 1999 amendment is moot. The amendment expired in May 2000, and in the intervening three years no similar agreement has gone into effect. A declaration as to the validity or invalidity of the 1999 amendment would therefore have no practical effect on the parties. The portion of plaintiffs' suit that challenges the validity of the 1993 compact, however, is not moot.

Parties -- Standing -- Taxpayer's Action Challenging Authority of Governor to Enter into Casino Gambling Compact with Indian Tribe

2. Plaintiff citizen taxpayers have standing under State Finance Law § 123-b to maintain actions challenging the authority of the Governor to enter into a casino gambling compact with an Indian tribe without legislative approval. Plaintiffs challenge as unconstitutional the expenditure of state funds and the use of state regulatory personnel for the casino, claims that have a sufficient nexus to fiscal activities of the state to allow for standing under section 123-b. If plaintiffs were denied standing, an important constitutional issue would be effectively insulated from judicial review.

Limitation of Actions -- Six-Year Statute of Limitations -- Action Challenging Authority of Governor to Enter into Casino Gambling Compact with Indian Tribe

3. Two actions challenging the authority of the Governor to enter into a casino gambling compact with an Indian tribe without legislative approval are not barred by the statute of limitations. Plaintiffs seek a declaration as to the unconstitutionality of the compact and an injunction against the use of state funds to implement it. That relief cannot be afforded under CPLR article 78, and the four-month limitations period (CPLR 217) for article 78 actions does not apply. Rather, plaintiffs' declaratory judgment actions fall within the residuary six-year statute of limitations period under CPLR 213 (1). The actions are timely, having been brought less than six years after the compact was published in the Federal Register.

Equity -- Laches -- Action Challenging Authority of Governor to Enter into Casino Gambling Compact with Indian Tribe

4. Two actions challenging the authority of the Governor to enter into a casino gambling compact with an Indian tribe without legislative approval brought nearly six years after the compact became final are not barred by laches. There has been no economic prejudice to the tribe, which has been operating, and presumably profiting from, the casino during the entire pendency of the suit. While the suit threatens future casino revenue, the prejudice caused by a loss of expected profits based on a predictably vulnerable compact is not the sort of prejudice that supports a defense of laches.

Parties -- Necessary Parties -- Failure to Join Indian Tribe in Actions to Invalidate Tribe's Casino Gambling Compact

5. Two actions challenging the authority of the Governor to enter into a casino gambling compact with an Indian tribe without legislative approval should not be dismissed for failure to join the tribe as an indispensable party (CPLR 1001). The tribe has chosen not to participate, and it cannot be forced to participate because it has sovereign immunity. Plaintiffs do not have another remedy available to them (CPLR 1001 [b] [1]), and no one would ever be able to bring this constitutional challenge should it be determined that the tribe is an indispensable party. To the extent that the tribe is prejudiced by the adjudication of issues that affect its rights under the compact, it could have mitigated that prejudice by participating in the suit.

Constitutional Law -- Separation of Powers -- Governor's Execution of Casino Gambling Compact with Indian Tribe without Legislative Approval

6. The Governor lacks authority to bind the State to a casino gambling compact with an Indian tribe without legislative approval. The Federal Indian Gaming Regulatory Act does not preempt state law governing which state actors are competent to negotiate and agree to gaming compacts, but it contemplates that states will confront several policy choices when negotiating gaming compacts (25 USC § 2710 [d] [3] [C]). These policy choices require a balancing of different interests, a task that the multi-member, representative Legislature is entrusted to perform under New York's constitutional structure. Moreover, the compact required the State Racing and Wagering Board to adopt new regulations for the oversight of casino gambling, which the agency cannot do without legislative authorization.

 

170 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Miriam Osborn Mem'l Home Ass'n v. Chassin


No. 68


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 544; 793 N.E.2d 404; 762 N.Y.S.2d 867; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 1315


May 6, 2003, Argued  
June 5, 2003, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the appellate division affirmed in part and modified in part; remitted to the trial court.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff residential health care facility (RHCF) sued respondent Commissioner of the New York State Department of Health, seeking a declaration that assessments imposed under N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-d were unconstitutional. The trial court dismissed the action but the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) reversed the trial court's judgment in part. The instant court granted leave to appeal.


OVERVIEW: New York State enacted N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2807-d in 1990 to raise revenue to overcome a budget and Medicaid deficit. Section 2807-d required RHCFs to pay 0.6 percent of their gross receipts from patient care services and operating income to the State, and was amended in 1992, by imposing an additional assessment of 1.2 percent. The amended statute exempted two categories of nonprofit RHCFs from the assessments but did not extend that exemption to a not-for-profit RHCF that operated a home of needy, aged women, and the RHCF filed an action claiming that § 2807-d was unconstitutional as applied to it. The trial court directed the RHCF to comply with the reporting requirements of § 2807-d and dismissed its action challenging assessments that were imposed under it, but the intermediate appellate court found that the additional assessment of 1.2 percent was arbitrary in that it imposed a tax exclusively on the RHCF, and it modified the trial court's judgment. The instant court held that § 2807-d was constitutional in all respects and the intermediate appellate court erred by finding that the additional assessment denied the RHCF equal protection of the law.


OUTCOME: The instant court declared that the statute was constitutional, directed the RHCF to comply with its reporting requirements, and remitted the case to the trial court for further consideration of the Department's counterclaim for an order determining the amounts which the RHCF owned.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Statute Imposing Assessment on Gross Receipts of Certain Health-Related Facilities

 Public Health Law § 2807-d (2) (b) (i), which requires residential health care facilities (RHCFs) to pay a monetary assessment of 0.6% of gross receipts, and Public Health Law § 2807-d (2) (b) (ii), which imposes an additional 1.2%, are constitutionally valid and are not violative of plaintiff's right to equal protection of the law. The statute exempts two new categories of nonprofit RHCFs from the assessments, neither of which includes plaintiff. For purposes of equal protection review, any classification creating differential taxation enjoys a strong presumption of constitutionality. A classification must be upheld if there is any reasonably conceivable state of facts that could provide a rational basis for the classification. Here, the policy-based exemptions and the tax itself are rationally imposed by the statute. The plain language of Public Health Law § 2807-d and its legislative history demonstrate a clear intention by the Legislature that the section apply to all RHCFs, as defined by article 28, absent a specific exemption, including plaintiff, a non-Medicaid, not-for-profit RHCF that does not fit within any exemption.

 

171 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Desiderio v. Ochs


No. 29


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


100 N.Y.2d 159; 791 N.E.2d 941; 761 N.Y.S.2d 576; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 432


February 12, 2003, Argued  
April 8, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected July 15th, 2003.



DISPOSITION: Order of the appellate division affirmed; certified question not answered as moot.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In respondent injured party's medical malpractice action, the trial court structured a future damages judgment under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 50-A. Appellants, a hospital and an insurer, sought review, and the Appellate Division (New York) affirmed. The hospital and insurer sought further review, and the Appellate Division certified a question.


OVERVIEW: The trial court rejected the hospital's and insurer's proposed structure for paying the injured party future damages he was awarded and adopted the injured party's proposed structure. The court of appeals held N.Y. C.P.L.R. 5031(e) was very specific regarding the procedure for structuring an annuity for the payment of future damages. The first annual payment was to be calculated by dividing the amount of future damages, after certain adjustments, by the number of years over which payment was to be made, and each succeeding year's payment was computed by adding four percent to the previous year's payment. The potential dramatic discrepancy between the jury's award and the injured party's ultimate recovery, if he survived the number of years the future damages award was intended to cover, did not allow the court to ignore the statute's clear language. Had the legislature intended that the structured judgment bear a more direct relationship to the jury's award, it could have required the jury's itemization of damages on a per-year basis or itemization of a specific inflation rate. The statute did not authorize the approach proposed by the hospital and insurer.


OUTCOME: The appellate division's judgment was affirmed, and its question was not answered.



HEADNOTES

Damages - Structured Judgment - Discrepancy between Jury Award and Ultimate Recovery

Literal application of CPLR article 50-A is not prohibited when the resulting structured judgment might exceed the jury's future damages award. CPLR 5031 (e) is clear that the first year payout under the annuity for future damages is to be determined "by dividing the remaining amount of future damages by the number of years over which such payments shall be made," and that the payment for each successive year is to be computed by "adding four percent to the previous year's payment." CPLR 4111 (d) requires only that juries itemize their verdicts with a category of damages, a total dollar amount and a term of years. Juries will not be asked to itemize the basis for their verdict in terms of inflation rates, productivity rates and other factors assumed in reaching a total amount of damages, and to thereby render superfluous the information required under CPLR 4111 (d). In determining a growth rate for the structured judgment, CPLR 5031 (e) does not authorize applying a rate that will increase payments in such a way as to equal the jury's future damages award in the specified number of years. Such a methodology disregards the additional four percent adjustment on structured judgments specifically delineated in the statute. Further, the phrase "determined in accordance with generally accepted actuarial practices" in CPLR 5031 (e) refers to selection of the discount rate used to reduce the structured judgment to present value. It does not empower courts to review and rewrite the entirety of a structured judgment to conform to economic doctrines.

 

172 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Moran Towing Corp. v. Urbach


No. 30


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


99 N.Y.2d 443; 787 N.E.2d 624; 757 N.Y.S.2d 513; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 279; 2003 AMC 1480


February 20, 2003, Argued  
March 27, 2003, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment and order of the appellate division reversed; matter remitted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state tax commissioner appealed the judgment of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, that found N.Y. Tax Law §§ 301(a)(1)(ii), 301-a(b)(2) and 301-a(c)(1)(B) facially unconstitutional. The decision came after respondent towing company and intervenors, two boat operators, initiated a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding that sought to overturn the commissioner's decision denying their requests for tax refunds paid.


OVERVIEW: A towing company and two companies that operated tug boats on New York's waterways challenged the constitutionality of New York's taxing scheme that taxed petroleum consumption. The applicable tax was assessed for the privilege of using the state's waterways. After the trial court found that the statutes were facially unconstitutional, the interim court reversed. The commissioner sought to resolve any questions, and appealed as a matter of right. The appellate court found that the applicable decisions supported the appellate court's conclusion that the Complete Auto test was the appropriate test to determine whether the tax statutes violated the Commerce Clause. Further, consistent with the appellate court's decision in Orvis, they supported the conclusion that physical presence of a business in New York was sufficient to constitute a "substantial nexus" with the state under Complete Auto. Thus, the tugboat towing companies' facial constitutional challenge failed because there was a set of circumstances under which the statute would be valid.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed and remitted.



HEADNOTES

Taxation - Motor Fuel Taxes - Constitutionality of Petroleum Business Tax - Commerce Clause - Substantial Nexus

1. Tax Law § 301 (a) (1) (ii) and § 301-a (b) (2); (c) (1) (B), which impose a tax on petroleum businesses for the privilege of doing business in New York measured by fuel consumption on vessels engaged in interstate commerce while operating in New York State waters, are not facially unconstitutional under the Commerce Clause. There is a "substantial nexus," within the meaning of Complete Auto Tr., Inc. v Brady (430 US 274 [1977]), between New York and the activity to which the statutes in question apply. The required nexus need not necessarily be directly related to the activity being taxed, but can simply be whether there is some definite link, some minimum connection, between the taxing state and the person it seeks to tax. Physical presence of a business in New York is sufficient to constitute a "substantial nexus," and the fact that the tax is measured by the consumption of fuel within New York does not alter the State's authority to tax the privilege of doing business in New York. Accordingly, the facial constitutional challenge must fail because there is a set of circumstances under which the statute would be valid: the entity being taxed may be a New York corporation with offices in the state, employing New York citizens and conducting business in the state.

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - "Came to Rest" Test

2. In determining that those portions of the petroleum business tax which impose a tax measured on fuel consumption on vessels engaged in interstate commerce while operating in New York State waters are facially unconstitutional under the Commerce Clause, the Appellate Division erred in applying cases decided before Complete Auto Tr., Inc. v Brady (430 US 274 [1977]). The United States Supreme Court has since determined that whether items remained "in the stream of interstate commerce" or "came to rest" within the state may be of some importance for other purposes, but for Commerce Clause analysis the distinction is largely irrelevant.

 

173 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Tompkins County Support Collection Unit ex rel. Chamberlin v. Chamberlin


No. 2


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


99 N.Y.2d 328; 786 N.E.2d 14; 756 N.Y.S.2d 115; 2003 N.Y. LEXIS 129


January 7, 2003, Argued  
February 13, 2003, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected March 28, 2003.



DISPOSITION: Reversed and remitted for further proceedings.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant child support agency sought to increase a child support order pursuant to child support guidelines, under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 413-a. The trial court entered an increased order, but the Appellate Division (New York) reversed the increase, the trial court reduced the order, and the agency appealed.


OVERVIEW: The agency said N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 413-a allowed the trial court to adjust the child support order based on the child support guidelines in N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 413, but respondent father said this would be a de facto modification without showing a change in circumstances. The court of appeals held the plain language and legislative history of N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 413-a directed the trial court to review the order to determine if an adjustment was warranted based on the child support guidelines, and not merely whether a cost of living adjustment should be applied. This adjustment was distinct from a modification based on a change in circumstances, so the parties' right to seek modification was not impermissibly expanded. This interpretation of the statute did not create an impediment to the father's right to contract with the mother, contrary to U.S. Const. art. I, § 10, cl. 1, and it served the important public purpose of ensuring that children received adequate support. The statute gave the father adequate notice of the possibility that the order could be adjusted in accordance with the child support guidelines, so the father's due process rights were not violated.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the appellate division was reversed.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child - Support - Cost of Living Adjustment - Right to De Novo Support Hearing upon Filing Objections

1. In a proceeding to review an objection to a cost of living adjustment (COLA) to a child support order, section 413-a of the Family Court Act authorizes the Family Court to review and adjust the underlying child support order in accordance with the standards set forth in Family Court Act § 413, not merely to decide if a COLA should be applied. Under the plain language of section 413-a, when a hearing is held pursuant to a COLA objection, the court is to review the order to determine whether an adjustment is warranted based on the section 413 guidelines. The statute directs the court to issue either "a new order of support in accordance with the child support standards" or, "where application of the child support standards ... results in a determination that no adjustment is appropriate," to enter an order of no adjustment. An order "in accordance with the child support standards" should be exactly that: an order that comports with the guidelines as set forth in section 413. Moreover, allowing de novo review of an underlying support order does not improperly expand the right to modification of support orders, since the right to review is distinct from the right to seek modification.

Parent and Child - Support - Cost of Living Adjustment - Constitutionality of De Novo Review of Child Support Obligation upon Filing Objections

2. De novo review and adjustment of a child support order under Family Court Act § 413-a in a proceeding to review a cost of living adjustment to that order does not violate the Contract Clause of the Federal Constitution. There is no impediment to the parties' right to contract. Moreover, even a substantial impairment of the right to contract is not unconstitutional if the State can demonstrate that it is reasonable and necessary to serve an important public purpose. Ensuring that children receive adequate support is an important public purpose, and review of support orders is a reasonable and necessary means of accomplishing that goal.

Parent and Child - Support - Cost of Living Adjustment - Due Process

3. The objection process of Family Court Act § 413-a, which authorizes the Family Court to review de novo and adjust an underlying child support order in a proceeding to review an objection to a cost of living adjustment to that order, satisfies due process requirements. Section 413-a notifies the parties that there will be a hearing in the event of an objection, and indicates what will be reviewed at the hearing and the possible outcomes. In addition, section 413-a does not require "specific written objections."

 

174 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Council of N.Y. v. PSC of N.Y.


No. 109


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


99 N.Y.2d 64; 781 N.E.2d 886; 751 N.Y.S.2d 822; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 3371


September 4, 2002, Argued  
October 22, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected January 17, 2003.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner City Council appealed from the dismissal of its petition by the Appellate Division (New York), seeking to annul two orders of respondent New York Public Service Commission (PSC) approving the renewal of franchises of respondent cable companies, negotiated by respondent information technology department, and approved by respondent New York City Franchise and Concession Review Committee (FCRC) and respondent former Mayor.


OVERVIEW: The Council sought to annul the PSC's orders and to direct the city respondents to submit the franchise agreements to the Council for review and approval. The appellate court held that the PSC rationally concluded that for purposes of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 591.3(c), the FCRC had the authority to approve franchise renewals. The regulation did not require the additional approval of the Council. The Council's argument that the City Charter precluded Council involvement in selection but not renewal of franchise agreements was rejected. The absence of an express prohibition on the Council's authority to approve renewals did not amount to an affirmative grant of power. The Charter gave the FCRC the authority to approve franchise agreements. The decision to approve the renewal of a franchise agreement necessarily involved selection of a franchise. The PSC rationally read the Charter to limit the power of the Council as to franchise renewals. The Charter contained the same limitation in connection with the renewal process. Therefore, the PSC correctly concluded that the FCRC was the "local legislative body" whose assent was required by state regulation.


OUTCOME: The dismissal was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Administrative Law - Administrative Interpretation - Deference to Agency Interpretation - Public Service Commission

1. In a proceeding to annul determinations of the Public Service Commission renewing certain cable television franchises in New York City, deference is due the orders of the Commission. Petitioner's challenge to the orders relies solely on the requirement of "local legislative approval" set forth in 9 NYCRR 591.3 (c). The interpretation given to a regulation by the agency which promulgated it and is responsible for its administration is entitled to deference if that determination is not irrational or unreasonable. The Commission's predecessor promulgated the regulation and the Commission is responsible for ensuring compliance with its requirements. The Commission, in applying its regulation, relied not only on the statute but also on its own past practices with respect to New York City cable franchises.

Radio and Television - Cable Television - Franchise - Local Legislative Approval of Renewal - New York City Council

2. In renewing certain cable television franchises in New York City, the Public Service Commission rationally concluded that "local legislative body" in 9 NYCRR 591.3 (c) meant the body designated to approve franchise renewals. The authorizing statute for section 591.3 (c)--Public Service Law § 222 (1)--speaks of "any municipal approval required ... by law." Although in municipalities other than New York City, franchises are granted by the town board, village board of trustees, or the common council of the city, the New York City Charter requires that the Franchise and Concession Review Committee approve franchises, and explicitly bars any participation by the New York City Council after the Council passes an authorizing resolution. Thus, the Commission rationally concluded that for purposes of 9 NYCRR 591.3 (c), the Review Committee was the body with authority to approve franchise renewals, and that its regulation did not require or authorize the additional approval of the Council.

Radio and Television - Cable Television - Franchise - Local Legislative Approval of Renewal - New York City Council

3. In renewing certain cable television franchises in New York City, the Public Service Commission rationally read the New York City Charter to limit the power of the New York City Council with respect to franchise renewals. The Charter gives the Franchise and Concession Review Committee the authority to approve franchise agreements. The absence of an express prohibition on the Council's authority to approve renewals does not amount to an affirmative grant of power. The Charter gives the Council the power to pass an authorizing resolution, but also limits its authority by providing that the Council may not use an authorizing resolution to involve itself in the selection of a franchise. The decision to approve renewal of a franchise agreement necessarily involves selection of a franchise. Accordingly, inasmuch as the charter contains the same limitation in connection with the renewal process, the Commission correctly concluded that the Review Committee was the local legislative body whose assent is required by state regulation to renew a franchise.

 

175 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Davidson


No. 132


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 738; 780 N.E.2d 972; 751 N.Y.S.2d 161; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 3131


September 12, 2002, Argued  
October 15, 2002, Decided



DISPOSITION: Appeal dismissed, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After defendant was convicted of loitering in a public place for the purpose of gambling with cards, dice or other gambling paraphernalia, under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.35(2), the trial court granted his motion to set aside the verdict, based on the unconstitutionality of the statute. The New York Appellate Division reversed, and defendant sought further review.


OVERVIEW: The court of appeals held defendant's motion seeking dismissal based on the unconstitutionality of the statute he was charged with violating had to be filed within 45 days after arraignment and before the commencement of trial, or within such additional time as the trial court granted, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 255.20. It was the legislature's intention that such a potentially dispositive motion be made at the outset of a prosecution and not delayed until after an unfavorable verdict. Because defendant's challenge to the statute's constitutionality was not raised until he filed a motion to set aside the verdict, under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.30, his challenge was not properly preserved. When the Appellate Division decided the constitutional issue on the merits without addressing the lack of preservation, its reversal was based on an unpreserved issue and an appeal of its decision to the court of appeals did not meet the jurisdictional requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 450.90(2)(a). Therefore, dismissal of defendant's appeal was required.


OUTCOME: The appeal was dismissed.



HEADNOTES

Crimes - Appeal - Matters Appealable - Constitutional Challenge to Penal Statute 

An appeal from an Appellate Division order which reversed an order granting defendant's motion pursuant to CPL 330.30 (1) to vacate a loitering conviction on the ground that Penal Law § 240.35 (2) is unconstitutional, and reinstated the verdict, is dismissed. A defendant may move to seek dismissal of an indictment based on the unconstitutionality of the statute defining the offense charged (see CPL 210.20 [1] [a]; 210.25 [3]) within specific time periods established by the Criminal Procedure Law (see CPL 210.20 [2]; 255.20 [1]). A trial court is afforded discretion to entertain a dismissal motion "in the interest of justice, and for good cause shown" at any time before sentence (CPL 255.20 [3]). These deadlines rest on the strong public policy to further orderly trial procedures and preserve scarce trial resources. Defendant's constitutional challenge, made for the first time on a CPL 330.30 motion, was not preserved. The Appellate Division decided the constitutional issue on the merits without addressing the lack of preservation. Since the reversal was based on an unpreserved issue, it does not satisfy the jurisdictional requirement of CPL 450.90 (2) (a).

 

176 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Rivera v. Espada


No. 165


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 422; 777 N.E.2d 235; 748 N.Y.S.2d 343; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 2255


August 28, 2002, Argued  
August 30, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 18, 2002.
Appeal after remand at Rivera v. Espada, 2004 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 415 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, Jan. 20, 2004)



DISPOSITION: Order reversed and matter remitted for further proceedings.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner party members filed a complaint with their political party's county committee to cancel respondent state senator's enrollment in their party. The committee's chair expelled the senator from the party. The trial court then ordered the board of elections to cancel the senator's enrollment pursuant to N.Y. Elec. Law § 16-110(2). The Appellate Division (New York) reversed the decision and dismissed the petition. The party members appealed.


OVERVIEW: The senator's expulsion from the party was sought after he announced his intention to change his party affiliation and join the opposing party. The senator ultimately deferred his enrollment in the opposing party, however, because of a delay in the change taking effect; he opted to run in his current party's primary and to enroll in the opposing party later. Upon a party member's written complaint, § 16-110(2) allowed the county committee's chair to determine that a voter enrolled in the party was not in sympathy with the party's principles, and required the trial court to direct cancellation of the voter's enrollment if it appeared that the chair's determination was just. The court of appeals agreed with the appellate division that evidence privileged under the speech and debate clause, N.Y. Const. art. III, § 11, was improperly considered by the committee's chair. However, other statements and conduct not protected by N.Y. Const. art. III, § 11 were also offered. Since it was unclear what the committee chair would have decided on a record purged of the privileged information, a remand was required for the committee's chair to redetermine the issue using only proper evidence.


OUTCOME: The court of appeals reversed the order of the appellate division, without costs, and remitted the matter to the trial court with directions to remit the matter to the chair of the political party's county committee for redetermination.


HEADNOTES

Elections - Political Parties - Expelling Person from Party - "Raids"

1. Election Law § 16-110 (2), which permits the cancellation of the enrollment of a member of a political party after a finding that the party enrollee is not in sympathy with party principles, is not limited to the prevention of "raids" on political parties. Neither a plain reading of the statute nor case law limits the statute's applicability to party raiding.

Elections - Political Parties - Expelling Person from Party - Conduct Protected by Speech or Debate Clause

2. A finding by a political party's county committee that a State Senator, who had announced his intention to switch to another party, was no longer in sympathy with the principles of the party in which he is still enrolled (Election Law § 16-110 [2]), may not be based on conduct which is protected by the Speech or Debate Clause of the State Constitution (NY Const, art III, § 11). The Senator's participation in the rival party's Senate Conference activities, his voting record on legislation, the change in his seating in the Senate Chamber, and other legislative conduct are privileged and may not be considered in determining the Senator's political sympathies. Accordingly, to the extent that the Senator's expulsion from his party was based on constitutionally protected acts, it may not stand.

Elections - Political Parties - Expelling Person from Party - Conduct Unprotected by Speech or Debate Clause

3. In determining if a State Senator, who had announced his intention to switch his allegiance to a rival political party, may be expelled from his political party pursuant to Election Law § 16-110 (2) on the ground that he is no longer in sympathy with his party's principles, certain conduct by the Senator, which was not protected by the Speech or Debate Clause (NY Const, art III, § 11), may be considered sufficient to justify expulsion. The record contains evidence, from several public sources, of repeated and consistently maintained statements in which the Senator denounced his party. It may not be assumed that the proper finder of fact would or should accord the greatest weight to the Senator's choice ultimately not to change his party enrollment. Since the proper finder of fact to make that determination is the County Committee Chair, which must not base its findings on evidence that relates solely to the Senator's legislative acts or participation in the Senate Conference of a rival party, the matter must be remitted to that body for a redetermination upon proper evidence.

 

177 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Stoppenbach v. Sweeney


No. 164


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 431; 778 N.E.2d 1040; 749 N.Y.S.2d 210; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 2256


August 28, 2002, Argued  
August 30, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected November 22, 2002.



DISPOSITION: On appeal by appellant-respondent, order affirmed, without costs. Appeal by respondent-appellant dismissed, without costs, for lack of aggrievement.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, an objector, filed a proceeding challenging the sufficiency of the petition designating respondent as a candidate for public office. The trial court invalidated the petition, excluding 48 signatures and thereby leaving an insufficient number of valid signatures, N.Y. Elec. Law §§ 6-130, 6-136. The Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York), affirmed. The candidate appealed as of right, and the objector cross-appealed.


OVERVIEW: The trial court excluded the signatures in question for failure of the signers to accurately designate a town or city, N.Y. Elec. Law §§ 6-130, 6-136. N.Y. Elec. Law § 6-130 provided that a designating petition had to set forth in every instance the name of the signer, his or her residence address, town, or city (except in the city of New York, the county), and the date when the signature was affixed. The appellate court held that because, in a number of instances, the petition signers did not accurately set forth the town, the candidate did not have sufficient signatures. The appellate court held that compliance with the statute was required, as it constituted a matter of substance and not of form. An amendment of the statute such as the candidate sought was for the legislature to make.


OUTCOME: The order was affirmed, without costs. The cross-appeal by the objector was dismissed, without costs, for lack of aggrievement.


HEADNOTES

Elections - Designating Petitions - Failure of Signers to Indicate Town of Residence

Signers of a designating petition must include their town of residence in order for their signatures to be valid. Election Law § 6-130 requires that a designating petition set forth in every instance the names of the signers, their residence addresses, towns or cities, and the date the signatures are affixed. Compliance with the statute is required, as it constitutes a matter of substance and not of form. Although the statute was amended to eliminate the requirement that wards, election districts, and assembly districts be provided, it left intact that provision requiring the designation of towns and cities.

 

178 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Westchester Creek Corp. v. N.Y. City Sch. Constr. Auth.


No. 98


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 298; 774 N.E.2d 749; 746 N.Y.S.2d 684; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 1990; 33 ELR 20009


June 6, 2002, Argued  
July 9, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected August 30, 2002.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner property corporation challenged the judgment of the Appellate Division (New York) pursuant to N.Y. Em. Dom. Proc. Law § 207 that affirmed respondent school construction authority's (SCA) determination to condemn its leasehold interest in property.


OVERVIEW: In 1978, the city leased lot 70, as well as six other nearby parcels, to the property corporation under a master lease for a term of 90 years, including renewal options, pursuant to an urban renewal plan. In 1987, lot 70 was severed from the master lease, and made subject to a severance lease with a similar term. SCA condemned lot 70 in order to construct an elementary/intermediate school on the site. The corporation argued that SCA lacked the statutory authority to condemn lot 70; that as expressed by the legislature, use for urban renewal was superior to use as a public school; and that it had a state constitutional right to develop lot 70. The appellate court found that the written notice sent by SCA to the mayor effectively complied with N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1728(6). Further, the prior public use doctrine did not bar the condemnation of the property. SCA sought to condemn the property in order to provide schools to relieve severe overcrowding in two districts. As SCA has complied with the appropriate statutory procedures, it was authorized to condemn the property.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Eminent Domain - New York City School Construction Authority - Condemnation of Property Owned by City - Notice to Mayor

1. The New York City School Construction Authority does not lack the statutory authority to condemn a leasehold interest in real property owned by the City of New York. Although Public Authorities Law § 1728 (6) confers on the Authority broad condemnation powers, the condemnation of City property, or property in which the City has an interest, must comply with section 1729 (2), under which the Authority must submit a written request for the property directly to the mayor. The Authority may condemn the property under section 1728 (6) if the mayor does not respond to the request within 30 days. Accordingly, the Authority effectively complied with section 1728 (6) by sending written notice to the mayor of its intention to use the leasehold through the submission of a site plan.

Eminent Domain - Public Use - Prior Public Use Doctrine - Condemnation by School Construction Authority of Property Designated for Urban Renewal

2. The prior public use doctrine does not bar condemnation by the New York City School Construction Authority of a leasehold interest in real property owned by the City of New York and designated for urban renewal. The Public Authorities Law expressly permits the condemnation of City-owned property, provided that the City, through its mayor, is first given the right to object to such taking. The importance of public renewal does not dictate a different result. While the Legislature has stated that urban redevelopment is "a superior public use," it has also stated that there can be no higher priority than creating a physical environment in the schools that fosters the education of children. To further that end, Public Authorities Law § 1728 (17) authorizes the Authority "[t]o do any and all things necessary or convenient to carry out and exercise the powers given and granted by this section." Inasmuch as the Authority seeks to condemn the property in order to provide schools to relieve severe overcrowding, and it has complied with the appropriate statutory procedures, it was authorized to condemn the property.

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Condemnation of Leasehold Interest in Urban Renewal Property by School District

3. The holder of a leasehold interest in real property designated for urban renewal and owned by the City of New York does not have a state constitutional right to develop the property. Accordingly, the New York City School Construction Authority may validly condemn the property in order to construct a school which will relieve overcrowding at other schools. While article XVIII, § 1 of the New York State Constitution gives the Legislature the power to establish urban renewal projects, it does not confer any protection on redevelopers against condemnation. By contrast, the Authority has unquestioned authority to act to relieve the severe overcrowding in community schools.

 

179 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Harris


No. 80


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 452; 779 N.E.2d 705; 749 N.Y.S.2d 766; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 1993


May 6, 2002, Argued  
July 9, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected November 29, 2002.
Writ of habeas corpus denied Harris v. Goord, 2004 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 14017 (E.D.N.Y., July 23, 2004)
Post-conviction relief denied at People v. Harris, 2011 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 624 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., Jan. 18, 2011)
Post-conviction relief denied at People v. Harris, 2012 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 5235 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., Oct. 24, 2012)



DISPOSITION: Judgment modified in part and affirmed in part; remitted to the trial court for resentencing; appeal from order dated 6/10/1999 dismissed as academic.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the judgment of the trial court (New York) that convicted defendant of six first degree murder counts, attempted first degree murder, and second degree criminal possession of a weapon in violation of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 125.27(1)(a)(vii), (viii); 110.00; 125.27(1)(a)(vii); and 265.03(2), respectively.


OVERVIEW: In the early morning hours of December 7, 1996, defendant entered a Brooklyn social club. After drinking his beer and smoking some cigarettes, defendant went to the bathroom. When he emerged, defendant demanded money from one customer who handed defendant over $ 200. defendant directed the bartender to approach him. As the bartender walked past him, defendant turned and shot him in the head at point-blank range. defendant then proceeded to kill three other patrons, and attempted to kill two others. He was apprehended approximately two weeks later. Following his conviction and death sentence, on appeal, defendant argued 28 assignments of error.
