The appellate court, on direct appeal, found that defendant failed to overcome the presumption of constitutionality with respect to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.20(1)(f). Further, to the extent the trial court may have forecast the type of individual who could avoid jury service when it described the life/death qualification process, there was no prejudice to defendant. Finally, defendant failed to make a claim that his for-cause challenge against a juror pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 270.20(1)(f) should have been granted.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was modified by vacating the sentence, and remitting to the trial court for re- sentencing, and, as so modified, affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Grand Jury - Instructions to Jury - Prosecutor Not Required to Present Mitigating Defense

1. A prosecutor is not required to present mitigating defenses to a grand jury. Unlike exculpatory defenses, which may result in a finding of no criminal liability, mitigating defenses only reduce the gravity of the offense committed. While a grand jury instructed on an exculpatory defense might avoid an unwarranted prosecution, the same result would not follow if it were instructed on a mitigating defense. Accordingly, the prosecutor in a homicide case was not obliged to give the grand jury an instruction on intoxication, which, like a mitigating defense, merely reduces the gravity of the offense by negating an element. The suggestion that the rule should be different in capital cases should not be followed.

Grand Jury - Instructions to Jury - Capital Murder - Mercy-Dispensing Power - Mitigation Relative to Punishment

2. The prosecutor in a capital murder case is not required to instruct the grand jury on its mercy-dispensing power or on the consideration of mitigating evidence relating to punishment. There is no authority mandating that the prosecutor charge the grand jury on mercy, even in a potential capital case. It is presumed that the grand jury will exercise mercy on its own accord. The decision to seek the death penalty is within the discretion of the prosecutor. The determination to impose the death penalty falls to the petit jury, not the grand jury. Thus, the prosecutor is not required to advise the grand jury that it has the power to seek out and consider evidence that mitigates punishment, or inform the grand jury that defendant requested presentation of such evidence.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Predicate Felonies - Violence

3. In determining that the predicate felonies for first-degree felony murder should be those that are potentially the most violent and involve a substantial risk of physical injury (e.g., robbery), the Legislature's decision to exclude felonies of a similar or higher grade (e.g., grand larceny) that lack the inherent potential for violence and physical injury was rational.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Constitutionality of Life/Death Qualification of Jury

4. In a capital murder prosecution, defendant has failed to overcome the presumption of constitutionality with respect to death qualification of prospective jurors under CPL 270.20 (1) (f). Death qualification ensures that prospective jurors are able to consider the death penalty. The statute sets forth the standard and procedure for excluding ineligible jurors. Death qualification at the beginning of the trial has been approved by the United States Supreme Court and is designed to serve the state's legitimate interest in obtaining a single jury that can properly and impartially apply the law to the facts of the case at both the guilt and sentencing phases of a capital trial. Neither the state's constitutional counterpart of the Sixth Amendment right to a jury trial (NY Const, art I, § 2) nor its jurisprudence suggests that defendant is entitled to greater protection under the State Constitution than under federal precepts.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Life/Death Qualification of Jury - Impartial Jury

5. Pretrial death qualification of a jury in a capital case, which ensures that prospective jurors are able to consider the death penalty, does not abrogate a defendant's right to an impartial jury. Defense counsel specifically asked every final panel if any prospective juror believed that, as a result of the qualification process, defendant was presumed guilty, and not one expressed that opinion. While defendant asserts that certain sociological studies, taken collectively, indicate that a death-qualified jury is more likely to convict, those studies provide no solid proof that pretrial death-qualification detrimentally conditions a jury, leads to a more conviction-prone jury, or excludes identifiable groups of people. Death qualification does not impair jury panel diversity. Rather, the State has a valid interest in excluding jurors from a capital trial whose views on the death penalty, whatever they may be, render them unable to perform their sworn duty to try the entire case free of prejudice.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Jury Selection - Judge's Explanation of Life/Death Qualification Process to Prospective Jurors

6. In a capital murder prosecution, to the extent that the trial court may have forecast the type of individual who could avoid jury service when it described the life/death qualification process and stressed that jurors should be open to both available sentencing options after a guilty verdict, defendant was not prejudiced. It is presumed that jurors follow their oaths, answer the questions put to them truthfully, and abide by the court's instructions. However, the way in which a court conducts death/life qualification should encourage honesty and frankness in a juror's responses without seeming to place a value or reward on a "correct" or "appropriate" answer.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Jury Selection - Group Voir Dire

7. CPL 270.16 (1), which directs that the court permit the parties on motion "to examine the prospective jurors individually and outside the presence of the other prospective jurors regarding their qualifications to serve as jurors," does not require only individual voir dire in capital cases. CPL 270.15 (1) (c) states that the court shall permit both parties to examine the prospective jurors "individually or collectively" regarding their qualifications to serve as jurors. There is nothing to suggest that in adding CPL 270.16, the Legislature intended to supersede CPL 270.15.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Life/Death Qualification of Jury - Standard for Excluding Prospective Juror

8. In a capital murder case, the trial court applied the proper standard in determining for-cause challenges during the CPL 270.20 (1) (f) life/death qualification, which is meant to ensure that jurors be open to both available sentencing options after a guilty verdict. The standard established by the United States Supreme Court for determining if prospective jurors may be excluded for cause because of their views on capital punishment is whether those views would prevent or substantially impair the performance of their duties as jurors in accordance with their instructions and their oath. CPL 270.20 (1) (f) provides that jurors may be excluded for cause when their views on the death penalty "preclude" them from performing their duties. The word "preclude" relates to a juror's ability to act impartially and follow a court's instructions. It is not a measurement of the strength of an individual's feelings on the death penalty. The focus is on jurors' ability to serve impartially, and not how the death penalty affects them generally. Therefore, the word "preclude" must be understood as an embodiment of the standard set down by the United States Supreme Court.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Prospective Jurors' Views on Capital Punishment - Particular Case

9. Jurors cannot be excluded for cause from participating on a jury in a capital case where they express conscientious views concerning the death penalty yet make clear that they are able to follow their oaths to act impartially. Because the entire statutory and constitutional line of inquiry is directed toward determining if a juror's attitude for or against the death penalty would affect that person's capability to sit fairly in the particular case at hand, it necessarily follows that a prosecutor's inquiry may properly focus on the jurors' views as they relate to the case at hand, not merely in the abstract.

Crimes - Jurors - Challenge to Jury - Capital Murder Trial - Potential Juror Skeptical of Proffered Mitigating Factor

10. In a capital murder prosecution, the trial court did not erroneously deny defendant's for-cause challenge to a juror who expressed skepticism about the validity of a proffered mitigating factor (i.e., child abuse as a cause of adult behavior), where defendant's challenge was premised solely on CPL 270.20 (1) (f), which provides that a prospective juror may be challenged for cause if his or her attitudes toward the death penalty preclude him or her from rendering an impartial verdict or properly determining the sentence. The juror was never asked if her uncertainties concerning the mitigating factor would affect her views on the death penalty in general or in its application to the case after the verdict. Critically, she was never asked if despite her doubts concerning the significance of the proffered mitigating evidence, she could still vote to give defendant life without parole. The statute is specifically directed at the potential juror whose views concerning the death penalty preclude the juror from serving during either stage of a capital trial. Thus, the statute anticipates a connection between the juror's attitude regarding a mitigator and its effect on that juror's consideration of the appropriate sentence, yet defendant made no such correlation.

Crimes - Disclosure - Notes of Nontestifying Expert

11. In a capital murder prosecution in which defendant claims that he acted under extreme emotional disturbance, the trial court did not exceed its authority by ordering the disclosure of notes used by defendant's nontestifying expert as part of his examination, where defendant's testifying expert relied upon the report of the nontestifying expert in evaluating defendant. Thus, the notes were disclosable as documents relating to defendant's extreme emotional disturbance defense (CPL 240.30 [1] [a]).

Crimes - Witnesses - Rebuttal Witness - Cumulative or Bolstering Testimony Not Admissible

12. In a capital murder prosecution, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing defendant's request to present a rebuttal witness to refute the findings of the prosecution's psychologist. The proposed rebuttal testimony disagreed with the prosecution's psychologist concerning the significance of tests both had performed, and the latter's conclusion that defendant did not suffer any significant neuropsychological impairments. However, the rebuttal witness did not challenge the testing methods or results of the prosecution's witness, only their significance. In essence, the rebuttal opinion as to the tests was no different than that of defendant's expert who initially testified--both relied on the same data. Thus, virtually all of the proffered rebuttal testimony was cumulative to, and corroborative of, the evidence presented on defendant's case-in-chief on the affirmative defense of extreme emotional disturbance.

Crimes - Fair Trial - Testimony of Victims' Family Members

13. In a capital murder prosecution in which testimony of some of the victims' family members exceeded the identification of the victims and supplied information about the victims' personal backgrounds, defendant's constitutional claims that the admission of that testimony deprived him of a fair trial and due process are arguably unpreserved. Defendant did not object and move to strike any testimony that went beyond identification until after all of the victims' family members had testified, thereby depriving the trial court of an opportunity to avoid the error. To the extent that defendant's claims may be preserved, the error was harmless beyond a reasonable doubt in light of the overwhelming evidence of defendant's guilt.

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Prosecutor's Reference during Summation to Defendant's Alleged Smiling during Testimony of Other Witnesses

14. In a capital murder case, defendant's single-word objections to the prosecutor's reference during summation to defendant allegedly having smiled during the testimony of two witnesses fell far short of apprising the court that defendant's constitutional rights against compelled self-incrimination, to due process, to a fair jury trial, and to confront those who testify against him, were allegedly violated. Moreover, defendant's motion to set aside the verdict based on the prosecutor's conduct does not cure his failure to register a specific objection. Were defendant's claims to be reviewed in the interest of justice, the error would be found harmless beyond a reasonable doubt.

Crimes - Instructions - Capital Murder - Defense of Extreme Emotional Disturbance

15. In a capital murder case, the trial court's instruction was sufficient to convey the need for unanimity with respect to the affirmative defense of extreme emotional disturbance. The question asked of the jury on the verdict sheet to which both sides subscribed--whether defendant established the affirmative defense of extreme emotional disturbance--could only be answered yes or no. Prior to deliberations, the jury was instructed that the goal of the process was an unanimous verdict. They were told that they needed to come to an unanimous agreement as to the facts of the case. When the jury inquired whether it had to be unanimous in answering the question on the affirmative defense, they were told "yes." Finally, when each individual juror was polled to ascertain whether the verdict announced by the foreperson was their verdict in all respects, each juror stated "yes." Thus, taking the trial court's instructions, supplemental instructions and the polling into consideration, the jury reasonably understood that its decision with respect to defendant's affirmative defense required unanimity.

Crimes - Murder - Capital Murder - Unconstitutional Plea Procedures

16. In a capital murder case in which defendant was prosecuted under a procedure in which only those defendants who exercised their Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights to plead not guilty and to a jury trial put themselves at risk of death, defendant's sentence of death must be vacated. The procedure in question impermissibly discouraged defendant's assertion of his constitutional rights. Accordingly, the appropriate remedy is to vacate the sentence and remit the case to Supreme Court for resentencing in accordance with Penal Law §§ 60.06 and 70.00 (5).

 

180 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Goshen v. Mut. Life Ins. Co.


No. 92, No. 93


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 314; 774 N.E.2d 1190; 746 N.Y.S.2d 858; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 1900


June 4, 2002, Argued  
July 2, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected September 6, 2002.
Related proceeding at McLean v. Mut. Life Ins. Co. (In re Mut. Life Ins. Co. of N.Y. Premium Litig.), 295 F. Supp. 2d 140, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 20799 (D. Mass., 2003)
Subsequent appeal at, Sub nomine at DeFilippo v. Mut. Life Ins. Co., 2004 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 15351 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, Dec. 16, 2004)



DISPOSITION: Appellate order in Goshen case affirmed in part; appellate order in Scott case affirmed in part and modified in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Two appeals involving New York's Consumer Protection Act were consolidated. In the first action, plaintiff insured appealed the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirming the dismissal of the claim brought against defendant insurers. In the second action, plaintiff consumers appealed the judgment seeking to reinstate their claims against defendant internet provider.


OVERVIEW: In the first action, the insured, a Florida resident, purchased a vanishing premium policy from the insurer. The insured sued under N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 349 claiming the vanishing premium was a deceptive scheme. The trial court dismissed the action because the insured purchased the policy in Florida. In the second action, New York and out-of-state consumers subscribed to the provider's DSL service and were dissatisfied with its performance. They alleged that, contrary to the provider's representations, the service was slow and unreliable and customer service was inadequate. The trial court denied the provider's motion under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(1), (7), and the appellate court reversed, dismissing the consumers' complaint. On appeal, the state high court noted the common issue to both appeals was whether an allegedly deceptive scheme that originated in New York but injured a consumer in a transaction outside the State, constituted an actionable deceptive practice under N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 349(a). After reviewing the language and legislative intent of the statute, the state high court concluded the transaction in which the consumer was deceived had to occur in New York.


OUTCOME: In the first action, the state high court affirmed the judgment. In the second action, the state high court modified the judgment by reinstating the claims as to the New York consumers, but not reinstating the claims as to the out-of-state consumers, and affirmed the judgment as modified.



HEADNOTES

Consumer Protection - Deceptive Acts and Practices - Injury Outside of New York

1. An allegedly deceptive scheme that originates in New York but injures a consumer in a transaction outside the state does not constitute an actionable deceptive act or practice under General Business Law § 349 (a). The statutory reference to deceptive practices in "the conduct of any business, trade or commerce or in the furnishing of any service in this state" unambiguously evinces a legislative intent to address commercial misconduct occurring within New York. "In this state" can only modify "the conduct of any business, trade or commerce [or] the furnishing of any service." The statutory phrase "deceptive acts or practices" refers not to the mere invention of a scheme or marketing strategy, but rather to the actual misrepresentation or omission to a consumer. Thus, to qualify as a prohibited act under the statute, the deception of a consumer must occur in New York. To apply the statute to out-of-state transactions would lead to an unwarranted expansive reading of the statute, contrary to legislative intent, and potentially lead to the nationwide, if not global, application of section 349.

Consumer Protection - Deceptive Acts and Practices - Injury Outside of New York

2. "Hatching a scheme" or originating a marketing campaign in New York in and of itself does not constitute an actionable deceptive act or practice under General Business Law § 349. The origin of any advertising or promotional conduct is irrelevant if the deception itself--that is, the advertisement or promotional package--did not result in a transaction in which the consumer was harmed. Consequently, plaintiffs who cannot allege that they were deceived in New York do not state cognizable causes of action under the statute.

Consumer Protection - False Advertising - Knowingly Deceptive Promotional Representations of Internet Service

3. Plaintiffs have sufficiently stated a claim for deceptive acts and practices or false advertising under General Business Law §§ 349 and 350 where they allege that defendants' so-called "high speed" Internet service was defective owing to malfunctions largely or wholly within defendants' control, that defendants knew this to be the case, and that defendants' promotional representations were therefore knowingly deceptive. Defendants' documentation illustrating a 30-day trial period and the contractual terms and conditions, including a product disclaimer, does not bar plaintiffs' claims for deceptive trade practices at the pleading stage of the proceedings, as such documentation does not establish a defense as a matter of law.

 

181 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Lavalle v. Hayden


No. 66


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 155; 773 N.E.2d 490; 746 N.Y.S.2d 125; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 1553


April 24, 2002, Argued  
June 6, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected August 16, 2002.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, with costs.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a state senator and a retired teacher, sued defendants, the New York State Board of Regents and others, seeking a declaration that the joint ballot procedure authorized by N.Y. Educ. Law § 202 was unconstitutional and enjoining use of that procedure. The trial court dismissed the action and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department (New York) affirmed. The state high court granted leave to appeal.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Educ. Law § 202 allowed the New York State Legislature to use a joint ballot procedure to elect regents to the New York State Board of Regents if the legislature tried but failed to elect a regent by concurrent resolution. A state senator and a retired teacher sought to enjoin regents who were elected by use of the joint ballot procedure from assuming office, and additionally sought a declaration that the joint ballot procedure violated N.Y. Const. art. XI. The state high court held that (1) although the New York State Legislature typically and necessarily functioned as a bicameral body in its lawmaking capacity, it could also function unicamerally when performing duties other than lawmaking; (2) the legislature was acting in a non-lawmaking capacity when it met to elect regents using the joint ballot provisions of N.Y. Educ. Law § 202; and (3) N.Y. Educ. Law § 202 did not violate N.Y. Const. art. XI, §§ 1, 2.


OUTCOME: The state high court affirmed the intermediate appellate court's judgment.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Election of Members of Board of Regents by Legislature

The joint ballot provisions of Education Law § 202 (1), (2), providing for an alternative means of electing members of the State Board of Regents, where the Senate and Assembly fail to elect by concurrent resolution, do not violate NY Constitution, article XI, §§ 1 and 2. The Constitution gives the Legislature control over the regents, and for more than two centuries the joint ballot has been an integral part of the procedure for selecting regents. The quintessential "legislative power," its lawmaking power, unlike the power to elect regents, is directly conferred to and vested in the Senate and the Assembly by the Constitution. The constitutional lawmaking prescription does not, however, negate or undermine the Legislature's ability to convene as a unicameral body, in a distinct, nonlawmaking capacity. The Legislature--whether functioning bicamerally, or sitting in joint session and acting unicamerally--is nevertheless the "legislature" as it is understood in article XI.

 

182 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Allstate Ins. Co. v. Serio


No. 46


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


98 N.Y.2d 198; 774 N.E.2d 180; 746 N.Y.S.2d 416; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 975


March 14, 2002, Argued  
April 30, 2002, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Corrected August 30, 2002.



DISPOSITION: Certified questions No. 1, 2 and 3 answered in the negative; question No. 4 not answered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, noting that N.Y. Ins. Law § 2610(b) had not been authoritatively interpreted by the instant court, certified questions on the statute to the court in a dispute concerning the regulation of insurance company referrals to repair shops.


OVERVIEW: The court of appeals found that a circular letter and a settlement letter exceeded the requirements of § 2610(b). The state department of insurance did not show how the letter advanced legislative intent, nor did the department evince a factual basis supporting its expansive construction of the regulation as prohibiting the (1) distribution to insureds of brochures or other literature that mentioned or described a repair program or a guarantee of repair programs, (2) posting of signs at insurer locations that mentioned or described a repair program, (3) initiating of communication that could prompt an insured to request a repair shop recommendation or information from the insurer, (4) discussion of an insured's repair shop choice, or (5) mentioning of the mere existence of § 2610(b) to an insured. Because the settlement letter mirrored the provisions contained in the circular letter, it was improper. The rejection of a proposed preferred repairer promotion was based on restrictions not supported by § 2610(b). The promotion merely required a prospective claimant to agree to use a preferred repairer for a reduced contract fee.


OUTCOME: Certified questions one, two, and three were answered in the negative and certified question four was not answered as unnecessary.


HEADNOTES

Insurance - Automobile Insurance - Regulation of "Steering" Claimants to Particular Repair Shops

1. Actions taken by the Department of Insurance pursuant to its interpretation of Insurance Law § 2610 (b), which is intended to discourage the use of "referral" body shops by insurers and to prevent "steering" claimants to particular shops, are invalid. The literal language of the statute restricts when an insurance company can make recommendations that repairs be performed at a particular shop. It does not regulate speech on subjects other than recommendations or suggestions about particular shops, nor regulate the content or placement of material promoting an insurance company's repair program, nor regulate discussion or distribution of its text. Accordingly, the Department may not prohibit an insurer from distributing to insureds brochures that mention or describe a repair program or a guarantee of repair programs, posting signs at insurer locations that mention or describe a repair program, initiating communication that might prompt an insured to request a repair shop recommendation or information from the insurer, discussing an insured's repair shop choice, or mentioning the mere existence of section 2610 (b) to an insured.

Insurance - Automobile Insurance - Regulation of "Steering" Claimants to Particular Repair Shops

2. The rejection by the Department of Insurance of an insurer's proposed preferred repairer promotion, in which the insurer would reduce the cost of coverage if the insured agreed to have repairs made at body shops recommended by the insurer, was based on restrictions not supported by Insurance Law § 2610 (b). The promotion does not require that an insurance company request, recommend or suggest a particular repair shop while an insurer has an active claim, but rather requires a prospective claimant to agree to use a preferred repairer for a reduced contract fee. Accordingly, inasmuch as the statutory restrictions on recommending particular body shops are implicated only when an insured has an active claim, section 2610 (b) does not provide a ground for rejecting the preferred repairer promotion in question.

 

183 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Horne


No. 24


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


97 N.Y.2d 404; 767 N.E.2d 132; 740 N.Y.S.2d 675; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 488


February 7, 2002, Argued  
March 14, 2002, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order of the Appellate Division affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from an order of the Appellate Division (New York) affirming a trial court's inclusion, in her sentence for filing false instruments with the county social services department, of a requirement that she make restitution to the department in the amount overpaid.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was prosecuted for various theft crimes and filing false instruments after her county social services department discovered that she had failed to note income from various jobs in her filings for welfare benefits. She was convicted and sentenced to probation, subject to a restitution order. The high court upheld the award of restitution, and its amount, holding that N.Y. Penal Law § 60.27 required consideration of, and allowed for awards of, restitution in all felony sentencing proceedings. Although the award exceeded the statutory cap, this was permissible because it represented the actual losses, in overpayments, suffered by the social services department, the victim. The restitution order was not an unconstitutional sentencing increase under the rule of Apprendi, because such orders fell squarely within the statutory sentencing range.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order.



HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Restitution - Receiving Overpayments of Social Services Benefits - "Offense"

1. In a prosecution arising out of defendant's failure to include accurate income information on social services benefit recertification forms, resulting in her conviction of three counts of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree, the sentencing court did not err in directing defendant to repay the benefit overpayments she received as a result of filing the false documents. Penal Law § 60.27 (1) allows a court to order a "person convicted of an offense" to "make restitution of the fruits of [that] offense or reparation for the actual out-of-pocket loss caused thereby." The term "offense" is broadly defined and because there is no statutory limitation on the types of criminal conduct that can support a sentence of restitution or reparation, restitution is a viable sentence for any crime provided there is a recognizable victim who has suffered "actual out-of-pocket loss" or there are discernible "fruits of the offense."

Crimes - Sentence - Restitution - Receiving Overpayments of Social Services Benefits - Intent to Defraud

2. Offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree falls within the broad definition of "offense" contained in Penal Law § 60.27, which permits a court to impose restitution or reparation as part of a sentence. Although defendant, who was convicted of the aforementioned felony arising out of her failure to include accurate income information on social services benefit recertification forms, maintained that she lacked a criminal intent, she did not contest the proof adduced at trial that she failed to disclose the income she received from four employers on recertification forms filed during the benefit periods. In finding defendant guilty, the jury necessarily concluded that defendant offered written instruments containing false statements or information "with intent to defraud the state or any political subdivision" (see Penal Law § 175.35). When it ordered restitution, the sentencing court found that defendant had received overpayments as a result of the filing of false documents. The record therefore supports an order of restitution or reparation.

Crimes - Sentence - Restitution - Receiving Overpayments of Social Services Benefits - Acquittal of "Theft" Offenses

3. In a prosecution arising out of defendant's failure to include accurate income information on social services benefit recertification forms, the fact that defendant was acquitted of welfare fraud, misuse of food stamps and grand larceny does not impugn the legality of the otherwise authorized sentence of restitution imposed, in addition to probation, upon defendant's conviction for three counts of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree. Defendant's acquittal of the so-called "theft offenses" does not lead to the conclusion that the jury must have determined that the local social services agency did not suffer any out-of-pocket losses. An acquittal of criminal charges is not equivalent to a finding of innocence, but stands for the proposition that a jury was not convinced of defendant's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Where a jury verdict is not repugnant, it is imprudent to speculate concerning the factual determinations that underlay the verdict, because what might appear to be an irrational verdict may actually constitute a jury's permissible exercise of mercy or leniency.

Crimes - Appeal - Matters Reviewable

4. In a prosecution arising out of defendant's failure to include accurate income information on social services benefit recertification forms, resulting in her conviction of three counts of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree, the sentencing court did not err in directing defendant to repay the benefit overpayments she received as a result of filing the false documents. Defendant's argument that the sentencing court erred in relying on the charges of which she was acquitted when imposing its restitution sentence need not be addressed because there is no indication that the court considered facts relating to the acquitted offenses when it directed restitution. Moreover, to the extent that defendant challenges the amount of the restitution order as lacking record support, that claim is not properly reviewable since defendant did not request a hearing to determine the sum of benefit overpayments or otherwise challenge the amount of the restitution order during the sentencing proceeding.

Crimes - Sentence - Restitution - Receiving Overpayments of Social Services Benefits - Statutory "Cap" on Amount of Restitution

5. The sentencing court did not err in ordering defendant, who received overpayments of social services benefits, to make restitution to a local social services department in an amount over $ 15,000 following her conviction of three counts of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree. Although paragraph (a) of Penal Law § 60.27 (5) provides that, except with the consent of defendant or in instances where restitution is ordered as a condition of probation or conditional discharge, "the amount of restitution or reparation required by the court shall not exceed fifteen thousand dollars in the case of a conviction for a felony," that provision is qualified by paragraph (b), which allows a court to order restitution in excess of that amount as long as the sum is "limited to the return of the victim's property, including money, or the equivalent value thereof." Defendant was convicted of three felonies covering three distinct benefit periods, and the amount of restitution attributable to each offense could be allocated separately, bringing the amount ordered for each offense well under $ 15,000. Even if defendant had been convicted of only one offense, the amount in excess of $ 15,000 would meet the dictates of section 60.27 (5) because the entire amount of defendant's restitution order was intended to reimburse the social services department for the equivalent value of benefit overpayments she received.

Crimes - Sentence - Restitution - Factual Determinations by Sentencing Court

6. The sentencing court did not make improper factual determinations in ordering defendant, who received overpayments of social services benefits, to make restitution to a local social services department. Restitution falls within the range of sentences available for any offense in New York; it is not a post-conviction sentencing enhancement mechanism. While Penal Law § 60.27 limits the types of expenses reimbursable in restitution orders exceeding $ 15,000 for a felony or $ 10,000 for a misdemeanor, the statute does not restrict the maximum amount of restitution that can be awarded. Accordingly, a sentencing court is not increasing the maximum sentence available when it makes factual determinations affecting restitution, but is merely issuing a sentence within the authorized statutory range. Because the restitution order in question does nothing more than compensate the social services department for losses sustained as a result of defendant's criminal conduct, it does not violate the principle that a court may not increase the penalty for a crime beyond the prescribed statutory maximum without submitting to a jury and proving beyond a reasonable doubt any fact upon which the increase is based.

Crimes - Right to be Present at Trial - Sentencing

7. Reversal of defendant's conviction of three counts of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree is not required where defendant was absent from the courtroom when the court denied her motion to set aside the verdict and discharged the jury the day after the verdict was announced. Inasmuch as the proceeding at issue involved only questions of law or procedure, defendant's presence was not required.

 

184 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mower


No. 9


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


97 N.Y.2d 239; 765 N.E.2d 839; 739 N.Y.S.2d 343; 2002 N.Y. LEXIS 183


January 8, 2002, Argued  
February 14, 2002, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant had pled guilty to murder with the understanding he would receive life without parole. While his direct appeal was pending before the Appellate Division (New York), defendant initiated a N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10 proceeding to vacate his conviction asserting a subsequent case rendered his plea invalid and his sentence illegal. The trial court denied the application. The appellate division affirmed.


OVERVIEW: The People never filed a N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 250.40 notice of intent to seek the death penalty against defendant for killing his parents. During the plea colloquy, defendant withdrew his omnibus motion, which included claims that certain provisions of the first degree murder statute were unconstitutionally vague and that the integrity of the grand jury proceeding was impaired. Arguing that invalidation of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 220.10(5)(e) and N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 220.30(3)(b)(vii) by a New York case, Hynes, effectively eliminated any statutory authorization for a sentence of life imprisonment without parole upon a plea to murder in the first degree, defendant contended he was entitled to be resentenced to an indeterminate prison term of 20-to-25 years to life. Because the trial court's sentencing authority was not derived from the plea provisions struck in Hynes, the court of appeals disagreed. Defendant did not raise the alleged constitutional infirmity before he pleaded guilty or was sentenced by the trial court, and it was therefore unpreserved.


OUTCOME: The order of the appellate division was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Murder - Validity of Plea under Death Penalty Statute and Imposition of Life Sentence without Parole

1. In a prosecution for first degree murder where no notice to seek a sentence of death was filed, defendant, who never faced the death penalty and pleaded guilty, may be sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole. The invalidation of certain plea provisions of the State's death penalty law by the Court of Appeals did not eliminate the statutory authorization for a sentence of life imprisonment without parole upon a plea of guilty to murder in the first degree, since the trial court's sentencing authority is not derived from those statutes. CPL 400.27, which sets forth sentencing procedures in death penalty cases, provides that the People may elect not to seek the death penalty "at any time," and that in such case the court "may sentence * * * defendant to life imprisonment without parole." The phrase "at any time" demonstrates that the statute applies to cases in which the People have declined to seek a death sentence, whether before or after expiration of the 120-day period for filing the notice of intent to seek the death penalty. If the People do not pursue a death sentence, the sentencing authority that would otherwise be vested in the jury remains with the trial court. CPL 400.27 applies to a first degree murder "conviction," which is defined as "the entry of a plea of guilty * * * or a verdict of guilty" (CPL 1.20 [13]). Thus, the authority to impose a sentence of life imprisonment without parole exists whether a defendant's conviction is by guilty plea or jury verdict.

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Legality of Sentence

2. In an appeal of a judgment convicting defendant, upon his plea of guilty, of first degree murder and sentencing defendant to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole, defendant's challenge to the legality of his sentence, even though the product of a negotiated plea agreement, is reviewable because the right to be sentenced as provided by law creates a narrow exception to the requirement that arguments must be properly preserved in order to be reviewed by the Court of Appeals.

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Voluntariness of Guilty Plea

3. In an appeal to the Court of Appeals from a judgment convicting defendant, upon his plea of guilty, of first degree murder and sentencing defendant to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole, and from an order denying defendant's CPL 440.10 motion to vacate the judgment of conviction and sentence, defendant's contention that his conviction was affected by a mistake of law because he pleaded guilty pursuant to statutory provisions later invalidated by the Court of Appeals, thus rendering his negotiated guilty plea invalid as involuntary, is not reviewable. Defendant presents an issue of law founded on a federal constitutional principle established more than a quarter-century ago. However, defendant did not raise this alleged constitutional infirmity before he pleaded guilty or was sentenced, and it is therefore unpreserved. Because defendant's claim does not involve factual matters beyond the scope of the record or legal issues which could not have been asserted before the final judgment of conviction, it was not the proper subject of a CPL 440.10 motion. Nor does defendant allege a facial defect in his allocution that would permit review by the Court of Appeals notwithstanding his failure to preserve the issue.

Crimes - Appeal - Matters Reviewable

4. In an appeal of a judgment convicting defendant, upon his plea of guilty, of first degree murder, defendant's contention that certain portions of the first degree murder statute are unconstitutionally vague was abandoned when he expressly withdrew all motions pending before Supreme Court, thereby precluding the creation of a record or a ruling subject to appellate review. Defendant's challenge to the integrity of the Grand Jury proceeding, which was also asserted in the omnibus motion he retracted, was likewise abandoned, and is therefore unreviewable. Although Supreme Court had issued a ruling in connection with defendant's request for "heightened due process" consideration, he forfeited his right to appeal this issue by pleading guilty.

 

185 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Patrolmen's Benevolent Ass'n of N.Y., Inc. v. City of New York


No. 171


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


97 N.Y.2d 378; 767 N.E.2d 116; 740 N.Y.S.2d 659; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 3813; 169 L.R.R.M. 3008


November 14, 2001, Argued  
December 20, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: Appellate court order modified in part and affirmed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city and its collective bargaining board sought review of affirmance, by the Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York), of a ruling, in consolidated declaratory judgment actions by the city and appellee police union, that 1998 N.Y. Laws ch. 641 gave the state's collective bargaining agency exclusive jurisdiction over impasse and scope of bargaining issues.


OVERVIEW: New York's Taylor Law, N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 200 et seq., permitted local governments to establish their own collective bargaining boards, in addition to the state agency, the New York State Public Employment Relations Board (PERB). 1998 N.Y. Laws ch. 641 amended N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 212 to give the PERB jurisdiction over disputes between police and fire unions in the four counties that had their own boards, in the event that negotiations reached an impasse. New York City and its local board resisted the police union's efforts to transfer a dispute to the PERB, arguing that the amendment was an unconstitutional special law, but the high court held that it did not violate N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2, because it covered all four counties and addressed a substantial state concern. The amendment did not, however, deprive local boards of jurisdiction to address scope of bargaining issues.


OUTCOME: The court modified the declaratory judgment to hold that the local collective bargaining agency retained concurrent jurisdiction over scope of bargaining issues, but otherwise affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Special Law Serving Substantial State Concerns - Collective Bargaining between New York City and Public Safety Unions

1. Chapter 641 of the Laws of 1998, which amended the Taylor Law to allow police and fire unions in any municipality with a local impasse resolution system to take their collective bargaining disputes to the State Public Employment Relations Board (PERB), is constitutional and enforceable. Chapter 641 is a "special law" that serves a substantial State concern, and thus, the home rule requirements of the State Constitution were not implicated. While chapter 641, by its terms, applies to all local governments, its actual effect is a restriction targeted at only the four localities that exercised the option to use a local, alternate administrative dispute resolution body. Although chapter 641 is a special law, it was enacted in furtherance of and bears a reasonable relationship to the substantial State-wide concern of fostering orderly resolution of collective bargaining disputes involving police and fire bargaining units in order to enhance public safety and prevent the loss or interruption of vital public services. Further, fulfillment of this legislative purpose is rationally served by chapter 641, which mandates that all local governments allow their police and fire unions access to PERB impasse procedures in resolving public sector labor disputes.

Civil Service - Public Employees' Fair Employment Act - Impasse Jurisdiction over Collective Bargaining Disputes between New York City and Public Safety Unions

2. In a collective bargaining dispute between the City of New York and a public safety union, once the union opts to seek impasse resolution by the State Public Employment Relations Board (PERB) and PERB declares an impasse, chapter 641 of the Laws of 1998 gives the Board exclusive jurisdiction to resolve such an impasse. Until such time, the City Board of Collective Bargaining (BCB) retains jurisdiction to determine scope of bargaining outside of the impasse context. Accordingly, PERB does not have exclusive jurisdiction over scope of bargaining disputes between the City and its public safety unions. In order to determine whether an impasse exists as to "conditions of employment," PERB must be authorized to determine what qualifies as a proper condition of employment because if the impasse does not relate to a condition of employment, PERB has no authority to render assistance. Because chapter 641 did not amend Civil Service Law § 205 (5) (d), which authorizes BCB to exercise jurisdiction over improper practice charges, or alter BCB's improper practice jurisdiction, BCB retains jurisdiction to decide whether an issue constitutes a mandatory subject of bargaining in the context of an improper practice proceeding. Accordingly, the Legislature has accorded both agencies jurisdiction over scope of bargaining in negotiations between a public safety union and the City.

 

186 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Buechel v. Bain


No. 134


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


97 N.Y.2d 295; 766 N.E.2d 914; 740 N.Y.S.2d 252; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 3814


October 16, 2001, Argued  
December 20, 2001, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Writ of certiorari denied: Bain v. Buechel, 2002 U.S. LEXIS 3857 (U.S. 2002).



DISPOSITION: Appellate order affirmed with costs; certified question answered in the affirmative.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff clients sued defendant attorneys, alleging breach of fiduciary and ethical obligations and legal malpractice. The trial court ruled that its judgment in a prior action filed by the attorneys' former partner was controlling and it awarded judgment to the clients. The attorneys appealed and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York) affirmed. The case was certified to the state's highest court.


OVERVIEW: Two clients brought an action seeking to terminate all interests which their former attorneys had in a trust that was created to compensate the attorneys for legal services. That action followed a prior and separate lawsuit (first action) that was filed by a former partner in the attorneys' law firm against the clients and raised the issue of whether the trust was valid. Although the attorneys were added as parties to the first action, they chose not to participate actively in that action, but instead moved to stay the second action until the first action was resolved. In the first action, the trial court ruled that the trust was invalid. Thereafter, the second action was tried and the trial court invoked the doctrine of res judicata to rule a second time that the trust was invalid. The state's highest court held that because the issues in the first action and the second action were the same, the doctrine of res judicata applied. This was especially true because the attorneys knew that the validity of the trust was being vigorously contested in the first action and that an adverse ruling would have serious consequences for them.


OUTCOME: The state's highest court affirmed the intermediate appellate court's judgment.



HEADNOTES

Judgments - Collateral Estoppel - Person in Privity with Party against Whom Issue Decided - Former Law Partners

1. For the purpose of applying collateral estoppel to preclude defendant attorneys from relitigating the validity of fee arrangements determined to be illegal in an earlier action, they were in privity with their former law partner against whom the issue was decided. Defendants were parties in the prior action, which was commenced by their former partner. Although they were not named in the counterclaim in which, after extensive pretrial and trial proceedings involving defendants, the legality of the fee arrangements was decided, defendants and their former partner were co-signatories to the fee agreement and co-beneficiaries to the trust proceeds arising from the agreement. Defendants' rights to receive payments were coextensive with those of their former partner and derived from the identical arrangement entered into when they were partners. Moreover, defendants themselves recognized that adjudication of their former partner's conduct as partner or agent of the law firm would have consequences for them. Thus, their interests were aligned with respect to the fee arrangements for the purpose of applying collateral estoppel.

Judgments - Collateral Estoppel - Full and Fair Opportunity to Litigate - Litigation Tactics

2. Collateral estoppel is available to preclude defendant attorneys from relitigating the validity of fee arrangements determined to be illegal in a counterclaim in an earlier action, notwithstanding that they were not initially named in the counterclaim and successfully opposed its later assertion against them. They were parties in that action with notice of the issues to be decided and, as such, could not sit by idly while the contract involving the fee arrangements, to which they were also parties, was judicially construed without being precluded by the result. Defendants cannot be rewarded for their conscious, tactical decision not to take a more active role in that litigation by now allowing relitigation of the very same issues and facts.

Judgments - Collateral Estoppel - Identity of Issue

3. For the purpose of applying collateral estoppel to preclude defendant attorneys from relitigating the validity of fee arrangements determined to be illegal as against their former law partner in an earlier action, the issues in the present action in which defendants seek to enforce certain agreements that incorporate those fee arrangements are identical with those already litigated and decided in the prior action.

Judgments - Collateral Estoppel - Full and Fair Opportunity to Litigate

4. For the purpose of applying collateral estoppel to preclude defendant attorneys from relitigating the validity of fee arrangements determined to be illegal as against their former law partner in an earlier action, defendants have failed to establish the lack of a full and fair opportunity to litigate the validity of the fee arrangements in that action. The former partner, with whom defendants were in privity, vigorously defended the validity of the trust that was dependent on the fee arrangements. In addition, defendants were not just nominal parties but, as beneficiaries of the trust, were essential parties whose rights were affected by the outcome of the prior action. Defendants produced documents for the litigation, received copies of select documents used in the trial and agreed to testify as witnesses, before changing their minds at the last minute. Although Supreme Court denied a motion to join defendants in the counterclaim in the prior action that disposed of the essential issue, that fact does not undermine the holding that the fee agreement was unenforceable. Additionally, while defendants were authorized to seek a stay of the present action pending a determination in the prior one, intending to invoke the benefits of the judgment if the outcome was favorable to them, under the circumstances this fact may be taken into account in analyzing whether defendants should be bound by the prior determination.

Courts - Jurisdiction - Peripheral Patent Issue Not Preemptive

5. An action alleging that an attorney fee arrangement and a corresponding trust agreement are illegal and unenforceable is not subject to exclusive Federal jurisdiction where plaintiff inventors are claiming that defendant attorneys failed to disclose potential conflicts of interest in their representation concerning plaintiffs' application for a patent. Plaintiffs did not plead any substantive questions of patent law as an element of the claims asserted against defendants. Rather, the case addresses the necessary disclosures attorneys must make and the ethical obligations they must maintain in the course of their interaction with clients. Although Federal patent law recognizes that attorneys may receive an interest in patents in lieu of traditional fee arrangements, the need for disclosure mandated by the Code of Professional Responsibility governing the practice of law in this State is not obviated.

 

187 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Robinson


No. 141, No. 142, No. 143


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


97 N.Y.2d 341; 767 N.E.2d 638; 741 N.Y.S.2d 147; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 3790


October 10, 2001, Argued  
December 18, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: In Robinson and Glenn cases, trial court orders affirmed: in Reynolds case, order reversed, defendant's motion to suppress denied, accusatory instruments reinstated; case remitted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: On consolidated appeal, two defendants appealed the Supreme Court, Appellate Division (New York) affirmances of their convictions, and in the third case, the People appealed a county court's reversal of defendant's conviction. The issue in all three was whether pretextual traffic stops were permissible under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 12.


OVERVIEW: In three different cases, with varying results upon defendants' motions to suppress, police officers who had observed suspicious conduct inside automobiles stopped the cars after having observed traffic infractions, and arrests for more serious offenses resulted. Federal constitutional law had already settled, in the Whren case, that such stops did not violate U.S. Const. amend. IV when they were based on actual violations of law, but it had not yet been determined whether such actions were permissible under N.Y. Const. art. I, § 12, which contained identical language to that of the Fourth Amendment. The high court adopted the rule of Whren, after noting that victims of racial profiling had other remedies under New York law, and that police officers could not otherwise be said to be acting arbitrarily when they acted in response to actual violations of law. The fact that many New Yorkers violated traffic laws was irrelevant.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgments in the cases in which orders to suppress had been denied. In the third case, it reversed the order of suppression, denied the motion to suppress, reinstated the charges, and remitted to the trial court for further consistent proceedings.



HEADNOTES

Crimes - Unlawful Search and Seizure - Validity of Pretextual Traffic Stop - Probable Cause to Believe Driver Committed Traffic Infraction

1. Whren v United States (517 US 806), which held that if a police officer has probable cause to detain a person temporarily for a traffic violation, that seizure does not violate the Fourth Amendment even though the underlying reason for the stop might have been to investigate some other matter, is adopted as a matter of state law. Thus, a police officer who has probable cause to believe a driver has committed a traffic infraction does not violate article I, § 12 of the New York State Constitution when the officer, whose primary motivation is to conduct another investigation, stops the vehicle. In making that determination of probable cause, neither the primary motivation of the officer nor a determination of what a reasonable traffic officer would have done under the circumstances is relevant. The Vehicle and Traffic Law provides an objective standard for the police to follow, and regulating the ability of the police to stop a vehicle when there is probable cause to believe that a traffic regulation has been violated does little to expand the rights of the accused. However, the scope, duration and intensity of the seizure, as well as any search made by the police subsequent to the stop, remain subject to the strictures of article I, § 12 and judicial review.

Crimes - Unlawful Search and Seizure - Validity of Pretextual Traffic Stop - Arbitrariness

2. In determining the legality of police conduct in the context of a traffic stop by officers whose primary motivation was to conduct another investigation, arbitrariness is not an added inquiry separate and distinct from probable cause. A police officer who can articulate credible facts establishing reasonable cause to believe that someone has violated a law has established a reasonable basis to effectuate a stop. There is no basis to distinguish violations of New York's criminal laws from infractions of the Vehicle and Traffic Law. While New Yorkers may ubiquitously disobey parts of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, that does not render its commands unenforceable. Because the Vehicle and Traffic Law provides an objective grid upon which to measure probable cause, a stop based on that standard is not arbitrary in the context of constitutional search and seizure jurisprudence. It is the violation of the Vehicle and Traffic Law that both triggers an officer's authority to make a stop and limits the officer's discretion. Moreover, the "reasonable police officer" test, which ties the legality of the police officers' conduct to the determination of whether a reasonable traffic police officer would have made the stop, should not be followed since it would result in inappropriate selective enforcement of traffic laws.

 

188 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Silver v. Pataki


No. 94


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 532; 755 N.E.2d 842; 730 N.Y.S.2d 482; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 1989


May 3, 2001, Argued  
July 10, 2001, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Reargument denied by Silver v. Pataki, 96 N.Y.2d 938, 759 N.E.2d 376, 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 3136, 733 N.Y.S.2d 377 (2001)
Later proceeding at Silver v. Pataki, 192 Misc. 2d 117, 744 N.Y.S.2d 821, 2002 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 706 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., 2002)
Summary judgment granted by, Judgment entered by Silver v. Pataki, 2011 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4896 (N.Y. Sup. Ct., June 17, 2011)



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the order of the Appellate Division should be modified, without costs, by denying defendant's motion to dismiss the complaint insofar as it is brought by plaintiff as a Member of the New York State Assembly and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant governor appealed the denial of his motion dismiss plaintiff member/speaker of the state assembly's declaratory judgment action seeking a determination that the governor's line-item veto of certain non-appropriated items violated N.Y. Const. art. IV, § 7. The Appellate Division reversed, and the court of appeals granted review.


OVERVIEW: After the governor exercised his line-item veto power 55 times to remove certain provisions from non-appropriation bills, the member/speaker brought a declaratory action to determine if the governor had authority to do so. The court of appeals held that the member/speaker had the capacity to sue individually but lacked authority to sue on behalf of the entire legislature. He was responsible for protecting the integrity of his vote. However, the state constitution did not give him representative authority and the assembly had not passed a resolution expressing its will that he engage in the litigation on its behalf. As a member, he had undoubtedly suffered an injury in fact with respect to the alleged nullification of his vote and, therefore, had standing.


OUTCOME: The order of the appellate division was modified by denying the motion to dismiss insofar as it was brought by the plaintiff as a member of the state assembly and, as so modified, was affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Parties - Capacity to Sue - Member of State Assembly - Improper Veto by Governor

1. Plaintiff, as a member of the State Assembly, who has the power and responsibility to consider and vote on legislation, has the capacity to bring an action to vindicate the effectiveness of his vote where he alleges that the Governor has acted improperly so as to usurp or nullify his vote by vetoing items in "non-appropriation" bills. As a member of the Assembly, plaintiff is constitutionally responsible for exercising legislative power, and that responsibility necessarily includes continuing concern for protecting the integrity of one's vote and implies the power to challenge in court the effectiveness of a vote that has allegedly been unconstitutionally nullified. Plaintiff's functional responsibilities as a legislator are not at an end once a bill is voted upon and leaves the Assembly. Legislators and the districts they represent could be disenfranchised from the budget process if stripped of the capacity to sue when confronted with allegedly unlawful or unconstitutional conduct of others that directly affects their official responsibilities.

Parties - Capacity to Sue - Speaker of State Assembly - Improper Veto by Governor

2. Plaintiff, as the Speaker of the State Assembly, does not have the inherent capacity to bring an action on behalf of that body to vindicate the effectiveness of his vote where he alleges that the Governor has acted improperly so as to usurp or nullify his vote by vetoing items in "non-appropriation" bills. The Constitution does not give the Speaker representative authority for the body over which he presides; nor has the Assembly passed a resolution expressing its will that the Speaker engage in such litigation. The Assembly Speaker is nominally a constitutional officer, but his express statutory powers are circumscribed; other duties are merely administrative. None of his specific responsibilities are broad enough to confer on him any special implied authority to seek judicial review on behalf of the interests of the Assembly in general.

Parties - Standing - Member of State Assembly - Improper Veto by Governor - Injury in Fact

3. Plaintiff, as a member of the State Assembly, has suffered an injury in fact sufficient to confer standing on him to maintain an action challenging the Governor's line-item veto power where he alleges that the Governor acted improperly so as to usurp or nullify his vote by vetoing items in "non-appropriation" bills. As a member of the Assembly who voted with the majority in favor of the budget legislation in question, plaintiff undoubtedly has suffered an injury in fact with respect to the alleged unconstitutional nullification of his vote sufficient to confer standing. Such a direct and personal injury is clearly within a legislator's zone of interest and unquestionably represents a concrete and particularized harm. Plaintiff is not seeking to obtain a result in a courtroom which he failed to gain in the halls of the Legislature. A controlling bloc of legislators (a number sufficient to enact or defeat legislation) is not a prerequisite to plaintiff's standing. His injury in the nullification of his personal vote continues to exist whether or not other legislators who have suffered the same injury decide to join in the suit. Moreover, the existence of other possible political remedies does not negate the injury in fact, and the fact that other parties may also be aggrieved by some of the contested vetoes does not diminish the direct injury suffered by plaintiff as a member of the Legislature.

 

189 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Edwards


No. 92


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 445; 754 N.E.2d 169; 729 N.Y.S.2d 410; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 2015


May 2, 2001, Argued  
July 5, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: On the People's appeal, order reversed, plea reinstated and case remitted to the Appellate Division, Third Department, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein. Defendant's appeal dismissed upon the ground that he is not adversely affected by the Appellate Division order within the meaning of CPL 450.90(1).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: A judge of the Court of Appeals of New York granted leave to both the People and defendant to appeal the appellate division's order upholding defendant's guilty plea to first-degree murder in order to determine whether the plea impermissibly burdened defendant's Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in exchange for dropping of the State's intent to seek the death penalty. After the plea had been entered but before sentencing, a judicial decision in a different matter was made that struck the plea provisions from the State's death penalty statute. Defendant moved to withdraw his plea, claiming it was invalid as a result of the decision. The appellate division reversed the conviction and restored the parties to their pre-plea positions because the plea rested upon a faulty premise. The court of appeals reviewed similar federal Supreme Court decisions and found no constitutional violations since the guilty plea was voluntarily made. Absent misrepresentation or other impermissible conduct by the State, a voluntary plea was not invalid merely because later judicial decisions indicated that the plea was based on a faulty premise.


OUTCOME: The order was reversed, the plea was reinstated, and the case was remitted for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Appeal - Matters Reviewable - Underlying Order Not Adverse to Defendant

1. Defendant's appeal from an order of the Appellate Division reversing a judgment convicting defendant, upon his guilty plea, of first degree murder, vacating defendant's plea and sentence, and restoring the indictment to the pre-plea stage with the notice of intent to seek the death penalty reinstated, must be dismissed. Although the underlying order granted defendant only partial relief, it was nonetheless not adverse to defendant within the meaning of CPL 450.90 (1) and, thus, the Court of Appeals is not empowered to review defendant's challenges to that order insofar as it upheld the denial of his suppression motion and reinstated the death notice.

Crimes - Plea of Guilty - Withdrawal of Plea - Capital Murder - Validity of Plea Resting on Faulty Premise

2. In a capital murder case, defendant's guilty plea was not rendered invalid by Matter of Hynes v Tomei (92 NY2d 613), which found unconstitutional plea provisions permitting a capital defendant to enter a guilty plea only with the consent of the People and permission of the court, and only when the agreed-upon sentence was either life without parole or a term of years, where Hynes was decided after the acceptance of the plea but prior to sentencing. Absent misrepresentation or other impermissible conduct by state agents, a voluntary plea of guilty intelligently made in light of the then applicable law does not become vulnerable because later judicial decisions indicate that the plea rested on a faulty premise. The fact that defendant did not anticipate Hynes does not impugn the truth or reliability of his plea.

Crimes - Plea of Guilty - Withdrawal of Plea - Capital Murder - Validity of Plea Where Defendant Faced with Choice between Exercising Trial Rights and Risking Death or Waiving Trial Rights and Avoiding Death

3. In a capital murder case, not all guilty pleas to capital offenses are invalid where a defendant is faced with the choice of exercising Fifth and Sixth Amendment trial rights and risking death, or waiving those rights and pleading guilty in order to avoid that risk. An otherwise valid plea is not involuntary because induced by defendant's desire to limit the possible maximum penalty to less than that authorized if there is a jury trial. Accordingly, defendant's guilty plea, even if it had been the exclusive means by which he avoided exposure to the risk of imposition of the death penalty, did not, standing alone, violate defendant's Fifth or Sixth Amendment rights.

 

190 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. O'Hara


No. 78


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 378; 754 N.E.2d 155; 729 N.Y.S.2d 396; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 1828


April 24, 2001, Argued  
June 14, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed his conviction of seven crimes arising from his fraudulent filing of a false voter registration form and voting in five separate elections in an election district in which he did not reside, claiming that residency definitions under N.Y. Elec. Law § 1-104(22) were vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant lived in an apartment building located within a voting district. After the building was put into a second district when the boundaries of the election district were redrawn defendant completed and filed a new voter registration form specifying that he resided at a different location within the first district. After his conviction and two appeals, he again appealed claiming that the residency definitions of § 1-104(22) were vague. He also claimed that the trial court improperly instructed the jury on residency. The appellate court recognized that a person could have more than one residence. It held that the jury was not asked to determine if defendant chose the correct residence, but only if he took up the second residence solely for voting purposes. As a result, the jury charge was not confusing.


OUTCOME: The convictions were affirmed.



HEADNOTES

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Illegal Voting - Definition of "Residence"

1. In a prosecution for offering a false instrument for filing, false (voter) registration, and illegal voting arising from defendant's alleged maintenance of two residences, defendant's arguments that the Election Law definition of "residence" cannot be applied literally in a case of dual residency, and that a literal application of Election Law § 1-104 (22), wherein "residence" is defined, is vague and unconstitutional, are unpreserved for review by the Court of Appeals. Defendant, during the jury charge conference, did not object to the specific language of the charge and did not raise any of the constitutional issues now asserted.

Crimes - Instructions - Illegal Voting - Definition of "Residence"

2. Defendant, who allegedly maintained two residences in different voting districts, was properly convicted of offering a false instrument for filing, false (voter) registration, and illegal voting arising from his fraudulent filing of a false voter registration form and voting in an election district in which he did not reside. The trial court's jury charge did not dictate a guilty verdict. The crucial determination whether a particular residence complies with the requirements of the Election Law is that the individual must manifest an intent, coupled with physical presence without any aura of sham. The charge, when read as a whole, was not confusing as a matter of law. It instructed the jury on how to determine whether the residence in question could be considered defendant's residence for voting purposes, and it informed the jury that if the proof established that defendant had two residences, he could pick one as long as the "residence" he picked was indeed a residence of his, and not a sham. The jury credited the testimony of the various witnesses, and duly applied the instruction to the facts it found. The jury was not asked to determine whether as between two residences defendant picked the more appropriate one. Rather, the sole issue was whether defendant genuinely took up one residence for voting purposes. In considering whether that residence was a bona fide residence from which defendant could vote, the jury needed to be informed of the Election Law's definition of residence, and it was not instructed to convict defendant if it found that he actually maintained two residences.

 

191 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Aliessa v. Novello


No. 73


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 418; 754 N.E.2d 1085; 730 N.Y.S.2d 1; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 1407


March 29, 2001, Argued  
June 5, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and case remitted to Supreme Court, New York County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff legal aliens sought review of a decision of the Supreme Court Appellate Division, New York, that held that N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 122 did not violate equal protection or N.Y. Const. art. XVII, § 1.


OVERVIEW: A group of legal aliens permanently residing in the United States under color of law (PRUCOLs) were denied Medicaid benefits by the state under N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 122. On appeal, they argued that § 122 violated the United States and New York Constitutions by denying them Medicaid benefits funded solely by the state based on their status as legal aliens. Upon review, the court of appeals concluded that § 122 did violate the Equal Protection Clauses of both the New York and United States Constitutions. Section 122 was subject to and could not pass strict scrutiny because it denied state Medicaid to otherwise eligible legal aliens permanently residing in the United States under the color of law and lawfully admitted permanent residents based on their status as aliens.


OUTCOME: The order of the superior court appellate division was reversed and remanded.



HEADNOTES

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Legal Aliens - Denial of State-Funded Benefits on Basis of Alienage Unconstitutional - State Constitutional Requirement to Care for Needy

1. Social Services Law § 122 violates the United States and New York Constitutions by denying Medicaid benefits funded solely by the State to plaintiffs based on their status as legal aliens. The concept of need plays no part in the operation of the statute, which cannot be justified on the basis of a distinction between "qualified aliens," i.e., aliens who are lawfully admitted for permanent residence (generally green card holders) or otherwise validly residing in the United States, and those permanently residing in the United States under color of law, i.e., aliens of whom the Immigration and Naturalization Service is aware but has no plans to deport, on the one hand, and citizens on the other. Section 122 violates the letter and spirit of NY Constitution, article XVII, § 1, which requires the State to provide for the care and support of the needy, by imposing on plaintiffs an overly burdensome eligibility condition having nothing to do with need, thereby depriving them of otherwise available basic necessity benefits.

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Legal Aliens - Denial of State-Funded Benefits on Basis of Alienage Unconstitutional - Equal Protection - Strict Scrutiny

2. Social Services Law § 122 violates the United States and New York Constitutions by denying Medicaid benefits funded solely by the State to plaintiffs based on their status as legal aliens. Inasmuch as section 122 creates classifications based on alienage, a strict scrutiny analysis is appropriate for considering plaintiffs' equal protection claim. Although section 122 implements title IV of the Federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act, whereby a State choosing to follow the Federal classification in determining the eligibility of qualified aliens for public assistance shall be considered to have chosen the least restrictive means available for achieving the compelling government interest of assuring that aliens be self-reliant in accordance with national immigration policy, the less stringent rational basis standard is inappropriate. Given our system of separation of powers, a lawmaking body may not legislatively declare that a statute meets constitutional criteria. Title IV cannot constitutionally authorize New York to determine for itself the extent to which it will discriminate against legal aliens for State Medicaid eligibility. Although the Federal government has broad constitutional power to distinguish among aliens in setting the rules for their admission and naturalization, Congress does not have power to authorize the individual States to violate the Equal Protection Clause.

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Legal Aliens - Denial of State-Funded Benefits on Basis of Alienage Unconstitutional - Equal Protection - Strict Scrutiny

3. Social Services Law § 122 violates the United States and New York Constitutions by denying Medicaid benefits funded solely by the State to plaintiffs based on their status as legal aliens. Section 122 is subject to and cannot pass strict scrutiny, notwithstanding the authorization of title IV of the Federal Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act, whereby a State may extend the ineligibility period for Federal Medicaid beyond the mandatory five years and terminate Federal Medicaid eligibility for certain refugees and asylees after seven years. Such authorizations improperly permit the States to adopt divergent laws on the subject of citizenship requirements for federally supported welfare programs. In the name of national immigration policy, title IV impermissibly authorizes each State to decide whether to disqualify many otherwise eligible aliens from State Medicaid. Section 122 is a product of this authorization. Accordingly, title IV can give section 122 no special insulation from strict scrutiny review.
