Thus, section 122 must be evaluated as any other State statute that classifies based on alienage, and it violates the Equal Protection Clauses of the United States and New York State Constitutions insofar as it denies State Medicaid to otherwise eligible persons permanently residing in the United States under color of law and lawfully admitted permanent residents based on their status as aliens.

 

192 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Ulster Home Care Inc. v. Vacco


No. 59


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 505; 757 N.E.2d 764; 731 N.Y.S.2d 910; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 1117


March 22, 2001, Argued  
May 10, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review reversed, with costs, and case remitted to Supreme Court, Ulster County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant state attorney general appealed, after brief remand to trial court, appellate division's (New York) declaration that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 18, § 505.14(h)(7)(ii)(a)(1) was unconstitutionally vague in defining rates customarily charged by a health care provider and order enjoining criminal prosecution of plaintiff health care providers.


OVERVIEW: Defendant New York attorney general commenced underlying civil enforcement proceedings to recover Medicaid overpayments and criminal prosecutions for grand larceny and false filing against plaintiff health care provider and individual employees. Plaintiffs brought their own action to enjoin criminal prosecution, also seeking a declaration that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. § 505.14(h)(7)(ii)(a)(1), identifying a reimbursement rate as the rate a provider charged the general public for personal care services, was unconstitutionally vague. New York's high court held that it was error to grant plaintiffs the relief they sought. The ordinary meaning of the regulation was not difficult to determine. Furthermore, it was improper to allow individual plaintiffs to forestall their prosecutions by making disingenuous constitutional challenges to a regulation the violation of which, if proven, supplied only one possible element of the offenses with which they were charged.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded for further consistent proceedings. Plaintiffs failed to show challenged regulation, the meaning of which was plain, was unconstitutional as applied to them. In any case, the challenged regulation related to proof of only one element of the alleged crimes.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Regulation - Medicaid Reimbursement Rates for Providers of Personal Care Services - "Rate" Charged to "General Public" Not Unconstitutionally Vague

1. A Medicaid regulation setting reimbursement rates for providers of personal care services at the lower of either the "rate" charged to the "general public" or the rate determined in accordance with a cost-based methodology ( 18 NYCRR 505.14 [h] [7] [ii] [a] [1] [i]) is not unconstitutionally vague. Neither the term "general public" nor "rate" as used in the regulation is so vague that it could not be understood by a person of ordinary intelligence, or could be arbitrarily enforced. The challenged language has a common understanding and is used in other State Medicaid and Medicare regulations. Moreover, application of the regulation is limited to home personal care providers who elect to enroll in the Medicaid program, who expressly agree to adhere to its rules, and who have had ample opportunity to understand the requirements of the Medicaid program.

Social Services - Medical Assistance - Criminal Liability - Overcharging for Providing Personal Services

2. It was error to enjoin the criminal prosecution of plaintiffs, providers of personal care services under the Medicaid program, where plaintiffs alleged that a Medicaid regulation setting reimbursement rates for providers of personal care services at the lower of either the "rate" charged to the "general public" or the rate determined in accordance with a cost-based methodology ( 18 NYCRR 505.14 [h] [7] [ii] [a] [1] [i]) was unconstitutionally vague. Plaintiffs were not subject to prosecution because they allegedly violated the regulation. Rather, the intended charges were grand larceny and offering false instruments for filing. The alleged violation of the regulation was only an element of proof of those crimes, and violation of the regulation alone, without a knowing attempt to deceive or defraud, could not support criminal liability.

 

193 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Clara C. v. William L.


No. 56


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 244; 750 N.E.2d 1068; 727 N.Y.S.2d 20; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 1113


March 21, 2001, Argued  
May 3, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and matter remitted to Family Court, Kings County, for further proceedings in accordance with the opinion herein. Certified question not answered upon the ground that it is unnecessary.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother challenged the judgment of the appellate division (New York), which affirmed a family court decision denying petitioner's request for a declaration of paternity and increased child support because of an existing support agreement pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 516.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner commenced a paternity proceeding against her former professor, respondent. Although blood tests revealed a 99.9 percent probability of paternity, the parties entered into a settlement agreement pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 516. After executing the agreement, the parties, along with the department of social services, appeared before family court for approval of the agreement pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 516(a). Ten years later, petitioner commenced the proceeding for a declaration of paternity, and an order increasing the child support. On respondent's motion, the hearing examiner dismissed the proceeding, concluding that it was barred by the terms of the agreement. The family court upheld dismissal of the petition, and petitioner appealed. The appellate court found that the family court's perfunctory approval of the agreement, without any determination as to its adequacy, failed to satisfy the requirements of N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 516. Nothing in the record indicated that the family court considered the parties' financial situation or whether the agreed-upon amount of support adequately met the minor child's needs throughout childhood.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was reversed and remitted to the family court.


HEADNOTES

Children Born out of Wedlock - Paternity Proceeding - Settlement Agreement No Bar to Seeking Additional Support Where Agreement Not Approved by Court with Regard to Child's Needs

1. A putative father may not invoke Family Court Act § 516 to bar a mother from seeking additional child support where the parties entered into a support agreement that was approved by a court without regard for the child's needs, notwithstanding that the father has lived up to the agreement since it was executed. The language of the statute is clear: a support agreement will be enforced "only when" a court has reviewed it and determined that adequate support for the child has been made. The purpose of judicial scrutiny is to ensure that the needs of nonmarital children are adequately met and not contracted away by their mothers, whose interests may not always coincide with those of their children. Accordingly, inasmuch as the court gave perfunctory approval of the parties' agreement, without any determination as to its adequacy, there was a failure to satisfy the requirements of the statute. Moreover, although the mother voiced no objection to the agreement for over 10 years, her failure to object does not justify enforcement thereof. Accordingly, the agreement is no bar to a paternity proceeding or the entry of an increased support order to meet the child's ongoing educational needs.

Appeal - Court of Appeals - Judicial Restraint - Deciding Case on Nonconstitutional Ground

2. In a proceeding in which petitioner mother sought a declaration of paternity and increased support from respondent, who alleged that a settlement agreement executed by the parties over 10 years earlier mandated dismissal of the petition pursuant to Family Court Act § 516, the Court of Appeals has no occasion to consider the constitutionality of the statute where it has determined that the agreement does not comply with the requirements of section 516. The Court is bound by principles of judicial restraint not to decide constitutional questions unless their disposition is necessary to the appeal. Because a compelling nonconstitutional ground resolves the present appeal, the Court refrains, at this time, from addressing the constitutional issues raised.

 

194 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



Tenn. Gas Pipeline Co. v. Urbach


No. 71


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 124; 750 N.E.2d 52; 726 N.Y.S.2d 350; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 1109; 149 Oil & Gas Rep. 342


March 29, 2001, Argued  
May 1, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, and Tax Law §§ 189, 189-a and 189-b declared unconstitutional as violative of the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant gas pipeline company sought a declaratory judgment against respondent tax commissioner, challenging its status under N.Y. Tax Law § 189, and challenging the constitutionality of that statute. Both parties moved for summary judgment. The trial court dismissed the complaint. The Appellate Division (New York) affirmed. Gas Pipeline Company appealed.


OVERVIEW: Gas pipeline company transported natural gas through New York to New England in pipes. Pumps within the state of New York used to transport the gas were powered by natural gas drawn off the line. The New York State Tax Department determined that gas pipeline company was a natural gas importer and owed $ 1.6 million in taxes under N.Y. Tax Law § 189. Gas pipeline company's declaratory judgment action challenged its status as a gas importer and challenged the facial constitutionality of N.Y. Tax Law § 189. Gas pipeline company argued that § 189 discriminated against interstate commerce and thus violated the Commerce Clause. The tax commissioner argued that the § 189 tax complemented taxes imposed under other sections of the tax law. The appellate court found that the § 189 tax was a valid compensatory tax. Gas pipeline company further argued that § 189 imposed a malapportioned tax. The appellate court found that since the § 189 import tax contained no credit for taxes assessed on the purchase of gas out-of-state, a double tax occurred and the statute crossed over from a permissible exercise of the state's taxing powers to an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce.


OUTCOME: The order was reversed, and N.Y. Tax Law § 189 was declared unconstitutional.



HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Valid Compensatory Tax - Natural Gas Import Tax

1. Tax Law § 189, which recaptures taxes on natural gas from end users who buy gas directly from out-of-State producers and avoid the taxes passed through by in-State utilities in the rates charged to customers, is a valid compensatory tax under the Commerce Clause. The statute discriminates against interstate commerce by imposing a tax on the out-of-State purchase of gas consumed in New York, while not taxing in-State purchases of gas used in New York. However, the tax rates imposed on consumers who purchase gas in-State are the same as those imposed on consumers who purchase gas elsewhere. The tax is imposed on the same activity, viz., the use of natural gas in New York, and reflects the "cost" of gas purchased in New York by utility customers. Moreover, because the in-State taxes are imposed on a receipt tax basis, the "pass-through" taxes will never be less than the import tax on comparable volumes of gas. While the "pass-through" taxes are franchise taxes and section 189 is an import tax, the taxable events are the sale of gas and the use of imported gas in New York. The taxes are also mutually exclusive; the consumer either buys the gas in-State or imports it. Thus, the taxes cannot overlap.

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Facial Unconstitutionality of Natural Gas Import Tax - Internal Inconsistency

2. Tax Law § 189, which recaptures taxes on natural gas from end users who buy gas directly from out-of-State producers and avoid the taxes passed through by in-State utilities in the rates charged to customers pursuant to Tax Law § 186, is facially unconstitutional. The taxes in question run afoul of the internal consistency test. Internal consistency is preserved when the imposition of a tax identical to the one in question by every other State would add no burden to interstate commerce that intrastate commerce would not also bear. However, if consumers buy gas in a State with a provision identical to Tax Law § 186, whereby utilities selling gas to consumers pass along a franchise tax representing the amount of New York's gas tax levy, they would pay a "pass-through" tax even though they exported the gas to New York where it was consumed. Because section 189 contains no credit for taxes assessed on the purchase of gas out-of-State, a double tax occurs, and the statute crosses over from a permissible exercise of the State's taxing powers to an unconstitutional burden on interstate commerce.

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Facial Unconstitutionality of Natural Gas Import Tax - Savings Clause

3. Tax Law § 189, which recaptures taxes on natural gas from end users who buy gas directly from out-of-State producers and avoid the taxes passed through by in-State utilities in the rates charged to customers pursuant to Tax Law § 186, is facially unconstitutional, and the constitutional flaw is not remedied by the statute's savings clause which permits the court to deem available any appropriate out-of-State credit. While the savings provision would appear to remedy the flaw in section 189 by providing a credit for any double taxation, it is invalid because it requires the Court to define the parameters of the credit and the manner in which it will be implemented. That, however, violates fundamental separation of powers principles, and would require the rewriting of the statute and creation of quasi-judicial tax regulations, a task for which the Court is not institutionally well suited.

 

195 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


In re Travis S.


No. 50


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 818; 752 N.E.2d 848; 728 N.Y.S.2d 411; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 1112


March 20, 2001, Argued  
May 1, 2001, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed, without costs, in a memorandum.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant was found to be a delinquent in a juvenile delinquency petition for an act constituting false personation in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 190.23. Appellant sought review from the Appellate Division of the New York Supreme Court, which affirmed the trial court's action. Appellant sought further review.


OVERVIEW: At the time of his arrest, appellant, who was 14 years of age, gave a false name, age and address. He continued to lie after being warned by a police officer that he would face additional charges if he gave false information. Appellant was originally charged with acts constituting the unauthorized use of a vehicle, and false personation in violation of N.Y. Penal Law §§ 165.05(1), 190.23. The unauthorized use of a vehicle charge was subsequently dismissed. The issue before the appellate court was whether N.Y. Penal Law § 190.23 was void for vagueness. The appellate court found that (1) the statute prohibited specific conduct, and (2) the statute was not subject to arbitrary enforcement.


OUTCOME: The order of the appellate division was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - False Personation

 Penal Law § 190.23, which provides that "[a] person is guilty of false personation when after being informed of the consequences of such act, he or she knowingly misrepresents his or her actual name, date of birth or address to a police officer or peace officer with intent to prevent such [officer] from ascertaining such information," is not void for vagueness on the ground that it fails to spell out the meaning of the requirement that people be informed of the "consequences" of lying to the police. A statute is unconstitutionally vague if it fails to provide a person of ordinary intelligence with a reasonable opportunity to know what is prohibited, and it is written in a manner that permits or encourages arbitrary or discriminatory enforcement. Penal Law § 190.23 makes a person aware of what conduct is specifically prohibited. Moreover, the term "consequences" in the statute clearly means that, for the statute to apply, the officer must first inform the defendant that giving false pedigree information subjects a person to criminal liability. The term thus has a limited meaning and is not subject to arbitrary enforcement.

 

196 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


People v. Rosen


No. 28


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 329; 752 N.E.2d 844; 728 N.Y.S.2d 407; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 943


February 7, 2001, Argued  
April 3, 2001, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied October 1, 2001, Reported at: 2001 U.S. LEXIS 6692.
Writ of certiorari denied Rosen v. New York, 534 U.S. 899, 151 L. Ed. 2d 160, 122 S. Ct. 224, 2001 U.S. LEXIS 6692 (2001)
Writ of habeas corpus granted, Stay granted by Rosen v. Walsh, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 26714 (S.D.N.Y., July 18, 2003)



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the New York Appellate Division's affirmation of the trial court's vacating defendant's plea and sending defendant to trial where he was convicted of first-degree sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pleaded guilty to first degree sexual abuse, the maximum sentence for which was seven years. The prosecutor then subsequently sought to have defendant sentenced as a persistent felony offender, which would increase his sentence beyond the maximum seven years. The trial court gave defendant an opportunity to recant his plea and explained that if defendant chose to retain the plea and were adjudicated a persistent felon, the court would consider the prosecutor's application and enhance the sentence. Defendant insisted on specific performance of the plea agreement, after which the court vacated the plea and sent the matter to trial. The trial court concluded defendant was a persistent felony offender based on two prior felony convictions and sentenced him to 25 years to life on the first-degree sexual abuse count and one year on the endangering the welfare of a child count. The Court of Appeals held defendant had no constitutional right to a jury trial to establish the facts of his prior felony convictions. It also held the trial court correctly vacated the plea.


OUTCOME: The order of the appellate division was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Argument That Discretionary Persistent Felony Offender Sentence Enhancement Provisions Violate Right to Jury Trial

1. Defendant's argument that discretionary persistent felony offender sentence enhancement provisions violate his right to trial by jury does not constitute a mode of proceedings error reviewable absent timely objection. While all factual determinations which may enhance a sentence must be submitted to a jury, prior felony convictions need not be. Under the statutory framework for enhancing sentences, prior felony convictions are the sole determinate of whether a defendant is subject to enhanced sentencing as a persistent felony offender. Although the court must consider other factors, that consideration is only part of its traditional role in ascertaining an appropriate sentence. Defendant has no constitutional right to a jury trial to establish the facts of his prior felony convictions. Accordingly, there was no mode of proceedings error in defendant's prosecution and, thus, any alleged error required preservation.

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Argument That Constitutional Rights were Violated Because Indictment Did Not Contain Discretionary Persistent Felony Offender Charge

2. Defendant's argument that his constitutional rights were violated because the indictment did not contain a discretionary persistent felony offender charge does not constitute a mode of proceedings error reviewable absent timely objection. Facts regarding recidivism increasing the maximum penalty need not be so charged.

Crimes - Trial - Mistrial - Improper Testimony Concerning Precluded Material - Refusal to Declare Mistrial Not Abuse of Discretion

3. In a prosecution arising from defendant's alleged sexual fondling of a four-year-old girl on a subway wherein the arresting officer testified concerning precluded material (i.e., defendant's prior sex-related convictions), the refusal of the trial court to declare a mistrial on the ground that such testimony was unduly prejudicial did not constitute an abuse of discretion. The court gave a curative instruction to the jury, striking out the prejudicial statements.

Crimes - Appeal - Preservation of Issue for Review - Argument That Trial Court Lacked Statutory Authority to Vacate Defendant's Plea

4. In a prosecution arising from defendant's alleged sexual fondling of a four-year-old girl on a subway, defendant's argument that the trial court lacked statutory authority to vacate defendant's guilty plea does not constitute a mode of proceedings error reviewable absent timely objection. Accordingly, defendant's failure to preserve precludes appellate review.

 

197 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Elliott v. City of New York


No. 33


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


95 N.Y.2d 730; 747 N.E.2d 760; 724 N.Y.S.2d 397; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 574


February 8, 2001, Argued  
 March 27, 2001, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Appeal after remand at Elliott v. City of New York, 2005 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 4503 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, Apr. 28, 2005)



DISPOSITION: Judgment appealed from and order of the Appellate Division brought up for review reversed, with costs, and a new trial ordered.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion for leave to appeal the order of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Judicial Department (New York), which modified the judgment of the trial court on the facts by directing a new trial in the negligence action on the issue of future lost earnings, unless plaintiff stipulated to a reduced award, and otherwise affirmed the judgment. The state high court granted leave to appeal.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff brought a negligence action against defendants after falling off a set of bleachers and sustaining injuries. Plaintiff alleged that defendants violated New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 27-531(a)(8)(d). The trial court granted plaintiff's motion for a directed verdict on liability, holding that defendants' violation of the provision constituted negligence per se. The issues of causation and damages, however, were submitted to the jury, which found defendants 100 percent liable for plaintiff's injuries. Plaintiff was awarded past and future pain and suffering damages, together with a past and future lost earnings award. The appellate court modified the judgment by directing a new trial on the issue of future lost earnings, unless plaintiff stipulated to a reduced award. Plaintiff stipulated to a reduction in his award. On appeal, the state high court reversed the judgment, advising that violation of a municipal ordinance constituted only evidence of negligence. The state high court determined that in the absence of a violation of a statutorily imposed duty in the case, a negligence per se finding was unwarranted and defendants were entitled to a reversal and a new trial.


OUTCOME: The state high court reversed the judgment appealed from and the order of the appellate court brought up for review, and ordered a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Tort Liability - Violation of New York City Administrative Code

In an action to recover damages for injuries plaintiff allegedly sustained after falling off of bleachers that lacked handrails, the trial court erred in determining as a matter of law that defendants' violation of Administrative Code of the City of New York § 27-531 (a) (8) (d), which requires protective guards at the open ends of bleacher seating, constituted negligence per se. Section 27-531 (a) (8) (d) was enacted as a local law and then designated as a section of the Administrative Code. As a rule, the violation of a State statute that imposes a specific duty constitutes negligence per se, or may even create absolute liability, whereas the violation of a municipal ordinance constitutes only evidence of negligence. The elevation of a violation of an ordinance, or an administrative rule or regulation, to a negligence per se standard would substantially recast the common law of the State. The specific nature of the duty imposed in Administrative Code § 27-531 (a) (8) (d) does not ameliorate the concern that only the Legislature can alter the State common law of negligence. Since the City retains the authority to amend or repeal its Administrative Code provisions, including section 27-531, without the need of State legislative action, the status of section 27-531 will not be transformed from that of a local enactment to a State statute.

 

198 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Affronti v. Crosson


No. 38


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


95 N.Y.2d 713; 746 N.E.2d 1049; 723 N.Y.S.2d 757; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 544


February 14, 2001, Argued  
 March 22, 2001, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Certiorari Denied October 1, 2001, Reported at: 2001 U.S. LEXIS 5664.



DISPOSITION: Order modified, with costs to defendants, by granting judgment declaring that the salary disparity between the Family Court Judges in Monroe County and Sullivan County is constitutional and, as so modified, affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, judges, sued defendants, Chief Administrator of Courts, state comptroller, and State, challenging N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 221-d, 221-e. The trial court held that salary disparities in state statute violated plaintiffs' equal protection rights. The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Fourth Judicial Department (New York) affirmed in part and reversed in part, and the state high court granted leave to appeal.


OVERVIEW: Current and former family court judges in Monroe County, New York, challenged N.Y. Jud. Law §§ 221-d, 221-e which set their pay at a level below the amount received by family court judges assigned to other counties. The state high court held that (1) because the classification was not based on an inherently suspect characteristic and it did not interfere with the exercise of a fundamental right, the rational basis test would be applied to evaluate the statute; (2) the fact that family court judges in other counties were assigned family court duties and other duties, and that the cost of living in other counties was different than it was in Monroe County, created a rational basis for pay disparities; and (3) because census data taken from the State Statistical Yearbook reflected a legislative fact, as opposed to an evidentiary fact, the appellate court could take judicial notice of that data for the first time on appeal, and use it when applying the rational basis test.


OUTCOME: The state high court modified the intermediate appellate court's judgment and granted judgment to the defendants. As so modified, the judgment was affirmed.


HEADNOTES

Judges - Judicial Salaries - Pay Disparity - Equal Protection - Rational Basis - Monroe and Suffolk County Family Court Judges - Putnam County Multi-Bench Judges

1. A rational basis exists for the judicial salary disparities between Monroe County Family Court Judges on one hand and Suffolk County Family Court Judges and Putnam County multi-bench Judges on the other. Therefore, the disparities do not violate equal protection and are constitutional. Putnam County Judges' multiple roles give rise to distinctions in their jurisdiction, authority, duties and caseloads, thereby precluding a determination of true unity of judicial interest in the compared posts. In addition, the Monroe County Judges proffered no proof that the costs of living in Monroe and Suffolk Counties are comparable and, thus, failed to demonstrate a true unity of judicial interest indistinguishable by separate geographic considerations. Accordingly, plaintiffs did not meet their threshold burden of demonstrating that they and the Judges from Putnam and Suffolk Counties were similarly situated for equal protection analysis.

Judges - Judicial Salaries - Pay Disparity - Equal Protection - Rational Basis - Monroe and Sullivan County Family Court Judges

2. In an action challenging the disparities in judicial salaries between Monroe and Sullivan County Family Court Judges, the State defendants submitted 1990 U.S. Census data from the 1996 New York State Statistical Yearbook (21st rev ed) demonstrating that median home values were approximately 3% higher in Sullivan County than in Monroe County--$ 93,400 to $ 90,700. The salary of a Family Court Judge in Sullivan County has been approximately 1% higher than plaintiffs' salaries since October 1987 and has never been more than 1.96% higher than plaintiffs' salaries (see, Judiciary Law §§ 221-d, 221-e). Therefore, the data illustrating the difference in median home values alone may provide a rational basis for the salary disparity.

Evidence - Judicial Notice - Consideration of Data for First Time on Appeal

3. In an action challenging the disparities in judicial salaries between Monroe and Sullivan County Family Court Judges, census data from the State Statistical Yearbook submitted by defendants, which was relied upon in prior judicial salary cases, is a proper subject of judicial notice because it is taken from public records. Moreover, because this data reflects a legislative fact, as opposed to an evidentiary fact, its absence from the record does not prevent its consideration for the first time on appeal. The data is not subject to dispute or courtroom factfinding; indeed, any effort to induce the Court of Appeals to utilize evidentiary facts to counteract arguable legislative assumptions would violate the rule that a legislative choice is not subject to courtroom factfinding. Accordingly, the census data is properly before the Court and provides a rational basis for the challenged statutes (Judiciary Law §§ 221-d, 221-e). Plaintiffs have failed to satisfy their heavy burden of proving that no reasonably conceivable state of facts supports the salary disparity.

 

199 of 1817 DOCUMENTS



People v. Fraser


No. 9


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


96 N.Y.2d 318; 752 N.E.2d 244; 728 N.Y.S.2d 115; 2001 N.Y. LEXIS 227


January 9, 2001, Argued  
February 20, 2001, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Related proceeding at Fraser v. Sleeper, 2007 Vt. LEXIS 238 (2007)



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with possessing sexual performance by child under N.Y. Penal Law § 263.16. Trial court precluded defendant from asserting affirmative defense based on scientific use pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 235.15(1). Defendant was convicted. Appellate Division (New York) entered order affirming defendant's conviction. Defendant was granted leave to appeal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant took his computer to a repair shop and a technician noticed child pornography files. Defendant had a master's degree in social work, was a certified social worker, and had extensive experience in treating victims and offenders of child abuse. The deputy commissioner of mental health for the county invited him to join a work group to develop a treatment program for persons convicted of child pornography crimes. Defendant testified that he possessed the child pornography for scientific research on developing treatment for such persons. Section 263.16 was not overbroad as applied to defendant, since the State had a compelling interest in protecting children. The New York statutory scheme, which treated the offenses under § 263.16 and N.Y. Penal Law art. 235 differently, only needed to be supported by some rational basis to survive constitutional scrutiny. There was nothing in Penal Law §263.00(4) that supported defendant's interpretation of the statute as allowing the possession of the prohibited material. Thus the mistake of law defense in N.Y. Penal Law § 15.20(2)(a) was not available to him.


OUTCOME: Order affirmed. Where defendant social worker was convicted of possessing child pornography on his computer, his defense that he possessed the material for scientific research purposes was not permitted, and his mistake of law defense failed.



HEADNOTES

Crimes - Possessing Sexual Performance by Child - Absence of "Scientific" Defense Does Not Render Statute Unconstitutionally Overbroad - Compelling State Interest in Protecting Children

1. In a prosecution for possessing a sexual performance by a child ( Penal Law § 263.16), defendant's First Amendment right of freedom of expression was not violated. The absence of the affirmative defense that the persons to whom allegedly obscene or indecent material was disseminated, or the audience to an allegedly obscene performance, consisted of persons or institutions having scientific, educational, governmental or other similar justification for possessing, disseminating or viewing the material (see, Penal Law § 235.15 [1]), does not render section 263.16 facially overbroad as applied to defendant, a certified social worker who claimed he possessed pictures of young children engaged in sexual activity with adults as part of his scientific research to develop treatment for persons transmitting child pornography on the Internet. The First Amendment does not protect pornographic material involving children. States enjoy greater latitude in regulating child pornography because of the government's compelling interest in safeguarding its children. It is irrelevant to the child who has been abused that the material in question has a literary, artistic, political or social value. Thus, the possible danger of infringement on serious literary, scientific, etc. works does not render the statute unconstitutional. On its face, New York's child pornography statute is more narrowly drawn than a sister State law that was found constitutional by the United States Supreme Court.

Crimes - Possessing Sexual Performance by Child - Absence of "Scientific" Defense Does Not Render Statute Unconstitutional Denial of Equal Protection - Compelling State Interest in Protecting Children

2. In a prosecution for possessing a sexual performance by a child ( Penal Law § 263.16), defendant's rights to equal protection under the Federal and State constitutions was not violated. The absence of the affirmative defense that the persons to whom allegedly obscene or indecent material was disseminated, or the audience to an allegedly obscene performance, consisted of persons or institutions having scientific, educational, governmental or other similar justification for possessing, disseminating or viewing the material (see, Penal Law § 235.15 [1]), did not violate the equal protection rights of defendant, a certified social worker who claimed he possessed pictures of young children engaged in sexual activity with adults as part of his scientific research to develop treatment for persons transmitting child pornography on the Internet. Section 263.16 allegedly criminalizes possession of the same pornographic material that would otherwise be allowed under Penal Law article 235 if the pornography were classified as obscene. The statutory scheme, which treats the offenses differently, need only be supported by some rational basis to survive constitutional scrutiny. The compelling State interest in eradicating child pornography and preventing child exploitation and abuse justifies the prohibition against child pornography. Because defendant has made no showing that the statutory scheme is irrational or contrary to public policy, the equal protection argument must fail.

Crimes - Possessing Sexual Performance by Child - Mistake of Law Defense - Possession of Child Pornography for Scientific Purpose - Belief That Digital Computer Image Not Photograph

3. In a prosecution for possession of a sexual performance by a child ( Penal Law § 263.16), the trial court properly refused to permit defendant, a certified social worker who claimed he possessed pictures of young children engaged in sexual activity with adults as part of his scientific research to develop treatment for persons transmitting child pornography on the Internet, to present a mistake of law defense (see, Penal Law § 15.20 [2] [a]). Penal Law article 263 does not authorize one to possess images on a computer hard drive of children engaged in sexual activity, if those images are not displayed to an audience, on the theory that the images technically were not photographs or other visual representations exhibited before an audience. Rather than showing that there was an official statement of the law contained in a statute authorizing his conduct, defendant maintains that a digital computer image is not a photograph within the meaning of Penal Law § 263.00 (4), which defines sexual "performance" as, inter alia, any visual representation exhibited before an audience. Defendant does not show that he relied on an official publication in construing the statute incorrectly. Thus, there is nothing in section 263.00 (4) that would support his interpretation of the statute as allowing the possession of the prohibited material. Accordingly, defendant only thought that the statutory exemptions permitted his conduct when, in fact, the primary statute clearly forbade his conduct.

Crimes - Possessing Sexual Performance by Child - Digital Computer Images as "Photographs"

4. In a prosecution for possession of a sexual performance by a child ( Penal Law § 263.16), computer graphic images may be considered "photographs" within the meaning of Penal Law § 263.00 (4), which defines sexual "performance." It cannot be said that computer graphic files containing images of children less than 16 years of age engaged in sexual conduct do not fall within the purview of the statute, on the theory that computer graphic images are not "photographs," or that they do not constitute an "other visual representation" because defendant did not "exhibit before an audience" the prohibited material ( Penal Law § 263.00 [4]). Such a narrow reading of the statute does not comport with reasonable interpretation. By enacting Penal Law article 263, the Legislature intended to employ broad measures to eradicate child pornography in all its forms. Consistent with that expressed intent, the graphic images stored in defendant's computer were either photographs that were converted to digital images by a scanner or taken by a digital camera. Defining digital computer images as photographs falls within the plain and natural meaning of the statute and gives effect to the objects of the law.

 

200 of 1817 DOCUMENTS


Garden Homes Woodlands Co. v. Town of Dover


No. 134


COURT OF APPEALS OF NEW YORK


95 N.Y.2d 516; 742 N.E.2d 593; 720 N.Y.S.2d 79; 2000 N.Y. LEXIS 3552


October 18, 2000, Argued  
 November 28, 2000, Decided



DISPOSITION: Order reversed, with costs, defendant Town of Dover's cross motion for summary judgment denied, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment against the Town of Dover granted and judgment granted declaring the subject special assessment levy invalid.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff property owners appealed the order granting defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (New York). Plaintiffs appealed denial of their motion for summary judgment based on lack of notice under U.S. Const. amend. XIV.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff property owners appealed grant of summary judgment in favor of defendant town, dismissing plaintiffs' claim that defendant towns failed to give proper notice under U.S. Const. amend. XIV for a special assessment of fees on plaintiffs' property. The trial court held that defendant town violated Dover, N.Y., Town Law § 239 by failing to hold a hearing prior to the assessment but that defendant adjoining town held the hearing and gave notice via a local newspaper. Also, the assessment did not constitute a divestiture of plaintiffs' title. The court found that plaintiffs were entitled to notice prior to the enactment of any special assessment, reasoning that where the interest of a property owner was substantially affected by an act of government, due process required that actual notice be given. Further, the court reasoned that a special assessment was no different than a tax sale or condemnation case and an owner was entitled to notice and a hearing prior to the assessment.


OUTCOME: The order granting defendant town's cross motion for summary judgment was reversed and the motion denied. Plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment was granted because plaintiffs never had the opportunity to object to a special assessment due to the fact that plaintiffs never received prior notice of a hearing.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Assessment - Notice to Taxpayer - Notice by Publication - Constitutional Requirement of Actual Notice - Due Process

1. Plaintiff, an out-of-State landowner, was deprived of due process by defendant town's notice by publication in a local newspaper of a special assessment, since plaintiff's interest as a property owner was substantially affected by the government action, and its name and address were known. Although defendant town complied with Town Law § 239, which only provides for notice by publication, compliance with this statute under the circumstances was inadequate to satisfy due process requirements. The opportunity to appear and object at the hearing provided for under section 239 is crucial: unless a property owner appears and objects to the proposed assessment, the owner will be forever barred from challenging the levy and will be responsible for paying the costs imposed. An objector has only 30 days from the date the special assessment is finalized to challenge it, and a failure to challenge would eventually result in a lien imposed upon the land. The right to appear and object is meaningless unless the property owner has notice that is reasonably calculated to apprise it of the proceeding. Significantly, the names and addresses of the affected landowners were indisputably known to defendant town because they appear on the special assessment roll, and there was no showing of other compelling or persuasive reasons, economic or otherwise, why direct notice could not be given.

Taxation - Assessment - Notice to Taxpayer - Notice by Publication - Constitutional Requirement of Actual Notice - Due Process - Taxpayer's Knowledge of Prior Assessments

2. Where the interest of a property owner will be substantially affected by an act of government, and where the owner's name and address are known, due process requires that actual notice be given. Plaintiff, an out-of-State landowner, was deprived of due process by defendant town's notice by publication in a local newspaper of a special assessment, and plaintiff may not be charged with knowledge of one year's assessment by virtue of its challenge to the prior year's assessment. The required hearings were not held for the prior year's assessments, and it was only after the imposition of the prior special assessment that plaintiff challenged its validity. Even with knowledge of a previous year's special assessment, plaintiff had no way of knowing whether the subsequent levy would be substantially different from the year before. Without notice, plaintiff never had the opportunity to object to the methodology employed in imposing the subsequent assessment and should not be compelled to rely on an earlier experience. The continuing nature of defendant's obligation under article 15 of the Town Law should not deprive plaintiff of its entitlement to receive actual notice of the scheduled hearing to consider the challenged special assessment, and an opportunity to attend and be heard.
